Kindle Highlights

Your Kindle Notes For: Thinking, Fast and Slow Daniel Kahneman Last accessed on Friday September 20, 2019 293 Highlight(s) | 0 Note(s) Yellow highlight | Page: 3 Many of us spontaneously anticipate how friends and colleagues will evaluate our choices; the quality and content of these anticipated judgments therefore matters.

Yellow highlight | Page: 5 we were far too willing to believe research findings based on inadequate evidence and prone to collect too few observations in our own research.

Yellow highlight | Page: 6 Amos was the more logical thinker, with an orientation to theory and an unfailing sense of direction.

Yellow highlight | Page: 6 I was more intuitive and rooted in the psychology of perception, from which we borrowed many ideas.

Yellow highlight | Page: 7 Did it occur to you that there are more than 20 male farmers for each male librarian in the United States? Because there are so many more farmers, it is almost certain that more “meek and tidy” souls will be found on tractors than at library information desks.

Yellow highlight | Page: 7 The reliance on the heuristic caused predictable biases (systematic errors) in their predictions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 7 We called this reliance on the ease of memory search the availability heuristic.

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 Our article challenged both assumptions without discussing them directly. We documented systematic errors in the thinking of normal people, and we traced these errors to the design of the machinery of cognition rather than to the corruption of thought by

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 emotion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 People tend to assess the relative importance of issues by the ease with which they are retrieved from memory—and this is largely determined by the extent of coverage in the media.

Yellow highlight | Page: 12 When the question is difficult and a skilled solution is not available, intuition still has a shot: an answer may come to mind quickly—but it is not an answer to the original question. The question that the executive faced (should I invest in Ford stock?) was difficult, but the answer to an easier and related question (do I like Ford cars?) came readily to his mind and determined his choice.

Yellow highlight | Page: 12 This is the essence of intuitive heuristics: when faced with a difficult question, we often answer an easier one instead, usually without noticing the substitution.

Yellow highlight | Page: 28 Our teacher took it for granted that the sympathy we would feel for the patient would not be under our control; it would arise from System 1.

Yellow highlight | Page: 34 The Invisible Gorilla had

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 you would be more likely to select the tempting chocolate cake when your mind is loaded with digits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 Another way of saying this is that controlling thoughts and behaviors is one of the tasks that System 2 performs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 42 ego depletion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 46 Intelligence is not only the ability to reason; it is also the ability to find relevant material in memory and to deploy attention when needed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 48 children’s ability to control their attention and their ability to control their emotions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 48 judgment? Stanovich published his conclusions in a book titled Rationality and the Reflective Mind,

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 The word evokes memories, which evoke emotions, which in turn evoke facial expressions and other reactions, such as a general tensing up and an avoidance tendency.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated—it has been called associatively coherent.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 cognition is embodied; you think with your body, not only with your brain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 David Hume reduced the principles of association to three: resemblance, contiguity in time and place, and causality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 effects (virus cold); things to their properties (lime green); things to the categories

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 exposure to a word causes immediate and measurable changes in the ease with which many related words can be evoked.

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 We call this a priming effect

Yellow highlight | Page: 53 your actions and your emotions can be primed by events of which you are not even aware.

Yellow highlight | Page: 53 influencing of an action by the idea—is known as the ideomotor effect.

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 if you were primed to think of old age, you would tend to act old, and acting old would reinforce the thought of old age.

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 Reciprocal links are common in the associative network.

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 you are likely to be rewarded by actually feeling calm and kind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 funding of schools was significantly greater when the polling station was in a school than when it was in a nearby location.

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 The general theme of these findings is that the idea of money primes individualism: a reluctance to be involved with others, to depend on others, or to accept demands from others.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 But your subjective experience consists largely of the story that your System 2 tells itself about what is going on. Priming phenomena arise in System 1, and you have no conscious access to them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 Evidently, a purely symbolic reminder of being watched prodded people into improved behavior.

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 Timothy Wilson wrote a book with the evocative title Strangers to Ourselves. You have now been introduced to that stranger in you, which may be in control of much of what you do, although you rarely have a glimpse of it. System 1 provides the impressions that often turn into your beliefs,

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 “His System 1 constructed a story, and his System 2 believed it. It happens to all of us.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 58 “I made myself smile and I’m actually feeling better!”

Yellow highlight | Page: 59 The surprise is that a single dial of cognitive ease is connected to a large network of diverse inputs and outputs. Figure 5 tells the story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 60 “Becoming Famous Overnight.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 greater cognitive ease in perceiving a word you have seen earlier, and it is this sense of ease that gives you the impression of familiarity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 pointing one way or another. You knew soon after reading them that the first two statements are true and the last one is false. Note, however, that the statement “A chicken has three legs” is more obviously false than “A chicken has four legs.” Your associative machinery slows the judgment of the latter

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 But there were questions where no good answer came to mind, where all I had to go by was cognitive ease.

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 The impression of familiarity is produced by System 1, and System 2 relies on that impression for a true/false judgment.

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 A reliable way to make people believe in falsehoods is frequent repetition, because familiarity is not easily

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 distinguished from truth.

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 true. It is entirely legitimate for you to enlist cognitive ease to work in your favor,

Yellow highlight | Page: 63 If you care about being thought credible and intelligent, do not use

Yellow highlight | Page: 63 complex language where simpler language will do.

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 performance was better with the bad font. Cognitive strain, whatever its source, mobilizes System 2, which is more likely to reject the intuitive answer suggested by System 1.

Yellow highlight | Page: 66 it. Zajonc called it the mere exposure effect.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 Indeed, the mere exposure effect is actually stronger for stimuli that the individual never consciously sees.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 The link between positive emotion and cognitive ease in System 1 has a long evolutionary history.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 creativity is associative memory that works

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 exceptionally well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 69 Mood evidently affects the operation of System 1: when we are uncomfortable and unhappy, we lose touch with our intuition.

Yellow highlight | Page: 69 when in a good mood, people become more intuitive and more creative but also less vigilant and more prone to logical errors.

Yellow highlight | Page: 70 “I’m in a very good mood today, and my System 2 is weaker than usual. I should be extra careful.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 73 “norm theory,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 73 “How many animals of each kind did Moses take into the ark?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 74 violations of normality are detected with astonishing speed and subtlety.

Yellow highlight | Page: 76 We are evidently ready from birth to have impressions of causality, which do not depend on reasoning about patterns of causation. They are products of System 1.

Yellow highlight | Page: 82 The tendency to like (or dislike) everything about a person—including things you have not observed—is known as the halo effect.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 A simple rule can help: before an issue is discussed, all members of the committee should be asked to write a very brief summary of their position.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 Good mood and cognitive ease are the human equivalents of assessments of safety and familiarity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 98 Substituting one question for another can be a good strategy for solving difficult problems, and George Pólya included substitution in his classic How to Solve It: “If you can’t solve a problem, then there is an easier problem you can solve:

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 Only visual artists and experienced photographers have developed the skill of seeing the drawing as an object on the page.

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 You were not confused about the question, but you were influenced by the answer to a question that you were not asked: “How tall are the three people?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 Paul Slovic has proposed an affect heuristic in which people let their likes and dislikes determine their beliefs about the world.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 attitudes, however, System 2 is more of an apologist for the emotions of System 1 than a critic of those emotions—an endorser rather than an enforcer. Its search

Yellow highlight | Page: 106 overweights low probabilities

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 Just as in the game of Jack and Jill, extreme outcomes (very high and/or very low cancer rates) are most likely to be found in sparsely populated counties. This is all there is to the story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 they are what scientists call artifacts, observations that are produced entirely by some aspect of the method of research—in this case, by differences in sample size.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 but they were wrong: the anchoring effect was 41%.

Yellow highlight | Page: 126 effects—sometimes due to priming, sometimes to insufficient adjustment

Yellow highlight | Page: 127 focuses his attention on the minimal offer that the opponent would accept, or on the costs to the opponent of failing to reach an agreement. In general, a strategy of deliberately “thinking the opposite” may be a good defense against anchoring effects, because it negates the biased recruitment of thoughts that produces these

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 the number of instances retrieved the ease with which they come to mind

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 The contest yielded a clear-cut winner: people who had just listed twelve instances rated themselves as less assertive than people who had listed only six.

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 Self-ratings were dominated by the ease with which examples had come to mind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 132 As you already know, frowning normally accompanies cognitive strain and the effect is symmetric: when people are instructed to frown while doing a task, they actually try harder and

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 experience greater cognitive strain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 availability bias.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 As expected, the students who listed more ways to improve the class rated it higher!

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 “unexplained unavailability” heuristic.

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 When the surprise is eliminated, low fluency no longer influences the judgment.

Yellow highlight | Page: 135 Merely reminding people of a time when they had power increases their apparent trust in their own intuition.

Yellow highlight | Page: 136 availability bias.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 136 “The CEO has had several successes in a row, so failure doesn’t come easily to her mind. The availability bias is making her overconfident.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 finding was that people who had received a message extolling the benefits of a technology also changed their beliefs about its risks.

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 Paul Slovic probably knows more about the peculiarities of human judgment of risk than any other individual.

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 inadequately sensitive to differences between low and negligibly low probabilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 140 genuine conflict of values.

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 Human beings have invented the concept of “risk” to help them understand and cope with the dangers and uncertainties of life.

Yellow highlight | Page: 142 cascade. They comment that in the social context, “all heuristics are equal, but availability is more equal than the others.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 142 An availability cascade is a self-sustaining chain of events, which may start from media reports of a relatively minor event and lead up to public panic and large-scale government action. On some occasions, a media story about a risk catches the attention of a segment of the public, which becomes aroused and worried. This emotional reaction becomes a story in itself, prompting additional coverage in the media, which in turn produces greater concern and involvement.

Yellow highlight | Page: 143 The Alar tale illustrates a basic limitation in the ability of our mind to deal with small risks: we either ignore them altogether or give them far too much weight—nothing in between.

Yellow highlight | Page: 144 Sunstein has coined the phrase “probability neglect” to describe the pattern.

Yellow highlight | Page: 144 insulating the experts from the emotions of the public produces policies that the public will

Yellow highlight | Page: 155 When the evidence is weak, one should stick with the base rates.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 158 The word fallacy is used, in general, when people fail to apply a logical rule that is obviously relevant.

Yellow highlight | Page: 174 Subjects’ unwillingness to deduce the particular from the general was matched only by their willingness to infer the general from the particular.

Yellow highlight | Page: 174 You are more likely to learn something by finding surprises in your own behavior than by hearing surprising facts about people in general.

Yellow highlight | Page: 176 The instructor had attached a causal interpretation to the inevitable fluctuations of a random process.

Yellow highlight | Page: 176 we are statistically punished for being nice and rewarded for being nasty.

Yellow highlight | Page: 182 mind is strongly biased toward causal explanations and does not deal well with “mere statistics.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 extreme groups regress to the mean over time. The correlation

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 mistake—confusing mere correlation with causation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 184 “She says experience has taught her that criticism is more effective than praise. What she doesn’t understand is that it’s all due to regression to the mean.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 The explanatory stories that people find compelling are simple; are concrete rather than abstract; assign a larger role to talent, stupidity, and intentions than to luck; and focus on a few striking events that happened rather than on the countless events that failed to happen.

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 we humans constantly fool ourselves by constructing flimsy accounts of the past and believing they are true.

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 The halo effect helps keep explanatory narratives simple and coherent by exaggerating the consistency of evaluations:

Yellow highlight | Page: 201 our almost unlimited ability to ignore our ignorance.

Yellow highlight | Page: 201 we apply the word know only when what was known is true and can be shown to be true. We can know something only if it is both true and knowable.

Yellow highlight | Page: 202 A general limitation of the human mind is its imperfect ability to reconstruct past states of knowledge, or beliefs that have changed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 204 The sense-making machinery of System 1 makes us see the world as more tidy, simple, predictable, and coherent than it really is.

Yellow highlight | Page: 206 In his penetrating book The Halo Effect, Philip Rosenzweig,

Yellow highlight | Page: 206 consistently exaggerate the impact of leadership style and management practices on firm outcomes, and thus their message is rarely useful.

Yellow highlight | Page: 206 halo. The CEO of a successful company is likely to be called flexible, methodical, and decisive.

Yellow highlight | Page: 206 confused, rigid, and authoritarian.

Yellow highlight | Page: 206 The halo effect and outcome bias combine to explain the extraordinary appeal of books that seek to draw operational morals from systematic examination of successful businesses.

Yellow highlight | Page: 207 good managerial practices can be identified and that good practices will be rewarded by good results. Both messages are overstated.

Yellow highlight | Page: 207 Because luck plays a large role, the quality of leadership and management practices cannot be inferred reliably from observations of success. And even if you had perfect foreknowledge that a CEO has brilliant vision and

Yellow highlight | Page: 207 “Most Admired Companies” finds that over a twenty-year period, the firms with the worst ratings went on to earn much higher stock returns than the most admired firms.

Yellow highlight | Page: 207 regression to the mean.

Yellow highlight | Page: 207 Stories of how businesses rise and fall strike a chord with readers by offering what the human mind needs: a simple message of triumph and failure that identifies clear causes and ignores the determinative power of luck and the inevitability of regression.

Yellow highlight | Page: 208 “Let’s not fall for the outcome bias. This was a stupid decision even though it worked out well.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 clear instance of substitution, and of the representativeness heuristic in particular.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 showed, people are often reluctant to infer the particular from the general.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 Confidence is a feeling, which reflects the coherence of the information and the cognitive ease of processing it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 confidence mainly tell you that an individual has constructed a coherent story in his mind, not necessarily that the story is true.

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 day. Most of the buyers and sellers know that they have the same information; they exchange the stocks primarily because they have different opinions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 does? For most of them, that belief is an illusion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 Everybody in the investment business has read Burton Malkiel’s wonderful book A Random Walk Down Wall Street. Malkiel’s central idea is that a stock’s price incorporates all the available knowledge about the value of the company and the best predictions about the future of the stock.

Yellow highlight | Page: 215 The results resembled what you would expect from a dice-rolling contest, not a game of skill.

Yellow highlight | Page: 216 The illusion of skill is not only an individual aberration; it is deeply ingrained in the culture of the industry.

Yellow highlight | Page: 216 Facts that challenge such basic assumptions—and thereby threaten people’s livelihood and self-esteem—are simply not absorbed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 217 it is not surprising that large numbers of individuals in that world believe themselves to be among the chosen few who can do what they believe others cannot.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 Even in the region they knew best, experts were not significantly better than nonspecialists.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 But those with the most knowledge are often less reliable.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 The reason is that the person who acquires more knowledge develops an enhanced illusion of her skill and becomes unrealistically overconfident.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 They are dazzled by their own brilliance and hate to be wrong.

Yellow highlight | Page: 220 Hedgehogs “know one big thing” and have a theory about the world; they account for particular events within a coherent framework, bristle with impatience toward those who don’t see things their way, and are confident in their forecasts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 220 Foxes, by contrast, are complex thinkers. They don’t believe that one big thing drives the march of history

Yellow highlight | Page: 220 The second is that high subjective confidence is not to be trusted as an indicator of accuracy

Yellow highlight | Page: 220 Let a sniper’s bullet move by a few centimeters and the performance of an officer will be transformed. I do not deny the

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 illusion of validity.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 Is this an illusion of skill?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 “She is a hedgehog. She has a theory that explains everything, and it gives her the illusion that she understands the world.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 “The question is not whether these experts are well trained. It is whether their world is predictable.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 222 Clinical vs. Statistical Prediction: A Theoretical Analysis and a Review of the Evidence.

Yellow highlight | Page: 225 a cool breeze on a hot day may make you slightly more positive and optimistic about whatever you are evaluating at the time.

Yellow highlight | Page: 226 “The Robust Beauty of Improper Linear Models in Decision Making.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 228 They know they are skilled, but they don’t necessarily know the boundaries of their skill.

Yellow highlight | Page: 230 simple, statistical rules are superior to intuitive “clinical” judgments.

Yellow highlight | Page: 231 intuition adds value even in the justly derided selection interview, but only after a disciplined collection of objective information and disciplined scoring of separate traits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 233 “Whenever we can replace human judgment by a formula, we should at least consider it.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 235 sculpture was a fake without knowing how they knew—the very definition of intuition.

Yellow highlight | Page: 237 “The situation has provided a cue; this cue has given the expert access to information stored in memory, and the information provides the answer. Intuition is nothing more and nothing less than recognition.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 237 The moral of Simon’s remark is that the mystery of knowing without knowing is not a distinctive feature of intuition; it is the norm of mental life.

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 When can you trust a self-confident professional who claims to have an intuition?

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 true experts know the limits of their knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 I argued that there are many pseudo-experts who have no idea that they do not know what they are doing (the illusion of validity),

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 We are confident when the story we tell ourselves comes easily to mind, with no contradiction and no competing scenario.

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 The associative machine is set to suppress doubt and to evoke ideas and information that are compatible with the currently dominant story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 ignoring what it does not know.

Yellow highlight | Page: 239 Klein and I eventually agreed on an important principle: the confidence that people have in their intuitions is not a reliable guide to their validity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 240 an environment that is sufficiently regular to be predictable an opportunity to learn these regularities through prolonged practice

Yellow highlight | Page: 241 However, it seems fair to blame professionals for believing they can succeed in an impossible task.

Yellow highlight | Page: 241 intuition cannot be trusted in the absence of stable regularities in the environment.

Yellow highlight | Page: 241 because of the long delay between actions and their noticeable outcomes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 270 Choices between such gambles provide a simple model that shares important features with the more complex decisions that researchers actually aim to understand.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 The errors of a theory are rarely found in what it asserts explicitly; they hide in what it ignores or tacitly assumes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 does not seem to fit the model, you assume that there must be a perfectly good explanation that you are somehow missing. You give the theory the benefit of the doubt, trusting the community of experts who have accepted it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 disbelieving is hard work, and System 2 is easily tired.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 That’s not surprising—she can only gain, so she’s risk averse. He, on the other hand, faces options that are all bad, so he’d rather take the risk.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 278 Harry Markowitz, who would later earn the Nobel Prize for his work on finance, had proposed a theory in which utilities were attached to changes of wealth rather than to states of wealth.

Yellow highlight | Page: 282 other, losses loom larger than gains. This asymmetry between the power of positive and negative expectations or experiences has an evolutionary history. Organisms that treat threats as more urgent than opportunities have a better chance to survive and reproduce.

Yellow highlight | Page: 284 When participants in an experiment were instructed to “think like a trader,” they became less loss averse and their emotional reaction to losses (measured by a physiological index of emotional arousal) was sharply reduced.

Yellow highlight | Page: 285 seeking. The pain of losing $900 is more than 90% of the pain of losing $1,000. These two insights are the essence of prospect theory.

Yellow highlight | Page: 285 Matthew Rabin finally proved mathematically that attempts to explain loss aversion by the utility of wealth are absurd and doomed to fail, and his proof attracted attention.

Yellow highlight | Page: 291 This preference for the status quo is a consequence of loss aversion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 295 Furthermore, economic theory correctly predicts both the final price at which the market will settle and the number of tokens that will change hands.

Yellow highlight | Page: 296 Selling goods that one would normally use activates regions of the brain that are associated with disgust and pain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 296 Brain recordings also indicate that buying at especially low prices is a pleasurable event.

Yellow highlight | Page: 297 The fundamental ideas of prospect theory are that reference points exist, and that losses loom larger than corresponding gains.

Yellow highlight | Page: 301 The sensitivity to threats extends to the processing of statements of opinions with which we strongly disagree.

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 The psychologist Paul Rozin, an expert on disgust, observed that a single cockroach will completely wreck the appeal of a bowl of cherries, but a cherry will do nothing at all for a bowl of cockroaches.

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 “Bad emotions, bad parents, and bad feedback have more impact than good ones, and bad information is processed more thoroughly than good.

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 The self is more motivated to avoid bad self-definitions than to pursue good ones.

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 Bad impressions and bad stereotypes are quicker to form and more resistant to disconfirmation than good ones.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 They cite John Gottman, the well-known expert in marital relations, who observed that the long-term success of a relationship depends far more on avoiding the negative than on seeking the positive. Gottman estimated that a stable relationship requires that good interactions outnumber bad interactions by at least 5 to 1. Other asymmetries in the social

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 We all know that a friendship that may take years to develop can be ruined by a single action.

Yellow highlight | Page: 302 Loss aversion refers to the relative strength of two motives: we are driven more strongly to avoid losses than to achieve gains.

Yellow highlight | Page: 305 A biologist observed that “when a territory holder is challenged by a rival, the owner almost always wins the contest—usually within a matter of seconds.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 308 reference-dependent fairness and has also shown that fairness concerns are economically significant, a fact we had suspected but did not prove.

Yellow highlight | Page: 308 The losses far exceeded the gains from the increased purchases produced by the lower prices in the new catalog.

Yellow highlight | Page: 308 Remarkably, altruistic punishment is accompanied by increased activity in the “pleasure centers” of the brain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 308 However, our brains are not designed to reward generosity as reliably as they punish meanness. Here again, we find a marked asymmetry between losses and gains.

Yellow highlight | Page: 310 Most often, however, you are just an observer to a global evaluation that your System 1 delivers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 311 The large impact of 0 5% illustrates the possibility effect, which causes highly unlikely

Yellow highlight | Page: 311 The improvement from 95% to 100% is another qualitative change that has a large impact, the certainty effect.

Yellow highlight | Page: 312 Because of the possibility effect, we tend to overweight small risks and are willing to pay far more than expected value to eliminate them

Yellow highlight | Page: 312 The conclusion is straightforward: the decision weights that people assign to outcomes are not identical to the probabilities of these outcomes, contrary to the expectation principle. Improbable outcomes are overweighted—this is the possibility effect. Outcomes that are almost certain are underweighted relative to actual certainty. The expectation principle, by which values are weighted by their probability, is poor psychology.

Yellow highlight | Page: 312 there is a powerful argument that a decision maker who wishes to be rational must conform to the expectation principle.

Yellow highlight | Page: 314 We retained utility theory as a logic of rational choice but abandoned the idea that people are perfectly rational choosers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 314 We took on the task of developing a psychological theory that would describe the choices people make, regardless of whether they are rational.

Yellow highlight | Page: 316 However, when an unlikely event becomes the focus of attention, we will assign it much more weight than its probability deserves.

Yellow highlight | Page: 316 people attach values to gains and losses rather than to wealth, and the decision weights that they assign to outcomes are different from probabilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 318 This is where people who face very bad options take desperate gambles, accepting a high probability of making things worse in exchange for a small hope of avoiding a large loss. Risk taking of this kind often turns manageable failures into disasters.

Yellow highlight | Page: 319 up. Because defeat is so difficult to accept, the losing side in wars often fights long past the point at which the victory of the other side is certain, and only a matter of time.

Yellow highlight | Page: 321 “They know the risk of a gas explosion is minuscule, but they want it mitigated. It’s a possibility effect, and they want peace of mind.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 323 that “highly unlikely events are either ignored or overweighted,

Yellow highlight | Page: 323 My current view of decision weights has been strongly influenced by recent research on the role of emotions and vividness in decision making.

Yellow highlight | Page: 323 Overweighting of unlikely outcomes is rooted in System 1 features that are familiar by

Yellow highlight | Page: 323 Emotion and vividness influence fluency, availability, and judgments of probability—and thus account for our excessive response to the few rare events that we do not ignore.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 People overestimate the probabilities of unlikely events. People overweight unlikely events in their decisions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 focused attention, confirmation bias, and cognitive ease.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 1. When you thought about the unlikely victory of a third-party candidate, your associative system worked in its usual confirmatory mode, selectively retrieving evidence, instances, and images that would make the statement true.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 Your judgment of probability was ultimately determined by the cognitive ease, or fluency, with which a plausible scenario came to mind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 You were asked to estimate the probability of the baby going home, but you almost certainly focused on the events that might cause a baby not to be released within the normal period.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 Our mind has a useful capability to focus spontaneously on whatever is odd, different, or unusual.

Yellow highlight | Page: 324 The unlikely event became focal.

Yellow highlight | Page: 325 The probability of a rare event is most likely to be overestimated when the alternative is not fully specified.

Yellow highlight | Page: 325 The absurdity disappeared when the same judges were asked whether the winner would be from the Eastern or the Western conference. The focal event and its alternative were equally specific in that question and the judgments of their probabilities added up to 100%.

Yellow highlight | Page: 330 The power of format creates opportunities for manipulation, which people with an axe to grind know how to exploit.

Yellow highlight | Page: 336 Broad framing was obviously superior in this case.

Yellow highlight | Page: 336 A rational agent will of course engage in broad framing, but Humans are by nature narrow framers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 339 the deliberate avoidance of exposure to short-term outcomes improves the quality of both decisions and outcomes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 340 the exaggerated optimism of the planning fallacy and the exaggerated caution induced by loss aversion.

Yellow highlight | Page: 341 “I would like all of them to accept their risks.” In the context of that conversation, it was natural for the CEO to adopt a broad frame that encompassed all 25 bets. Like Sam facing 100 coin tosses, he could count on statistical aggregation to mitigate the overall risk.

Yellow highlight | Page: 344 The disposition effect is an instance of narrow framing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 345 A rational decision maker is interested only in the future consequences of current investments. Justifying earlier mistakes is not among the Econ’s concerns.

Yellow highlight | Page: 345 account, when better investments are available, is known as the sunk-cost fallacy,

Yellow highlight | Page: 345 All too often a company afflicted by sunk costs drives into the blizzard, throwing good money after bad rather than accepting the humiliation of closing the account of a costly failure.

Yellow highlight | Page: 346 In the presence of sunk costs, the manager’s incentives are misaligned with the objectives of the firm and its shareholders,

Yellow highlight | Page: 346 Boards of directors are well aware of these conflicts and often replace a CEO who is encumbered by prior decisions and reluctant to cut losses.

Yellow highlight | Page: 346 The sunk-cost fallacy keeps people for too long in poor jobs, unhappy marriages, and unpromising research projects.

Yellow highlight | Page: 346 “accompanied by feelings that one should have known better, by a sinking feeling, by thoughts about the mistake one has made and the opportunities lost, by a tendency to kick oneself and to correct one’s mistake, and by wanting to undo the event and to get a second chance.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 346 Regret is one of the counterfactual emotions that are triggered by the availability of alternatives to reality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 347 Regret and blame are both evoked by a comparison to a norm, but the relevant norms are different.

Yellow highlight | Page: 347 Decision makers know that they are prone to regret, and the anticipation of that painful emotion plays a part in many decisions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 348 people expect to have stronger emotional reactions (including regret) to an outcome that is produced by action than to the same outcome when it is produced by inaction.

Yellow highlight | Page: 349 success is generally a more normal outcome than is failure.

Yellow highlight | Page: 354 The familiar System 1 mechanisms of substitution and intensity matching translate the strength of the emotional reaction to the story onto a monetary scale, creating a large difference in dollar awards.

Yellow highlight | Page: 354 The discrepancy between single and joint evaluation of the burglary scenario belongs to a broad family of reversals of judgment and choice.

Yellow highlight | Page: 355 As in the burglary scenarios, the preference reversal occurs because joint evaluation focuses attention on an aspect of the situation—the fact that bet A is much less safe than bet B—which was less salient in single evaluation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 356 phenomenon that Lichtenstein and Slovic had described. This was probably the first finding by experimental psychologists that ever attracted the attention of economists. Yellow highlight | Page: 359 The narrow framing of single evaluation allowed dolphins to have a higher intensity score, leading to a high rate of contributions by intensity matching.

Yellow highlight | Page: 359 the “human vs. animal” feature becomes salient only when the two are seen together. Yellow highlight | Page: 363 This is how Econs understand things. Their beliefs and preferences are reality-bound. In particular, the objects of their choices are states of the world, which are not affected by the words chosen to describe them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 363 The fact that logically equivalent statements evoke different reactions makes it impossible for Humans to be as reliably rational as Econs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 377 Jeremy Bentham opened his Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation with the famous sentence “Nature has placed mankind under the governance of two sovereign masters, pain and pleasure.

Yellow highlight | Page: 381 He told of listening raptly to a long symphony on a disc that was scratched near the end, producing a shocking sound, and he reported that the bad ending “ruined the whole experience.” But the experience was not actually ruined, only the memory of it. The experiencing self had had an experience that was almost entirely good, and the bad end could not undo it, because it had already happened. My questioner had assigned the entire episode a failing grade because it had ended very badly, but that grade effectively ignored 40 minutes of musical bliss. Does the

Yellow highlight | Page: 381 Confusing experience with the memory of it is a compelling cognitive illusion—and it is the substitution that makes us believe a past experience can be ruined.

Yellow highlight | Page: 381 What we learn from the past is to maximize the qualities of our future memories, not necessarily of our future experience. This is the tyranny of the remembering self.

Yellow highlight | Page: 383 The cold-hand experiment, like my old injections puzzle, revealed a discrepancy between decision utility and experienced utility.

Yellow highlight | Page: 383 System 1 represents sets by averages, norms, and prototypes, not by sums.

Yellow highlight | Page: 385 Tastes and decisions are shaped by memories, and the memories can be wrong.

Yellow highlight | Page: 389 As in the cold-hand experiment, right or wrong, people choose by memory when they decide whether or not to repeat an experience.

Yellow highlight | Page: 390 Others share my feeling, which is that I feel pity for my suffering self but not more than I would feel for a stranger in pain. Odd as it may seem, I am my remembering self, and the experiencing self, who does my living, is like a stranger to me.

Yellow highlight | Page: 391 short—not too much time in a neutral state in which she would not care either way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 399 the decision to get married reflects, for many people, a massive error of affective forecasting.

Yellow highlight | Page: 402 goals—one recipe for a dissatisfied adulthood is setting goals that are especially difficult to attain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 402 In part because of these findings I have changed my mind about the definition of well-being. The goals that people set for themselves are so important to what they do and how they feel about it that an exclusive focus on experienced well-being is not tenable.

Yellow highlight | Page: 402 We can infer from the speed with which people respond to questions about their life, and from the effects of current mood on their responses, that they do not engage in a careful examination when they evaluate their life. They must be using heuristics, which are examples of both substitution and WYSIATI. Although their view of their life was influenced by a question about dating or by a coin on the copying machine, the participants in these studies did not forget that there is more to life than dating or feeling lucky. The concept of happiness is not suddenly changed by finding a dime, but System 1 readily

Yellow highlight | Page: 402 Any aspect of life to which attention is directed will loom large in a global evaluation. This is the essence of the focusing illusion, which can be described in a single sentence:Nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 403 Californians were an error of affective forecasting.

Yellow highlight | Page: 404 Thoughts of any aspect of life are more likely to be salient if a contrasting alternative is highly available.

Yellow highlight | Page: 407 fancy car would make her happier, but it turned out to be an error of affective forecasting.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 412 For behavioral economists, however, freedom has a cost, which is borne by individuals who make bad choices, and by a society that feels obligated to help them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 413 and Sunstein call it choice architecture—has a huge effect on the outcome.

Yellow highlight | Page: 413 The default option is naturally perceived as the normal choice. Deviating from the normal choice is an act of commission, which requires more effortful deliberation,

Yellow highlight | Page: 417 Its operative features, which include WYSIATI, intensity matching, and associative coherence, among others, give rise to predictable biases and to cognitive illusions such as anchoring, nonregressive predictions, overconfidence, and numerous others.

Yellow highlight | Page: 417 Observers are less cognitively busy and more open to information than actors.

Yellow highlight | Page: 417 Organizations are better than individuals when it comes to avoiding errors, because they naturally think more slowly and have the power to impose orderly procedures.
