Yellow highlight | Page: 76 “In that instant I realized that journalism was not just about regurgitating the facts but about figuring out the point. It wasn’t enough to know the who, what, when, and where; you had to understand what it meant. And why it mattered.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 80 We began this chapter with two questions: How do we get people’s attention? And how do we keep it?

Blue highlight | Page: 80 “I also found something I had not expected—the most successful of these pieces all began with a mystery story. The authors described a state of affairs that seemed to make no sense and then invited the reader into the material as a way of solving the mystery.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 Mysteries are powerful, Cialdini says, because they create a need for closure. “You’ve heard of the famous Aha! experience, right?” he says. “Well, the Aha! experience is much more satisfying when it is preceded by the Huh? experience.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 Cialdini began to create mysteries in his own classroom, and the power of the approach quickly became clear.

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 “Normally five to ten minutes before the scheduled end time, some students start preparing to leave. You know the signals—pencils are put away, notebooks folded, backpacks zipped up.”

Blue highlight | Page: 82 Cialdini believes that a major benefit of teaching using mysteries is that “the process of resolving mysteries is remarkably similar to the process of science.” So, by using mysteries, teachers don’t just heighten students’ interest in the day’s material; they train them to think like scientists.

Blue highlight | Page: 82 Mystery is created not from an unexpected moment but from an unexpected journey. We know where we’re headed—we want to solve the mystery—but we’re not sure how we’ll get there.

Blue highlight | Page: 83 McKee says, “Curiosity11 is the intellectual need to answer questions and close open patterns. Story plays to this universal desire by doing the opposite, posing questions and opening situations.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 83 In McKee’s view, a great script is designed so that every scene is a Turning Point. “Each Turning Point hooks curiosity. The audience wonders, What will happen next? and How will it turn out?

Yellow highlight | Page: 83 McKee notes that the How will it turn out? question is powerful enough to keep us watching even when we know better. “Think of all the bad films you’ve sat through just to get the answer to that nagging question.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 In 1994, George Loewenstein,12 a behavioral economist at Carnegie Mellon University, provided the most comprehensive account of situational interest. It is surprisingly simple. Curiosity, he says, happens when we feel a gap in our knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 Loewenstein argues that gaps cause pain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 “Story works by posing questions and opening situations.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 Pokémon cards cause kids to wonder, Which characters am I missing?

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 One important implication of the gap theory is that we need to open gaps before we close them. Our tendency is to tell people the facts. First, though, they must realize that they need these facts. The trick to convincing people that they need our message, according to Loewenstein, is to first highlight some specific knowledge that they’re missing. We can pose a question or puzzle that confronts people with a gap in their knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 We can point out that someone else knows something they don’t. We can present them with situations that have unknown resolutions, such as elections, sports events, or mysteries. We can challenge them to predict an outcome (which creates two knowledge gaps—What will happen? and Was I right?).

Blue highlight | Page: 85 They work because they tease you with something that you don’t know—in fact, something that you didn’t care about at all, until you found out that you didn’t know it. “Is my daughter strung out on one of my old prescriptions? I wonder if I ate at the restaurant with the slime?

Blue highlight | Page: 86 In improving this message, we need to think about how to elicit interest rather than force-feeding facts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 This approach is inspired by the gap theory. The goal is not to summarize; it’s to make you care about knowing something, and then to tell you what you want to know.

Blue highlight | Page: 87 The improvement here is driven by structure, not content. Let’s face it, this is not a particularly interesting mystery. It would never make an episode of Law & Order. But our minds are extremely generous when it comes to mysteries—the format is inherently appealing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 The news-teaser approach can be used with all sorts of ideas in all sorts of contexts. To make our communications more effective, we need to shift our thinking from “What information do I need to convey?” to “What questions do I want my audience to ask?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 know. One complication is that people tend to think they know a lot.

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 If people believe they know everything, it’s hard to make the gap theory work. Fortunately, there are strategies for combating overconfidence. For instance, Nora Ephron’s journalism teacher prevented overconfidence by causing the students’ schemas of journalism to fail. He made them commit to their preconceived ideas and then pulled the rug out from under them.

Blue highlight | Page: 88 Making people commit to a prediction can help prevent overconfidence.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 Eric Mazur, a physics professor at Harvard, came up with a pedagogical innovation known as “concept testing.” Every so often in his classes, Mazur will pose a conceptual question and then ask his students to vote publicly on the answer. The simple act of committing to an answer makes the students more engaged and more curious about the outcome.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 The thirst to fill a knowledge gap—to find out who was right—can be more powerful than the thirst for slides and jungle gyms.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 If curiosity arises from knowledge gaps, we might assume that when we know more, we’ll become less curious because there are fewer gaps in our knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 But Loewenstein argues that the opposite is true. He says that as we gain

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 information we are more and more likely to focus on what we don’t know. Someone who knows the state capitals of 17 of 50 states may be proud of her knowledge. But someone who knows 47 may be more likely to think of herself as not knowing 3 capitals.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 Human-interest stories are fascinating because we know what it’s like to be human—but we don’t know what it’s like to have certain dramatic experiences.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 Gossip is popular because we know a lot about some people but there’s some information that we lack.

Blue highlight | Page: 91 The trick, Arledge said, was to give people enough context about the game so that they’d start to care.

Yellow highlight | Page: 91 Arledge intuitively made use of Loewenstein’s gap theory. How do you get people interested in a topic? You point out a gap in their knowledge. But what if they lack so much knowledge about, say, the Georgia Bulldogs, that they’ve got more of an abyss than a gap? In that case, you have to fill in enough knowledge to make the abyss into a gap.

Yellow highlight | Page: 92 The tool kit he developed for NCAA football stood the test of time. The way to get people to care is to provide context. Today that seems obvious, because these techniques have become ubiquitous. But this avalanche of context started because a twenty-nine-year-old wrote a memo about how to make college football more interesting.

Yellow highlight | Page: 92 Knowledge gaps create interest. But to prove that the knowledge gaps exist, it may be necessary to highlight some knowledge first.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 “Here’s what you know. Now here’s what you’re missing.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 Alternatively, you can set context so people care what comes next.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 Unexpected ideas, by opening a knowledge gap, tease and flirt.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 They mark a big red X on something that needs to be discovered but don’t necessarily tell you how to get there.

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 In Kennedy’s address to Congress, he outlined a series of requests to help the United States maintain its leadership during the Cold War. He asked for funds to achieve a number of strategic goals: to establish the AID program for international development, to expand the NATO alliance, to build radio and television stations in Latin America and Southeast Asia, and to shore up civil defense.

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 next, the ideas give us a sudden, dramatic glimpse of how the world might unfold. And not just how but why.

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 it’s important to remember that knowledge gaps are painful. “If people like curiosity,15 why do they work to resolve it?

Yellow highlight | Page: 97 When we’re skeptical about our ability to get people’s attention, or our ability to keep people’s attention, we should draw inspiration from Kennedy and Ibuka. And, on a smaller scale, from Nora Ephron’s journalism teacher and Nordstrom’s managers. Unexpectedness, in the service of core principles, can have surprising longevity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 Clearly, Aesop was illustrating a universal human shortcoming. The fable would not have survived for more than 2,500 years if it didn’t reflect some profound truth about human nature.

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 This truth is especially sticky because of the way it was encoded. The concrete images evoked by the fable—the grapes, the fox, the dismissive comment about sour grapes—allowed its message to persist.

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 Our favorite from medicine: “idiopathic cardiomyopathy.” “Cardiomyopathy” means something is wrong with your heart, and “idiopathic” means “we have no idea why yours isn’t working.

Blue highlight | Page: 99 Language is often abstract, but life is not abstract. Teachers teach students about battles and animals and books. Doctors repair problems with our stomachs, backs, and hearts. Companies create software, build planes, distribute newspapers; they build cars that are cheaper, faster, or fancier than last year’s. Even the most abstract business strategy must eventually show up in the tangible actions of human beings. It’s easier to understand those tangible actions than to understand an abstract strategy statement—just as it’s easier to understand a fox dissing some grapes than an abstract commentary about the human psyche.

Yellow highlight | Page: 100 California is one of only five Mediterranean climate regions in the world. (The others are the fynbos of South Africa, the matorral of Chile, the kwongan of Australia, and, of course, the Mediterranean.) These Mediterranean climate zones occupy only 2 percent of the world’s landmass but host more than 20 percent of its plant species. If you want to buy environmentally precious land, Mediterranean climates give you a lot of bang for your buck.

Blue highlight | Page: 101 These new strategies made sense—TNC could protect more areas than it could reach through “bucks and acres.” But they also had drawbacks. First, they were much less concrete to donors. Donors can’t “walk around on” a favorable government regulation. Second, they were also potentially demoralizing for employees—they made progress less tangible. When

Blue highlight | Page: 101 TNC was focused on land deals, Sweeney said, “it was easy to celebrate a deal closing, to tell everyone, ‘John and Mary got this land,’ and to pat them on the back.” These “milestone moments,” so great for morale, were harder to find in the new model. How could TNC make the new strategy more concrete?

Blue highlight | Page: 103 TNC named the oak savanna the Mount Hamilton Wilderness (based on its highest peak, the site of a local observatory). Identifying the area as a coherent landscape and naming it put it on the map for local groups and policymakers.

Blue highlight | Page: 103 tangible. But when you say, ‘The Mount Hamilton Wilderness,’ their interest perks up.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 The Mount Hamilton Wilderness is not a set of acres; it’s an eco-celebrity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 This is not a story about land; it’s a story about abstraction. TNC avoided the trap of abstraction—saving 2 million acres per year—by converting abstract blobs on a map into tangible landscapes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 Concreteness is an indispensable component of sticky ideas.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 “Unexpected” chapter, we talked about Nordstrom’s world-class customer service. “World-class customer service” is abstract. A Nordie ironing a customer’s shirt is concrete.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 Concrete language helps people, especially novices, understand new concepts. Abstraction is the luxury of the expert.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 If you’ve got to teach an idea to a room full of people, and you aren’t certain what they know, concreteness is the only safe language.

Pink highlight | Page: 107 Yale researcher Eric Havelock3 studies tales that have been passed down by word of mouth, such as the Iliad and the Odyssey. He notes that these tales are characterized by lots of concrete actions, with few abstractions. Why? The ancient Greeks certainly had no problem with abstraction—this was the society that produced Plato and Aristotle, after all. Havelock believes that the stories evolved away from abstraction over time. When they were passed along from generation to generation, the more memorable concrete details survived and the abstractions evaporated.

Blue highlight | Page: 111 Brown Eyes, Blue Eyes

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 Novices perceive concrete details as concrete details. Experts perceive concrete details as symbols of patterns and insights that they have learned through years of experience.

Yellow highlight | Page: 114 To build such machinery, the firm needed two sets of skills: engineers who could create brilliant designs, and skilled manufacturing people who could transform those designs into complex physical machines. If the firm was to succeed, these two sets of people had to be able to communicate smoothly.

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 It’s easy to lose awareness that we’re talking like an expert. We start to suffer from the Curse of Knowledge, like the tappers in the “tappers and listeners” game. It can feel unnatural to speak concretely about subject matter we’ve known intimately for years. But if we’re willing to make the effort we’ll see the rewards: Our audience will understand what we’re saying and remember it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 the moral of the story is to find a “universal language,” one that everyone speaks fluently. Inevitably, that universal language will be concrete.

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 When Boeing prepared to launch the design of the 727 passenger plane in the 1960s, its managers set a goal that was deliberately concrete: The 727 must seat 131 passengers,8 fly nonstop from Miami to New York City, and land on Runway 4-22 at La Guardia. (The 4-22 runway was chosen for its length—less than a mile, which was much too short for any of the existing passenger jets.)

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 With a goal this concrete, Boeing effectively coordinated the actions

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 of thousands of experts in various aspects of engineering or manufacturing. Imagine how much harder it would have been to build a 727 whose goal was to be “the best passenger plane in the world.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 Write down as many things that are white in color as you can think of. STOP. Reset your timer for fifteen seconds. Turn the page for the instructions for Step 2.   STEP 2 INSTRUCTIONS: Write down as many white things in your refrigerator as you can think of.

Blue highlight | Page: 120 Why does this happen? Because concreteness is a way of mobilizing and focusing your brain. For another example of this phenomenon, consider these two statements: (1) Think of five silly things that people have done in the world in the past ten years. (2) Think about five silly things your child has done in the past ten years.

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 Concreteness creates a shared “turf” on which people can collaborate. Everybody in the room feels comfortable that they’re tackling the same challenge. Even experts—even the Kleiner Perkins venture capitalists, the rock stars of the technology world—benefit from concrete talk that puts them on common ground.

Yellow highlight | Page: 129 To be simple—to find our core message—is quite difficult. (It’s certainly worth the effort, but let’s not kid ourselves that it’s easy.) Crafting our ideas in an unexpected way takes a fair amount of effort and applied creativity. But being concrete isn’t hard, and it doesn’t require a lot of effort. The barrier is simply forgetfulness—we forget that we’re slipping into abstractspeak. We forget that other people don’t know what we know. We’re the engineers who keep flipping back to our drawings, not noticing that the assemblers just want us to follow them down to the factory floor.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 A person’s knowledge of details is often a good proxy for her expertise.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 We’ve seen that we can make our ideas more credible, on their own merits, by using compelling details or by using statistics.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 It’s the Sinatra Test: If you can make it there, you can make it anywhere. Safexpress, a family-owned business

Yellow highlight | Page: 153 For an example that unites all three of the “internal credibility” sources—details, statistics, and the Sinatra Test—we can turn to Bill McDonough, an

Yellow highlight | Page: 155 So far we’ve talked about creating credibility by drawing on external sources—authorities and antiauthorities. And we’ve talked about creating credibility by drawing on sources inside the message itself—by using details and statistics and examples that pass the Sinatra Test. But there’s one remaining source of credibility that we haven’t discussed. And it may be the most powerful source of all.

Yellow highlight | Page: 156 The ads were a refreshing departure from the standard advertiser tool kit that attempts to paint powerful but irrelevant emotions on consumer goods—for instance, associating a mother’s love of her children with a particular brand of fabric softener.

Yellow highlight | Page: 156 Wendy’s did something more admirable: It highlighted a genuine advantage of its product and presented it in an enjoyable way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 156 the commercials developed a brand-new source of credibility: the audience. Wendy’s outsourced its credibility to its customers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 157 The spots implicitly challenged customers to verify Wendy’s claims: See for yourself—look at our burgers versus McDonald’s burgers. You’ll notice the size difference!

Yellow highlight | Page: 157 Testable credentials can provide an enormous credibility boost, since they essentially allow your audience members to “try before they buy.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 157 bait-and-switch version of “Where’s the Beef?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 158 Testable credentials are useful in many domains. For example, take the question “Are you better off now than you were four years ago?” Ronald Reagan famously posed this question to the audience during his 1980 presidential debate with Jimmy Carter.

Yellow highlight | Page: 158 The mission of the PCA is to emphasize that youth sports should not be about winning at all costs; it should be about learning life lessons.

Yellow highlight | Page: 159 Observing their own behavior, the coaches learn the lesson—how they found it easier to criticize than to support, to think of ten clever insults rather than a single consolation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 159 Thompson found a way to transform his point into a testable credential, something the coaches could experience for themselves.

Yellow highlight | Page: 160 event, to judge the event’s probability by its availability in our memory.

Yellow highlight | Page: 160 We intuitively think that events are more likely when they are easier to remember. But often the things we remember are not an accurate summary of the world.

Yellow highlight | Page: 163 But what’s more likely to stick with someone: hearing about someone who fooled someone else, or being fooled yourself?

Yellow highlight | Page: 163 It’s not always obvious which wellspring of credibility we should draw from. What Marshall showed so brilliantly was perseverance—knowing when it was time to draw on a different well. In this chapter we’ve seen that the most obvious sources of credibility—external validation and statistics—aren’t always the best. A few vivid

Yellow highlight | Page: 164 details might be more persuasive than a barrage of statistics. An antiauthority might work better than an authority. A single story that passes the Sinatra Test might overcome a mountain of skepticism. It’s inspirational to know that a medical genius like Marshall had to climb over the same hurdles with his idea as we’ll have to climb with ours—and to see that he eventually prevailed, to the benefit of us all.

Yellow highlight | Page: 167 The researchers theorized that thinking about statistics shifts people into a more analytical frame of mind. When people think analytically, they’re less likely to think emotionally. And the researchers believed it was people’s emotional response to Rokia’s plight that led them to act.

Yellow highlight | Page: 167 When people were primed to feel before they read about Rokia, they gave $2.34, about the same as before. But when they were primed to calculate before they read about Rokia, they gave $1.26.

Yellow highlight | Page: 167 These results are shocking. The mere act of calculation reduced people’s charity. Once we put on our analytical hat, we react to emotional appeals differently. We hinder our ability to feel.

Yellow highlight | Page: 168 IN THE LAST chapter, we discussed how to convince people that our ideas are credible, how to make them believe. Belief counts for a lot, but belief isn’t enough. For people to take action, they have to care.

Yellow highlight | Page: 169 Rather, the goal of making messages “emotional” is to make people care. Feelings inspire people to act.

Yellow highlight | Page: 171 The Truth campaign isn’t about rational decision-making; it’s about rebellion. And it made a lot of teens care enough to do something. In this case, that something was nothing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 171 In fact, many ideas use a sort of piggybacking strategy, associating themselves with emotions5 that already exist.

Yellow highlight | Page: 172 The movie questions the existence of absolute truth—or, at least, our ability to uncover it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 172 From Einstein’s view, things don’t look unpredictable; they look surprisingly orderly.

Yellow highlight | Page: 176 They called it Honoring the Game. People care about sports, they care about the Game. It’s a way of making the point that the Game and its integrity are larger than the individual participants.

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 John Caples is often cited as the greatest copywriter of all time.

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 He says, “First and foremost, try to get self-interest into every headline you write. Make your headline suggest to readers that here is something they want.

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 You Can Laugh at Money Worries if You Follow This Simple Plan Give Me 5 Days and I’ll Give You a Magnetic Personality … Let Me Prove It—Free The Secret of How to Be Taller How You Can Improve Your Memory in One Evening Retire at 55

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 Caples says companies often emphasize features when they should be emphasizing benefits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 “The most frequent reason for unsuccessful advertising is advertisers who are so full of their own accomplishments (the world’s best seed!) that they forget to tell us why we should buy (the world’s best

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 An old advertising maxim says you’ve got to spell out the benefit of the benefit. In other words, people don’t buy quarter-inch drill bits. They buy quarter-inch holes so they can hang their children’s pictures.

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 He says that the WIIFY—“what’s in it for you,” pronounced whiff-y—should be a central aspect of every speech.

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 “Even if it takes them just a few seconds to connect the dots between the feature you describe and the implied benefit, by the time they catch up, you will have

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 moved on to your next point, and they probably won’t have time to absorb the benefit … or the next point.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 Teachers are all too familiar with the student refrain “How are we ever going to use this?” In other words, what’s in it for me? If the WIIFY was that algebra made students better at video games, would any teacher hesitate to say so? Does any teacher doubt that students would pay more attention?

Yellow highlight | Page: 180 If you’ve got self-interest on your side, don’t bury it. Don’t talk around it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 180 It’s important, Caples says, to keep the self in self-interest: “Don’t say, ‘People will enjoy12 a sense of security when they use Goodyear Tires.’ Say, ‘You enjoy a sense of security when you use Goodyear Tires.’

Yellow highlight | Page: 181 avoid talking about abstract benefits (“People will enjoy a sense of security when they use Goodyear Tires”) and focus on personal benefits (“You enjoy a sense of security when you use Goodyear Tires”).

Yellow highlight | Page: 181 The Arizona study, though, took it a step further. It asked people to visualize the feeling of security they would get by using Goodyear tires.

Yellow highlight | Page: 181 the homeowners who imagined themselves subscribing to cable subscribed at a rate of 47 percent.

Yellow highlight | Page: 181 when it was published, was subtitled “Does Imagining Make It So?” The answer was yes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 182 It may be enough to promise reasonable benefits that people can easily imagine themselves enjoying.

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 Abraham Maslow14 surveyed the research in psychology about what motivates people.

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 Transcendence: help others realize their potential

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 Self-actualization: realize our own potential, self-fulfillment, peak

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 experiences Aesthetic: symmetry, order, beauty, balance Learning: know, understand, mentally connect Esteem: achieve, be competent, gain approval, independence, status Belonging: love, family, friends, affection Security: protection, safety,

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 stability Physical: hunger, thirst, bodily comfort

Yellow highlight | Page: 185 In other words, a lot of us think everyone else is living in Maslow’s basement—we may have a penthouse apartment, but everyone else is living below.

Yellow highlight | Page: 185 The result of spending too much time in Maslow’s basement is that we may overlook lots of opportunities to motivate people.

Yellow highlight | Page: 187 Lee is tapping into Maslow’s forgotten categories—the Aesthetic, Learning, and Transcendence needs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 188 The second question tested two versions of his greed appeal: “Would your firefighters prefer a large electric popcorn popper or an excellent set of chef’s carving knives as a thank-you for reviewing the film?” The first two calls yielded definitive answers to this question: “Do you think we’d use a fire safety program because of some #*$@%! popcorn popper?!” The marketer stopped asking about the free gifts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 189 But self-interest isn’t the whole story. Principles—equality, individualism, ideals about government, human rights, and the like—may matter to us even when they violate our immediate self-interest.

Yellow highlight | Page: 189 And perhaps the most important part of the story is this: “Group interest” is often a better predictor of political opinions than self-interest. Kinder says that in forming opinions people seem to ask not “What’s in it for me?” but, rather, “What’s in it for my group?” Our group affiliation may be based on race, class, religion, gender, region, political party, industry, or countless other dimensions of difference.

Yellow highlight | Page: 190 This model is the standard view of decision-making in economics classes: People are self-interested and rational.

Yellow highlight | Page: 190 The second model is quite different. It assumes that people make decisions based on identity. They ask themselves three questions: Who am I? What kind of situation is this?

Yellow highlight | Page: 190 And what do people like me do in this kind of situation?

Yellow highlight | Page: 190 There are no calculations, only norms and principles. Which sofa would someone like me—a Southeastern accountant—be more likely to buy? Which political candidate should a Hollywood Buddhist get behind?

Yellow highlight | Page: 191 But from the perspective of the identity model of decision-making, turning down the popper makes perfect sense. The thought process would be more like this: “I’m a firefighter. You’re offering me a popcorn popper to get me to view a film on safety. But firefighters aren’t the kind of people who need little gifts to motivate us to learn about safety. We risk our lives, going into burning buildings to save people. Shame on you for implying that I need a popcorn popper!”

Yellow highlight | Page: 191 to unite these two decision models. What if the marketer had offered to donate fifty dollars to a school’s fire-safety program in exchange for the firemen’s viewing the film? It’s less clear that this offer would have violated the firefighters’ sense of identity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 191 What should a Pegasus person do in this situation?

Yellow highlight | Page: 194 botched

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 articulate

Note:goko word

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 refine the core mission of their organization. The questions put to the attendees were difficult ones: Why does your organization exist? Can other organizations do what you do—and if so, what is it you do that is unique?

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 define the purpose of their organization in a way that would motivate other people to care about it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 199 Volunteers must care enough to contribute their time, donors must care enough to donate their money, and employees must care enough to stick by the organization

Yellow highlight | Page: 200 the sound of the orchestra but the intimacy of chamber music”—was

Yellow highlight | Page: 201 The reality is that they did in fact know better than anyone on earth why the duo piano was worth preserving. But the Curse of Knowledge prevented them from expressing it well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 211 quite enough to get the job done. Maybe

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 activity. Brain scans show that when people imagine a flashing light, they activate the visual area of the brain; when they imagine someone tapping on their skin, they activate tactile areas of the brain.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 People who imagine words that start with b or p can’t resist subtle lip movements, and people who imagine looking at the Eiffel Tower can’t resist moving their eyes upward. Mental simulation can even alter visceral physical responses: When people drink water but imagine that it’s lemon juice, they salivate more. Even more surprisingly, when people drink lemon juice but imagine that it’s water, they salivate less.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 Mental simulations help us manage emotions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 Notice that these visualizations focus on the events themselves—the process, rather than the outcomes. No one has ever been cured of a phobia by imagining how happy they’ll be when it’s

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 Mental simulation helps with problem-solving. Even in mundane planning situations, mentally simulating an event helps us think of things that we might otherwise have neglected.

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 Research has suggested that mental rehearsal can prevent people from relapsing into bad habits such as smoking, excessive drinking, or overeating.

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 Overall, mental practice alone produced about two thirds of the benefits of actual physical practice.

Yellow highlight | Page: 214 A story is powerful because it provides the context missing from abstract prose.

Yellow highlight | Page: 214 It’s back to the Velcro theory of memory, the idea that the more hooks we put into our ideas, the better they’ll stick.

Yellow highlight | Page: 217 Notice that many of the bulleted points from the first message are shown, rather than told, in the story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 217 We must fight the temptation to skip directly to the “tips” and leave out the story.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 When Fogle registered9 for a class, he didn’t base his choice on professor or class time like most students. He based which classes to register on whether he could fit into the classroom seats.

Yellow highlight | Page: 225 Just as there are ad templates that have been proven effective, so, too, there are story templates that have been proven effective. Learning the templates gives our spotting ability a huge boost.

Yellow highlight | Page: 227 Challenge plots are inspiring in a defined way. They inspire us by appealing to our perseverance and courage. They make us want to work harder, take on new challenges, overcome obstacles.

Yellow highlight | Page: 232 Someone in charge of a vital operation needed information. He went looking for it, found it, and, as a result, was able to act more effectively.

Yellow highlight | Page: 234 Denning talks about engaging the “little voice inside the head,”18 the voice that would normally debate the speaker’s points.

Yellow highlight | Page: 234 “The conventional view of communication is to ignore the little voice inside the head and hope it stays quiet and that the message will somehow get through,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 234 “Don’t ignore the little voice. … Instead, work in harmony with it. Engage it by giving it something to do. Tell a story in a way that elicits a second story from the little voice.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 234 In addition to creating buy-in, springboard stories mobilize people to act. Stories focus people on potential solutions. Telling stories with visible goals and barriers shifts the audience into a problem-solving mode.

Yellow highlight | Page: 234 A springboard story is an exercise in mass customization—each audience member uses the story as a springboard to slightly different destinations.

Yellow highlight | Page: 237 In the “Simple” and “Unexpected” chapters, we said that good messages must move from common sense to uncommon sense.

Yellow highlight | Page: 243 The first villain is the natural tendency to bury the lead—to get lost in a sea of information.

Yellow highlight | Page: 243 One of the worst things about knowing a lot, or having access to a lot of information, is that we’re tempted to share it all.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 The second villain is the tendency to focus on the presentation rather than on the message.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 The first is decision paralysis—the anxiety and irrationality that can emerge from excessive choice or ambiguous situations. Think about the students who missed both a fantastic lecture and a great film because they couldn’t decide which one was better, or how hard it was for Jeff Hawkins, the leader of the Palm Pilot development group, to get his team to focus on a few issues rather than on many. To beat decision paralysis, communicators have to do the hard work of finding the core.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 The archvillain of sticky ideas, as you know by now, is the Curse of Knowledge. The Stanford students didn’t face the Curse of Knowledge

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 them—they were more akin to reporters trying to avoid burying the lead on a news story than to experts who have forgotten what it’s like not to know something.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 The Curse of Knowledge is a worthy adversary, because in some sense it’s inevitable. Getting a message across has two stages: the Answer stage and the Telling Others stage. In the Answer stage, you use your expertise to arrive at the idea that you want to share. Doctors study for a decade to be capable of giving the Answer. Business managers may deliberate for months to arrive at the Answer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 Here’s the rub: The same factors that worked to your advantage in the Answer stage will backfire on you during the Telling Others stage. To get the Answer, you need expertise, but you can’t dissociate expertise from the Curse of Knowledge. You know things that others don’t know, and you can’t remember what it was like not to know those things. So when you get around to sharing the Answer, you’ll tend to communicate as if your audience were you.

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 There is a curious disconnect between the amount of time we invest in training people how to arrive at the Answer and the amount of time we invest in training them how to Tell Others.

Note:made a good point

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 College professors take dozens of courses in their areas of expertise but none on how to teach.

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 A lot of engineers would scoff at a training program about Telling Others.

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 clicked through a PowerPoint

Yellow highlight | Page: 245 If they’re good speakers, they may even have created an enhanced sense,

Yellow highlight | Page: 246 They’ve shared data, but they haven’t created ideas that are useful and lasting. Nothing stuck.

Yellow highlight | Page: 246 Framework For an idea to stick, for it to be useful and lasting, it’s got to make the audience: Pay attention Understand and remember it Agree/Believe Care Be able to act on

Yellow highlight | Page: 247 “No one is listening to me” or “They seem bored—they hear this stuff all the time.” SOLUTION: Surprise them by breaking their guessing machines—tell them something that is uncommon sense.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Create curiosity gaps—tell people just enough for them to realize the piece that’s missing from their knowledge.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Or create mysteries or puzzles that are slowly solved over the course of the communication.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Make the message simpler and use concrete language.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Or use concrete, real-world examples. Don’t talk about “knowledge management”; tell a story about a health worker in Zambia getting information on malaria from the Internet.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Create a highly concrete turf where people can apply their knowledge. (Think of the venture-capital pitch for a portable computer where the entrepreneur tossed his binder onto the table, sparking brainstorming.) Have people grapple with specific examples or cases rather than concepts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 248 Find the telling details for your message—the equivalent of the dancing seventy-three-year-old man, or the textile factory so environmentally friendly that it actually cleans the water pouring through it. Use fewer authorities and more antiauthorities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 “They quibble with everything I say” or “I spend all my time arguing with them about this.” SOLUTION: Quiet the audience’s mental skeptics by using a springboard story, switching them into creative mode.

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 Move away from statistics and facts toward meaningful examples. Use an

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 anecdote that passes the Sinatra Test.

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 Remember the Mother Teresa effect—people care more about individuals than they do about abstractions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 Tell them an inspiring Challenge plot or Creativity plot story. Tap into their sense of their own identities, like the “Don’t Mess with Texas” ads, which suggested that not littering was the Texan thing to

Yellow highlight | Page: 249 “The things that used to get people excited just aren’t doing it anymore.” SOLUTION: Get out of Maslow’s basement and try appealing to more profound types of self-interest.

Yellow highlight | Page: 253 Beat decision paralysis through relentless prioritization: “It’s the economy, stupid.” Clinic: Sun exposure. Names, names, names.

Yellow highlight | Page: 253 Simple = core + compact. Proverbs: sound bites that are profound. Visual proverbs: The Palm Pilot wood block. How to pack a lot of punch into a compact communication: (1) Using what’s there: Tap into existing schemas. The pomelo. (2) Create a high concept pitch: “Die Hard on a bus.” (3) Use a generative analogy: Disney’s “cast members.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 254 GET ATTENTION: SURPRISE. The successful flight safety announcement. Break a pattern!

Yellow highlight | Page: 254 Break people’s guessing machines (on a core issue). The surprise brow: a pause to collect information. Avoid gimmicky surprise—make it “postdictable.” “The Nordie who …” “There will be no school next Thursday.” Clinic: Too much on foreign aid?

Yellow highlight | Page: 255 Talk about people, not data:

Yellow highlight | Page: 256 APPEAL TO IDENTITY.

Yellow highlight | Page: 256 The firemen who rejected the popcorn popper. Understand how people make decisions based on identity. (Who am I? What kind of situation is this? And what do people like me do in this kind of situation?)

Your Kindle Notes For: The Charisma Myth: Master the Art of Personal Magnetism Olivia Fox Cabane Last accessed on Wednesday January 23, 2019 336 Highlight(s) | 0 Note(s) Yellow highlight | Location: 79 charisma is a skill that you can learn and practice.

Yellow highlight | Location: 85 It can determine whether you’re seen as a follower or a leader,

Yellow highlight | Location: 85 whether your ideas get adopted, and how effectively your projects are implemented.

Yellow highlight | Location: 105 It’s Not Magic, It’s Learned Behaviors

Yellow highlight | Location: 129 When you meet a charismatic person, you get the impression that they have a lot of power and they like you a lot.

Yellow highlight | Location: 131 impression that you possess both high power and high warmth, since charismatic behaviors project a combination of these two qualities.

Yellow highlight | Location: 132 “Fight or flight?” is the power question. “Friend or foe?” is the warmth question.

Yellow highlight | Location: 135 Presence is the single most requested aspect of charisma when I’m coaching executives.

Yellow highlight | Location: 138 you not only feel his power and a sense of warm engagement, you also feel that he’s completely here with you, in this moment. Present.

Yellow highlight | Location: 145 It involves managing your mental ecosystem, understanding and attending to your own needs, as well as knowing which behaviors inspire others to see you as charismatic and learning how to project them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 153 The world will become your lab, and every time you meet someone, you’ll get an opportunity to experiment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 164 “After dining with Mr. Gladstone, I thought he was the cleverest person in England. But after dining with Mr. Disraeli, I thought I was the cleverest person in England.” Guess who won the election? It was the man who made others feel intelligent, impressive, and fascinating: Benjamin Disraeli.

Yellow highlight | Location: 174 But introversion is not a terminal handicap. In fact, as we’ll see, it can be a strong advantage for certain forms of charisma.

Yellow highlight | Location: 181 Last but not least, you won’t have to change your personality. In order to become more charismatic, you don’t have to force yourself into one particular personality style

Yellow highlight | Location: 185 Lower the intonation of your voice at the end of your sentences. Reduce how quickly and how often you nod. Pause for two full seconds before you speak.

Pink highlight | Location: 222 CHARISMATIC BEHAVIOR CAN be broken down into three core elements: presence, power, and warmth.

Yellow highlight | Location: 225 In order to be charismatic, we need to choose mental states that make our body language, words, and behaviors flow together and express the three core elements of charisma.

Yellow highlight | Location: 285 When you’re fully present, it shows in your body language in a highly charisma-enhancing way.

Yellow highlight | Location: 286 Being charismatic does not depend on how much time you have but on how fully present you are in each interaction.

Yellow highlight | Location: 288 The people you’re with feel that they have your full attention and that they are the most important thing in the world to you at that moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 298 “In most moments we have a continuous internal commentary on what is happening and what we should do next. We might greet a friend with a hug, but the warmth of our greeting becomes blurred by our computations about how long to embrace or what we’re going to say when we’re done. We rush through the motions, not fully present.” Being present enables you to fully notice and drink in the good moments.

Yellow highlight | Location: 307 We look for clues of power in someone’s appearance, in others’ reaction to this person, and, most of all, in the person’s body language.

Yellow highlight | Location: 308 others. Warmth tells us whether or not people will want to use whatever power they have in our favor.

Yellow highlight | Location: 310 Warmth is assessed almost entirely through body language and behavior; it’s evaluated more directly than power.

Yellow highlight | Location: 322 warmth. The combination of power and warmth would have been very rare and very, very precious:

Pink highlight | Location: 327 From lab experiments to neuroimaging, research has consistently shown that they are the two dimensions we evaluate first and foremost in assessing other people.3 Both power and warmth are necessary conditions for charisma.

Yellow highlight | Location: 341 Though this may sound incredible—how could words carry so little weight compared to the body language of the person delivering them?—it actually makes sense. In the scope of human evolution, language is a relatively recent invention.

Yellow highlight | Location: 344 This is why nonverbal communication has a far greater impact.

Yellow highlight | Location: 359 The second consequence is that our body language expresses our mental state whether we like it or not.

Yellow highlight | Location: 364 (remember, people can read your face in as little as seventeen milliseconds).

Yellow highlight | Location: 375 Thus, the first step in learning charisma—and what the first part of this book is all about—is developing the various mental states that produce charismatic body language and behaviors.

Yellow highlight | Location: 389 Individuals with strong internal skills are aware of what exactly is happening inside them and know how to handle

Yellow highlight | Location: 399 “To know others is knowledge. To know oneself is wisdom.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 400 Knowing your internal world starts with one key insight upon which all charisma is built: your mind can’t tell fact from fiction. This is the one dimension of your internal world that can help you get into the right charismatic mental state at will, and almost instantly.

Yellow highlight | Location: 423 The placebo effect is the basis for many of the best charisma-enhancing techniques,

Yellow highlight | Location: 436 When you exhibit presence, those around you feel listened to, respected, and valued.

Yellow highlight | Location: 438 exhibit presence, power, and warmth—you must display charismatic body language.

Yellow highlight | Location: 440 by creating a charismatic internal state your body language will authentically display charisma.

Yellow highlight | Location: 441 critical. Get the internal state right, and the right charismatic behaviors and body language will pour forth automatically.

Yellow highlight | Location: 472 In fact, that’s probably exactly what will happen, because most of us tend to interpret events—whether they’re personal or impersonal—as relating to us.

Yellow highlight | Location: 475 When interacting with someone, assume that he or she will feel (at least on a subconscious level) that whatever you do relates to him or to her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 482 Prevent Recognize Remedy or explain

Yellow highlight | Location: 484 “An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure”

Yellow highlight | Location: 492 (this means you can take deep belly breaths, not shallow chest breaths). How well you breathe affects how much oxygen gets to your brain, and therefore how well you perform mentally.

Yellow highlight | Location: 524 For many of us, a state of doubt or uncertainty is an uncomfortable place to be.

Yellow highlight | Location: 526 Our inability to tolerate uncertainty carries multiple costs.

Yellow highlight | Location: 529 Anxiety is a serious drawback to charisma. First, it impacts our internal state: quite obviously, it’s hard to be fully present while you’re feeling anxious. Anxiety can also lower our confidence. Anxiety, low presence, and low confidence can show up directly in our body language, as well as reduce our ability to emanate warmth.

Yellow highlight | Location: 531 Yet if there’s one thing that’s certain, it’s that uncertainty isn’t going away.

Yellow highlight | Location: 533 Those who are better at handling it will gain a distinctive advantage over others.

Yellow highlight | Location: 537 But how many of us have felt our minds going over the different outcomes again and again, rehashing the various plans we’ve made, replaying possible scenarios, mentally rehearsing the upcoming conversations not just once or twice but ad nauseam?

Yellow highlight | Location: 547 The reason Tom couldn’t let go is that our minds are fundamentally uncomfortable with uncertainty.

Yellow highlight | Location: 548 The minute our brain registers ambiguity, it flashes an error signal. Uncertainty registers as a tension: something that must be corrected before we can feel comfortable again.

Pink highlight | Location: 549 Our natural discomfort with uncertainty is yet another legacy of our survival instincts. We tend to be more comfortable with what is familiar, which obviously hasn’t killed us yet, than with what is unknown or uncertain, which could turn out to be dangerous.

Yellow highlight | Location: 552 the ability to be comfortable with uncertainty and ambiguity turns out to be one of the strongest predictors of success in business.

Yellow highlight | Location: 558 The single most effective technique I’ve found to alleviate the discomfort of uncertainty is the responsibility transfer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 577 If you did feel something happen, fantastic: you’ve just performed a responsibility transfer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 580 The reason this technique works is that when presented with a scenario, our brain’s first reaction is to consider it as possible.

Yellow highlight | Location: 585 may last only a brief moment, it’s enough to produce an emotional and physical reassurance,

Yellow highlight | Location: 591 However, the responsibility transfer works without trying to negate uncertainty. Instead, it helps you to be less affected by it, drawing you out of the negative mental and physical states that often accompany a position of not knowing.

Yellow highlight | Location: 593 By presenting your mind with the possibility that responsibility has been transferred, you’re putting to good use the wonderful placebo effect—the brain’s inability to distinguish between imagination and reality.

Yellow highlight | Location: 603 Personally, I’ve chosen to believe in a benevolent Universe, which has a grand master plan for me (and for everything else).

Yellow highlight | Location: 605 perform a quick visualization to transfer responsibility. It’s amazing to feel the instant sense of relief and the warmth, calm, and serenity rising. I feel my whole body relax, and it’s as if my whole being starts to glow.

Yellow highlight | Location: 607 Dissatisfaction Caused by Comparison

Yellow highlight | Location: 611 Human beings are by nature driven to compare.

Yellow highlight | Location: 614 The very act of comparing and evaluating hinders our ability to be fully present.

Yellow highlight | Location: 616 And a negative evaluation can easily put us in a negative mental state, such as dissatisfaction, envy, or resentment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 623 Few things impact people’s performance more than how they feel about themselves.

Yellow highlight | Location: 624 Athletes will tell you that a bad mental state will affect their performance no matter how well prepared they are physically. Psychological negativity can have real physical consequences.

Pink highlight | Location: 625 When our internal voice starts criticizing us, lashing out, it can feel like we’re under attack. Because our brain doesn’t distinguish between imagination and reality, these internal attacks are perceived by our mind just as a real, physical attack would be, and they can generate an automatic physical reaction known as the threat response or fight-or-flight response.

Pink highlight | Location: 628 The effects of this activation are well-known. Just as a zebra reacts to the stress of being chased by a lion, the human body shoots adrenaline and cortisol (stress hormones) through its veins, and directs all its resources toward crucial functions: elevated heart and breathing rates, muscle reaction, vision acuity, and so forth. The body is no longer concerned with living ten more years, but with surviving ten more minutes. It shuts down nonurgent functions such as muscle repair, digestion, and the immune system,

Yellow highlight | Location: 633 In other words, because it’s not critical to survival, intelligent thinking gets shut down.

Pink highlight | Location: 633 David Rock, founder of the NeuroLeadership Institute, explains that “the threat response impairs analytic thinking, creative insight, and problem solving.”7 This kind of negativity doesn’t just affect our actual performance, it also affects how others perceive us.

Yellow highlight | Location: 639 No matter how brief that negative expression, the person facing you is going to spot it. And all they know is that while you were looking at them and listening to them, a negative expression crossed your face. Naturally they’ll assume that expression was a reaction to them—what they said or did, or what you thought about them. This is how internal negativity affects your body language, and thus your charisma, in addition to your performance.

Yellow highlight | Location: 642 Self-criticism is one of the most common obstacles to great performance in any field.

Yellow highlight | Location: 646 “Eighty percent of my day is spent fighting my inner critic.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 650 enough. In one of the manifestations of self-doubt, known as the impostor syndrome, competent people feel they don’t really know what they’re doing and are just waiting for someone to expose them as a fraud.

Yellow highlight | Location: 654 But already, just knowing the universality of such feelings can help us neutralize their effect and reduce their power.

Yellow highlight | Location: 668 The difficult feelings we experience are a natural by-product of one of our most useful survival mechanisms.

Yellow highlight | Location: 669 Feelings like fear or anxiety are designed to get you to do something. They’re uncomfortable because they’re “designed” to be uncomfortable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 706 Feeling internal discomfort and negativity is a natural part of life. Everyone experiences it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 713 we feel they “shouldn’t” be happening. So not only do we feel bad, we then also feel bad about feeling bad.

Yellow highlight | Location: 735 The brain equates social needs with survival; being hungry and being ostracized activate similar neural responses.1 Somewhere in the back of our minds is the fear of being so disapproved-of that we’d be excluded by those who matter to our survival.

Yellow highlight | Location: 740 that the tendency to feel bad about feeling bad is especially true for good people.

Yellow highlight | Location: 767 whatever I’ve seen may well be the sign of how they’re feeling about themselves, an itchy wool suit, or something else entirely.

Yellow highlight | Location: 784 reality. But sometimes our mind will present us with a seriously distorted view of reality. And the distortion often skews negative because the elements that our danger-focused brain deems important

Yellow highlight | Location: 785 are usually the most negative ones. This tendency is called the negativity bias, and

Yellow highlight | Location: 798 When your brain spins negative scenarios, remind yourself that you may not be getting an accurate perception of reality.

Yellow highlight | Location: 810 failure is seldom fatal, and just realizing that even the worst-case scenario is survivable can bolster your confidence.

Yellow highlight | Location: 830 thoughts. We want to avoid falling into the trap of arguing with them or trying to suppress them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 837 Because trying to suppress a self-critical thought only makes it more central to your thinking, it’s a far better strategy to simply aim to neutralize it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 850 Once the fight-or-flight response is aroused, it’s hard to quiet down.

Yellow highlight | Location: 852 If you aimed to simply suppress the anger, you would pay a high price.

Yellow highlight | Location: 854 But what if you happened to learn that this apparently reckless driver was actually a distraught mother whose baby was choking in the backseat, and she was desperately trying to pull over into the breakdown lane while reaching back to save her baby’s life?

Yellow highlight | Location: 857 Deciding to change your belief about what happened (technically called cognitive reappraisal) effectively decreases the brain’s stress levels.

Yellow highlight | Location: 859 The researchers concluded that deciding to change beliefs was a far more effective and healthier solution than attempting to repress or ignore emotions.4 In most situations, we don’t know for certain what motivates a person’s actions, so we might as well choose the explanation that is most helpful to us and create a version of events that gets us into the specific mental state we need for charisma.

Yellow highlight | Location: 863 first, choosing to rewrite your perception of reality is actually the rational and smart thing to do.

Yellow highlight | Location: 864 It can help you get back into the right mental state to emanate charismatic body language and can improve

Yellow highlight | Location: 875 What if this unfortunate, unpleasant experience is absolutely perfect just as it is—the insomnia, the nausea, the fact that this is happening the very night before a high-profile assignment?

Yellow highlight | Location: 876 In what way can this turn out to be absolutely perfect for me?

Yellow highlight | Location: 890 “I decide to interpret everything favorably toward myself.

Yellow highlight | Location: 890 It’s not just that I’m optimistic, I’m actually conveniently deluded.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 891 Once again, we can thank the brain’s tendency to accept imagination as reality.

Yellow highlight | Location: 894 rather than trying to suppress or ignore your internal difficulties, consider a few alternate versions of reality. Conjure a few different scenarios that would induce

Yellow highlight | Location: 904 Was this pleasant? Definitely not. Effective? Absolutely. Within one month, I was able to

Yellow highlight | Location: 930 adages: “Resentment is like drinking poison and waiting for the other person to die.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 955 By using these two exercises, rewriting reality and getting satisfaction, you can choose your perception of the situation—one that allows you to be both effective and charismatic.

Yellow highlight | Location: 958 destigmatize discomfort, neutralize negativity, and rewrite reality.

Yellow highlight | Location: 989 Being comfortable with discomfort.

Yellow highlight | Location: 996 The answer, surprisingly, is to delve into those very sensations of discomfort. That’s right. Though it sounds counterintuitive, rather than trying to suppress, ignore, or power through them, your goal is to give your full attention to the very sensations you’d instinctively want to push away.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,000 In fact, this technique, called delving into sensations, can help you access charismatic presence even during highly uncomfortable situations.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,029 As far as his charisma was concerned, the energy he was using to try to suppress his impatience was only making things worse.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,035 The ability to handle discomfort is a highly valuable skill. The less discomfort affects you, the fewer the situations that can impair your charisma potential.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,038 “the most effective thing you can do for your career is to get comfortable being uncomfortable.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,040 I’ve often heard professional negotiators tell me that they could accurately predict the outcome of negotiations fairly early on using one simple clue: whoever has less endurance for silence loses.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,057 Remind yourself that you’re not doing anything illegal! The only thing that’s holding you back is social customs. You can

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,060 practice. So if you can bring yourself to talk to strangers whenever you’re waiting around in lines, or on buses or trains, do it. Grab every opportunity, and you’ll improve fast.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,086 Golfer Jack Nicklaus said that he never hit a shot, even during practice, without visualizing it first.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,088 “There is good evidence that imagining oneself performing an activity activates parts of the brain that are used in actually performing the activity,”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,102 If their internal emotions were not what they wanted the outside world to see, sooner or later, something of these underlying thoughts and feelings would show.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,106 Because of its powerful mental and physiological effects, visualization is one of the most effective charisma-boosting tools available.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,108 Just by using the right mental images, your subconscious mind will send a remarkable chain reaction of confidence signals cascading through your body. In fact, you can display nearly any body language just by picking the right visualization.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,123 The next time you do this exercise, aim to create images that are even more detailed. Guided imagery must be precise, vivid, and detailed to be effective, says Harvard-trained visualization specialist Stephen Krauss. When visualization is used with Olympic ski teams, skiers visualize themselves careening through the entire course, feeling their muscles tensing, experiencing each bump and turn in their minds.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,151 Visualization is truly a miracle method, helping you boost confidence, emanate more warmth, replace anxiety with calm serenity, or gain access to whichever emotion you’d like to feel and then broadcast it through your body language.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,175 I’ve even found visualization helpful before writing important e-mails. Just as the right visualization helps you get into the right body language so that the right signals flow effortlessly, you can use visualization to get into specific emotional or mental states so that the right words flow as well.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,182 One of my favorite neuroscience resources, the Wise Brain Bulletin, suggested

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,192 “Every night… I held an imaginary council meeting with this group whom I called my ‘Invisible Counselors.’… I now

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,218 Gratitude is a great antidote to all of these negative feelings because it comes from thinking of things you already have—from material items or experiences to cherished relationships.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,220 Gratitude can be a great charisma conduit, bringing you back to the present and giving you immediate access to feelings of both confidence and warmth.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,222 gratitude helps you live longer, healthier, and even happier.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,230 During a recent lunch meeting at a restaurant, for instance, I focused on little delights: the sun streaming through the window; blue skies; that the waiter got my order right; or the existence, availability, and wonders of ketchup.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,297 When our only aim is to broadcast goodwill, it takes the pressure off. We’re no longer striving, struggling, pushing for things to go in a certain direction.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,298 And since we’re less concerned about how the interaction goes, we can both feel and project more charismatic confidence.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,303 One simple but effective way to start is to try to find three things you like about the person you want to feel goodwill toward.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,308 First, a visualization. This one comes from neuroscientist Dr. Privahini Bradoo,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,309 imagine the person you’re speaking to, and all those around you, as having invisible angel wings.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,316 If you respond better to auditory guides, try a few different phrases. For instance, while looking at someone, think, I like you. And I like you just for you. Or try to remember this guideline: Just love as much as you can from wherever you are.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,319 the options open to me right now, which one would bring the most love into this world?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,332 Your willingness to focus on others’ well-being is all you need to positively change your body language.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,361 “Why would people like me? Even I don’t find myself likable.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,361 As you can imagine, this cold internal message resonated in her head, played across her body language, and diminished how much warmth she could emanate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,366 Self-confidence is our belief in our ability to do or to learn how to do something.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,367 Self-esteem is how much we approve of or value ourselves. It’s often a comparison-based evaluation (whether measured against other people or against our own internal standards for approval).

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,369 Self-compassion is how much warmth we can have for ourselves, especially when we’re going through a difficult experience.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,370 have high self-confidence but low self-esteem and very low self-compassion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,373 may be healthier to focus on self-compassion than on self-esteem.6

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,374 Self-esteem is more of a roller coaster, contingent on how we believe we compare to others. It also tends to correlate with narcissism.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,375 Individuals who score high on self-compassion scales demonstrate greater emotional resilience to daily difficulties and fewer negative reactions to difficult situations, such as receiving unflattering feedback.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,377 Higher self-compassion predicts a greater sense of personal responsibility for the outcome of events: it helps predict levels of accountability. People who score high on self-compassion also have a lower tendency for denial. This makes sense: personal mistakes would generate less self-criticism, so people would be more willing to admit to them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,383 self-compassion is feeling that what happened to you is unfortunate, whereas self-pity is feeling that what happened to you is unfair. In this way, self-pity can lead to resentment or bitterness, and to feeling more isolated and alienated. In contrast, self-compassion often leads to increased feelings of connectedness.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,394 Self-compassion delivers an impressive array of benefits: decreased anxiety, depression, and self-criticism; improved relationships and greater feelings of social connectedness and satisfaction with life; increased ability

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,396 to handle negative events; and even improved immune system functioning.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,399 Kristin Neff, one of compassion’s foremost researchers,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,400 First, realizing that we’re experiencing difficulties. Second, responding with kindness and understanding toward ourselves when we are suffering or feel inadequate, rather than being harshly self-critical. Third, realizing that whatever we’re going through is commonly experienced by all human beings, and remembering that everyone goes through difficult times.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,409 Christopher Germer, author of The Mindful Path to Self-Compassion, is adamant that “self-compassion is not a gift you’re either born with or not.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,411 discovering the ways in which you already care for yourself, and then reminding yourself to do these things when negativity hits.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,422 Metta is the conscious practice of developing kind intentions toward all beings.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,423 Not only did they emit deeper brain waves, they also bounced back from stress scenarios much faster, and they showed particular enhancement in the left frontal lobe of their cortexes, the “happy region” of the brain.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,458 As Germer puts it: “A moment of self-compassion can change your entire day. A string of such moments can change the course of your life.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,460 you can think of self-compassion as standing up to self-harm, the same way you’d stand up to something threatening a loved one.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,467 To nurture my internal warmth I set up a “Metta circle” of photographs in the area where I practice every morning.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,470 One of my clients put together what she calls a “lovable book.” Anytime anyone says something kind, complimentary, or affectionate to her, she jots it down in this book.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,474 So far, we’ve focused mainly on the ways that our mind affects our body—

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,476 Emotions and body language are so linked that adopting a certain posture or facial expression will, in fact, create the corresponding feelings in your mind.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,482 Displaying confident body language will actually make you feel more confident;

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,501 she pauses for a second, looks in the mirror, preens, and then announces, “I feel beeyootiful!” And then, shoulders back, head held high, she swoops out to make her grand entrance.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,503 I was walking up the Gran Via in Madrid, feeling tired, hungry, lonely, unfashionably dressed, and the epitome of an ugly American. The attitude was definitely not working for me, so what to do? I decided that I was a movie star incognito. I stood up straighter, shoulders back, head erect, with the posture that I imagine I would have if I were royalty. Suddenly the dress that had seemed so out of place a moment ago felt like an amazing fashion statement, something that everyone else should copy. I noticed as I walked down the street that heads were turning, all of them. When I asked a man for directions, he said he would be honored if I would allow him to show me the way. It was amazing. From one second to the next, I went from a dowdy, frumpy, ugly stranger to a head-turning movie star. It was memorable. And enlightening.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,514 And if you keep at it, you will get comfortable with it. Eventually, it will become second nature.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,520 In fact, it’s important to understand just how limited our daily reserves of willpower really are.13

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,522 willpower is a bit like a muscle that fatigues depending on how much we use it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,526 He noticed that when he spent time during a meeting or a conversation fighting his internal rising impatience, he’d perform less well for hours afterward.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,529 I explained to Robert that every time he used his willpower, he depleted his willpower reserves.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,530 allocating his willpower resources appropriately.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,536 do not include meetings or interactions that could make you feel bad about yourself.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,537 plan a warm-up that will boost your self-esteem: have coffee with someone who makes you feel good about yourself, or plan an activity (play a sport or a musical instrument) that makes you feel competent or accomplished.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,540 Just like an athlete who is careful to stay centered on the morning of a big race, when you need to be at your most charismatic, be highly vigilant about what’s entering your mind. Even the music you listen to can affect your emotional and mental state.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,543 I curate my playlists considering both tempo and lyrics, and when preparing for a key moment, I’m careful to choose songs that correspond with the mood I’m trying to achieve. I have playlists for self-confidence, warmth, empathy, and patience. I’ve found that it really makes a difference. These playlists are also organized as “pre-speech,” “morning wake-up,” and even “pre–family gatherings” (yes, I’m serious).

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,552 he often plays his planned party-music playlist as he’s getting his apartment ready.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,581 To make visualizations most effective, vividly engage all five senses in your imagination.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,582 You can increase both warmth and confidence by practicing gratitude, goodwill, and compassion for others as well as for yourself.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,584 Just as professional athletes and performers do, plan a gradual warm-up to reach your peak charismatic performance.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,585 plan warmth- and confidence-boosting activities instead.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,586 Your body affects your mind. Flip the visualization technique on its head and practice adopting the right posture and facial expressions to access more of almost any desired internal state.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,591 Throughout this chapter we’ll look at four distinct kinds of charisma: focus, visionary, kindness, and authority.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,628 situations. It’s particularly useful when you need people to open up and share information.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,639 Conveying visionary charisma requires the ability to project complete conviction and confidence in a cause.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,692 world. We evaluate someone’s authority charisma through four indicators: body language, appearance, title, and the reactions of others.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,008 what impacts people isn’t the words or content used. Rather, they remember how it felt to be speaking with you.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,051 Great listeners know to let others interrupt them. When someone interrupts you, let them!

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,052 But even if they were wrong, it’s not worth making them feel wrong; your job instead is to make them feel right.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,053 if you notice the other person repeatedly agitating to speak, keep your sentences short and leave frequent pauses for them to jump in.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,054 People really do love to hear themselves talk. The more you let them speak, the more they will like you.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,058 they pause before they answer.
