Yellow highlight | Location: 2,100 Benjamin Disraeli’s genius was his ability to make whomever he was speaking with feel intelligent and fascinating.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,120 For many people, compliments feel both pleasant and a little awkward, and they don’t quite know how to handle them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,143 “You can make more friends in two months by becoming truly interested in other people than you can in two years by trying to get other people interested in you.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,145 trick is to imagine that the person you’re speaking with is the main star in a movie you’re watching right now.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,147 Charismatic people are masters at using positive associations, whether consciously or subconsciously,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,149 I tell all my clients: Don’t try to impress people. Let them impress you, and they will love you for it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,150 you don’t need to sound smart. You just need to make them feel smart.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,154 A picture is worth a thousand words,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,156 Our brain’s language-processing abilities are much newer and less deeply wired than are our visual-processing abilities.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,157 you speak in words, the brain has to relate the words to concepts, then translate the concepts into images, which is what actually gets understood.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,158 Whenever you can, choose to speak in pictures. You’ll have a much greater impact, and your message will be far more memorable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,162 a dramatic way to illustrate

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,170 When you craft your images and metaphors, try to make them sensory-rich: involve as many of the five senses as possible.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,194 Entertainment: Make your e-mail or meeting enjoyable. Information: Give interesting or informative content that they can use. Good feelings: Find ways to make them feel important or good about themselves.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,197 Professional speakers, when rehearsing a new presentation, will often have their first attempt taped and transcribed, and then go over each sentence, aiming to tighten their speech as much as possible.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,199 In fact, aiming to deliver high value for low effort brings together

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,199 When you speak or write, use few words and lots of pictures, and strive to make your communications useful, enjoyable, and even entertaining.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,212 Studies have consistently shown that audience ratings of a lecture are more strongly influenced by delivery style than by content.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,216 Ratio of speaking to listening Amount of voice fluctuation

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,222 Repeat a sentence several times with as wide a variation in emotions as you can. Try to say it with authority, with anger, with sorrow, with empathetic care and concern, with warmth, and with enthusiasm.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,234 Pause. People who broadcast confidence often pause while speaking. They will pause for a second or two between sentences or even in the middle of a sentence. This conveys the feeling that they’re so confident in their power, they trust that people won’t interrupt.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,238 drops. Lowering the intonation of your voice at the end of a sentence broadcasts power. When you want to sound superconfident, you can even lower your intonation midsentence.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,258 Get graphic: use pictures, metaphors, and sensory-rich language to convey a compelling, charismatic message.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,259 Use as few words as possible, and

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,260 deliver as much value as possible: entertainment, information, or good feelings.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,274 What the speaker was saying was clearly not important to his spellbinding power. How he was saying it was enough.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,275 Words are grasped first by people’s cognitive minds, their logical side, which gets to work on understanding their meaning.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,276 Body language, in contrast, affects us on a visceral, emotional level. It’s this emotional level that you need to access in order to inspire others to follow, care for, or obey you.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,277 “Logic makes people think. Emotion makes them act.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,278 If you speak only to people’s logical mind, you’re missing half the playing field.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,279 It bypasses our logical thinking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,282 other), the nonverbal amplifies the verbal.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,283 When they conflict, we tend to trust the nonverbal over the verbal.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,284 On the other hand, with the right body language you can succeed even with an imperfect message.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,295 As a leader, the emotions conveyed by your body language, even during brief, casual encounters, can have a ripple effect through your team or even your entire company.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,297 This ripple effect is due to the mirror neurons in our brain,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,304 Within organizations, leaders’ emotions always propagate fastest because people are strongly affected by those in a position of power

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,318 This tendency to mimic the body language of others is technically called limbic resonance,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,319 thanks to a certain class of neurons called oscillators, which coordinate people physically by regulating how and when their bodies move together.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,323 Imitating someone’s body language is an easy way to establish trust and rapport.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,324 is the conscious application of something that many charismatic people do instinctively.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,325 consciously mirror someone’s body language, you activate deep instincts of trust and liking. For this reason, it can be a great aid when you need people to open up.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,328 mirroring someone’s body language can get them to pick up your dropped items, buy your products, or give you a better deal.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,330 During your next few conversations, try to mirror the other person’s overall posture: the way they hold their head, how they place their feet, the shifts in their weight. If they move their left hand, move your right hand. Aim also to adapt your voice to theirs in speed, pitch, and intonation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,375 Only when it’s your turn to speak should you start infusing the interaction with warmth, caring, and compassion through your voice, face, and eyes. As you speak, gradually shift into a more relaxed, calm, and, eventually, confident posture. There’s a good chance that she’ll follow.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,377 Mirror-then-lead is a smart strategy when the person you’re interacting with needs reassurance

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,383 Rather than mirroring, try breaking him out of his posture by handing him something: a piece of paper or a pen—whatever works.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,384 And then, as soon as he’s in a new position, distract him by giving him new information or changing the subject while you mirror his posture to reestablish rapport.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,385 Remember, our physiology affects our psychology.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,387 As long as their body is in a certain emotional mode, it will be nearly impossible to get their mind to feel something different.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,425 And by association, their discomfort would likely affect their perception of you.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,432 someone, it can speed up their heart rate and send a hormone called phenylethylamine, or PEA, coursing through their bloodstream. PEA is the same hormone that produces the phenomenon we call love at first sight.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,437 Our eyes are a key part of our nonverbal communication, perhaps the single most important one. Why are eyes called the “windows to the soul”? Because they are the most mobile part of the entire face—and so, the most expressive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,554 people who come across as powerful, confident, or high-status are usually more contained; they don’t feel the urge to give so much reassurance because they’re not as worried about what their counterpart is thinking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,558 The first is excessive or rapid nodding.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,560 The second hindrance is excessive verbal reassurance: making a sound, such as “uh-huh,” or a half-sentence, such as “Oh, I agree.” Done once, and consciously, this is fine; multiple times per sentence is not.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,598 While our words speak to a person’s logical mind, our nonverbal communication speaks to a person’s emotional mind.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,601 When verbal and nonverbal messages contradict, we tend to trust what we see in the other person’s body language more than what we hear them say.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,681 Remember John Kenneth Galbraith’s quote about our strong preference to prove ourselves correct rather than change our minds.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,685 If someone feels like they’ve done you harm, they will seek to rationalize their actions and will convince themselves that what they did was justified.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,692 show the person how this idea or project was, at its very core, in its very source, inspired by what they did in the past—a similar idea, project, or initiative they supported.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,248 in times of crisis, people instinctively turn to individuals who are bold, confident, and decisive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,249 Crisis creates uncertainty, which creates angst, and people will cling to whatever they feel diminishes this angst. This is why faith, vision, and authority have such power in times of crisis.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,264 You Become a Magnet for Praise as Well as Envy

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,286 I told Nancy that the only way her success wouldn’t make him feel envious or resentful was if he could see it as his success, too. I encouraged her to give Kevin this sense of ownership by finding some way he might have participated in her success.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,293 I also reminded Nancy of the Ben Franklin Effect. She could periodically ask Kevin for his thoughts and opinions to show him that she values his opinion, helping him to feel respected again.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,304 Second, expressing something we don’t believe leads to cognitive dissonance, which uses up our focus, diverts our attention, and thus impairs our performance. Insincerity just isn’t worth the toll it takes.

Yellow highlight | Location: 235 All it takes is a bit of insight and fore-thought.

Yellow highlight | Location: 252 To avoid this kind of oversight, we must understand when special moments are needed. We must learn to think in moments, to spot the occasions that are worthy of investment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 254 This “moment-spotting” habit can be unnatural. In organizations, for instance, we are consumed with goals. Time is meaningful only insofar as it clarifies or measures our goals. The goal is the thing.

Yellow highlight | Location: 255 But for an individual human being, moments are the thing. Moments are what we remember and what we cherish. Certainly we might celebrate achieving a goal, such as completing a marathon or landing a significant client—but the achievement is embedded in a moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 261 We’ll explore three situations that deserve punctuation: transitions, milestones, and pits.

Yellow highlight | Location: 342 So “fresh starts” happen not only on New Year’s Day, but also on any other landmark date. If you’re struggling to make a transition, create a defining moment that draws a dividing line between Old You and New You.

Yellow highlight | Location: 705 How do you build peaks? You create a positive moment with elements of elevation, insight, pride, and/or connection.

Yellow highlight | Location: 707 To elevate a moment, do three things: First, boost sensory appeal. Second, raise the stakes. Third, break the script.

Yellow highlight | Location: 741 Why? It’s no one’s job, and it’s a hassle, and there’s always something happening that seems more urgent. This same dynamic is what makes it so hard to create peaks in our personal lives as well.

Yellow highlight | Location: 749 We’re not trying to pop your balloon. Rather, we want to build your determination: It’s going to be way harder than you think to create peaks. But once you’ve done it, you’re going to consider every ounce of effort worth it. You will have created your own defining moments.

Yellow highlight | Location: 790 We may have more time to live than he did, but should that be a reason to put them off?

Yellow highlight | Location: 829 Breaking the script—defying people’s expectations of how an experience will unfold—is the third method.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,000 Novelty even changes our perception of time. In an experiment conducted by Vani Pariyadath and David Eagleman of Baylor College of Medicine, participants were shown a series of images. Most of them were identical, but every now

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,004 This misperception has become known as the “oddball effect.”12

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,011 In other words, surprise stretches time.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,013 Afterward, they are asked to estimate how long the fall took, and their estimates are, on average, too high by 36%. Their fear and focus make time seem to expand. (So here’s one tip to live a “longer” life:

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,024 By breaking the script, we can lay down a richer set of memories. As the authors of the book Surprise put it, “We feel most comfortable when things are certain, but we feel most alive when they’re not.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,044 • Novelty actually seems to slow down time. That’s why we feel like time goes faster as we age.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,197 When you have a sudden realization, one that you didn’t see coming, and one that you know viscerally is right, you’ve tripped over the truth.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,224 CLTS facilitators see the problem vividly, but they don’t share their concerns directly. They let the villagers see for themselves. The “aha!” moment should always happen in the minds of the audience.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,226 This three-part recipe—a (1) clear insight (2) compressed in time and (3) discovered by the audience itself—provides a blueprint for us when we want people to confront uncomfortable truths.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,230 To trip is to catch one’s foot on something and stumble. To trip over the truth is to catch one’s brain on something and struggle. What exactly is the “something

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,234 Your focus, in other words, would be on the virtues of the solution. But in the stories we’ve seen so far in this chapter, you’ll notice that no one is talking about solutions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,237 What they did, instead, was dramatize the problems:

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,239 You can’t appreciate the solution until you appreciate the problem. So when we talk about “tripping over the truth,” we mean the truth about a problem or harm. That’s what sparks sudden insight.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,246 Over the course of the week at Palmer’s CDI, the professors learn the science of teaching: how to motivate students, how to reach different types of learners, and how to ensure that students retain the most important

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,249 “backward-integrated design.” First, you identify your goals. Second, you figure out how you’d assess whether students had hit those goals. Third, you design activities that would prepare students to excel at those assessments.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,259 Now put yourself in Palmer’s shoes. He knows professors are approaching curriculum design the wrong way, and he has a solution for them (backward-integrated design). If he pitched the virtues of the solution, that would make him, in essence, a salesman for backward-integrated design.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,261 But how do audiences respond to sales pitches? With skepticism. We quibble and challenge and question.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,262 If Palmer wants to persuade the professors, he needs them to trip over the truth. And that starts with a focus on the problem, not the solution.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,280 “You look at your syllabus, and you go, ‘Zero.’” Most professors discover exactly the same

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,282 quickly realized that the syllabus was useless to me—it wasn’t covering any of my objectives.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,284 striking. (To see an example of a complete syllabus before and after the CDI, visit http://www.heathbrothers.com/CDIsyllabi

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,286 something inspiring. These are its opening paragraphs: Why do bridges and buildings stay up? Why do bridges and buildings fall down? How should buildings be built in an earthquake or a hurricane zone? What are some of the forces that bring them down? What is a force? Physics can describe everything that we see around us, when we know how

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,289 to look! An airplane flying is a study in pressure and drag; a collision turns into a problem in momentum; a rainbow becomes an awesome show of refraction and dispersion; an earthquake illustrates shear forces and flexibility; bridge construction is about heat and expansion; a concert hall is the interplay of reflection and interference.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,355 Research suggests that reflecting or ruminating on our thoughts and feelings is an ineffective way to achieve true understanding.4 Studying our own behavior is more fruitful.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,359 Action leads to insight more often than insight leads to action.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,363 Self-understanding comes slowly. One of the few ways to accelerate it—to experience more crystallizing moments—is to stretch for insight.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,390 More than thirty years later, Michael Dinneen looks back on that night as one of the defining moments of his life. It was the first time he had lost a patient.6 But what sticks with him nearly as much is what the night taught him about himself: I can endure.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,396 Others, like Dinneen, discover that they can survive the experiences, and that the potential negative peaks are outweighed by the positive.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,397 Dinneen never would have learned about his ability to endure had he not been pushed and supported by Ridenour. “I was expected to get back in the game,” said Dinneen. “He knew I had it in me to make it through that night when I didn’t know that myself.” Ridenour’s wise actions in the middle of the night transformed a moment of trauma into a moment of growth.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,403 Mentors focus on improvement: Can you push a little bit further? Can you shoulder a little more responsibility? They introduce a productive level of stress.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,419 good starting place is a two-part formula cited in a paper by the psychologist David Scott Yeager and eight colleagues: high standards + assurance.8 Yeager described a study in a suburban junior high school in which 44 seventh-grade students were assigned to write an essay about a personal hero.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,422 Their teachers then marked up the essays, providing written feedback.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,434 High standards + assurance is a powerful formula, but ultimately it’s just a statement of expectations. What great mentors do is add two more elements: direction and support.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,435 have high expectations for you and I know you can meet them. So try this new challenge and if you fail, I’ll help you recover.

Note:Mentorship definition

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,499 What separated Blakely from other women with the same idea was her persistence.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,511 don’t fear failure anymore. It’s no longer an obstacle to me.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,516 her father would ask them a question every week at the dinner table: “What did you guys fail at this week?”

Note:Good qauedstgion

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,517 “If we had nothing to tell him, he’d be disappointed,” Blakely said. “The logic seems counterintuitive, but it worked beautifully. He knew that many people become paralyzed by the fear of failure. They’re constantly afraid of what others will think if they don’t do a great job and, as a result, take no risks. My father wanted us to try everything and feel free to push the envelope. His attitude taught me to define failure as not trying something I want to do instead of not achieving the right outcome.” His question, “What did you guys fail at this week?” was a push to stretch. It was an attempt to normalize failure, to make it part of a casual dinner conversation. Because when you seek out situations where you might fail, failure loses some of its menace. You’ve been inoculated against it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,531 The promise of stretching is not success, it’s learning. It’s self-insight. It’s the promise of gleaning the answers to some of the most important and vexing questions of our lives: What do we want? What can we do? Who can we be? What can we endure?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,539 Moments of insight deliver realizations and transformations.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,556 The promise of stretching is not success, it’s learning.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,567 Great experiences are mostly forgettable and occasionally remarkable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,699 Keith Risinger, who works in leadership development at Eli Lilly, has made recognition a hallmark of his management style.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,721 About a month later, Risinger kicked off a sales meeting with the story of Hughes’s progress with Dr. Singh, highlighting the value of asking more questions and listening to the answers. To commemorate the occasion he awarded Hughes a symbol of his quality listening: a pair of Bose headphones.

Note:Listening / importance

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,730 Maybe your managerial style is different;

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,733 The style is not important. What’s important is authenticity: being personal not programmatic. And frequency: closer to weekly than yearly. And of course what’s most important is the message: “I saw what you did and I appreciate it.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,839 The common goal to “get in shape” is ambiguous and un-motivating. Pursuing it puts you on a path with no clear destination and no intermediate moments to celebrate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,843 Three months ago, I couldn’t run 100 yards without heaving, and now I’m the kind of person who can finish a race!

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,848 He worried about how much of his life he was losing to the escapist pleasures of gaming.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,888 By using Kamb’s level-up strategy, we multiply the number of motivating milestones we encounter en route to a goal. That’s a forward-looking strategy:

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,890 We’re anticipating moments of pride ahead. But the opposite is also possible: to surface those milestones you’ve already met but might not have noticed.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,921 A numerical goal plus supporting plans. Notice what that combination leaves us with: A destination that is not inherently motivating and that lacks meaningful milestones along the way. As a result, achieving the “20 by 2020” goal

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,925 We should be careful that we don’t let this corporate style of goal-setting infiltrate our personal lives, where we’re in full control. “I’m going to lose 10 pounds in 2 months,” for instance, is a classic corporate goal: arbitrary, numerical, and lacking intermediate milestones.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,928 By now, you know what to do: Restore the milestones. Level up: Go one week straight without using the elevator. Pick out 2 microbrews to enjoy on Saturday after a full week without booze. If I jog continuously for three songs on my playlist, that entitles me to download three new ones. And so on.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,944 The same logic applies to milestones involving less tangible goals, such as building leadership

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,944 skills. In most organizations, the only clear “levels” en route to leadership positions are promotions. But what if it takes five years for an employee to earn a promotion, or what if she is not interested in or suited for a promotion? How do you create the intermediate milestones that could provide moments of pride?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,958 Hitting a milestone sparks pride. It should also spark a celebration—a moment of elevation. (Don’t forget that milestones, along with pits and transitions, are three natural defining moments that deserve extra attention.) Milestones deserve peaks.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,001 “From my experience, the most common trait you will consistently observe in accomplished people is an obsession with completion.6 Once a project falls into their horizon, they crave almost compulsively, to finish it.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,004 What milestones do is compel us to make that push, because (a) they’re within our grasp, and (b) we’ve chosen them precisely because they’re worth reaching for. Milestones define moments that are conquerable and worth conquering. A Boy Scout spends one more

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,053 The difficulty with nonviolent people and efforts is that they don’t recognize the necessity of fierce discipline and training.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,065 “Courage is resistance to fear, mastery of fear—not absence of fear.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,074 Rather, they are describing moments of courage.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,079 The military understands this concept well. As the psychologist S. J. Rachman wrote in a report on military training, “What might be called ‘training for courage’ plays an important part in preparing people to undertake dangerous jobs such as fire-fighting or parachuting.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,091 That element—“gradual and graduated practice”—is also the hallmark of exposure therapy, one of the most effective techniques for reducing phobias (irrational fears).

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,113 Managing fear—the goal of exposure therapy—is a critical part of courage. The civil rights demonstrator and the bomb-disposal operator must be able to control their fears to be successful.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,114 But courage isn’t just suppressed fear. It’s also the knowledge of how to act in the moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,117 His workshops weren’t just about toughening up emotionally. They were about mental rehearsals.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,117 Participants had to anticipate how they would react to certain situations. In a sense, they were preloading a response so that, in the moment, they could act quickly without deliberation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,119 The psychologist Peter Gollwitzer has studied the way this preloading affects our behavior. His research shows that when people make advance mental commitments—if X happens, then I will do Y—they are substantially more likely to act in support of their goals than people who lack those mental plans.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,123 Gollwitzer calls these plans “implementation intentions,”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,124 and often the trigger for the plan is as simple as a time and place: When I leave work today, I’m going to drive straight to the gym. The success rate is striking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,125 Setting implementation intentions more than doubled the number of students who turned in a certain assignment on time; doubled the number of women who performed breast self-exams in a certain month; and cut by half the recovery time required by patients who had received hip or knee replacement (among many other examples). There is power in preloading a response.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,137 She became convinced that ethics education should focus not on WHAT is the right thing to do? but rather on HOW can I get the right thing done?

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,147 “Just as an athlete practices his or her moves to commit them to muscle memory, the point here is to make voicing our values the default position,” said Gentile.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,220 Moments of pride commemorate people’s achievements. We feel our chest puff out and our chin lift.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,223 We dramatically underinvest in recognition.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,226 Risinger at Eli Lilly used “tailored rewards” (e.g., Bose headphones) to show his team: I saw what you did and I appreciate it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,281 Mark’s meeting is a great example of showing vulnerability, which is a prerequisite to intimacy.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,329 They consulted with experts: the Studer Group and coauthors James Gilmore and Joseph Pine (who wrote the seminal book The Experience Economy).

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,335 The best place for employees to work The best place for physicians to practice The best place for patients to receive care Ultimately, the best health care system in the universe

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,380 But for groups, defining moments arise when we create shared meaning—highlighting the mission that binds us together and supersedes our differences. We are made to feel united.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,392 Provine found that laughter was 30 times more common in social settings than private ones.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,393 a social reaction. “Laughter is more about relationships than humor,” Provine concluded.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,394 We laugh to tie the group together. Our laughter says, I’m with you. I’m part of your group.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,395 In groups, we are constantly assessing the reactions and feelings of the group. Our words and

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,395 glances are a kind of social sonar. Are you still there? Are you hearing what I’m hearing? Are your reactions like mine? Laughing in groups is another way of sending positive signals back and forth. We are synchronizing our reactions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,409 This is important. This is real. We’re in this together. And what we’re doing matters.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,425 The researchers concluded that perceived pain increases “prosociality,” or voluntary behavior to benefit others.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,449 In his forthcoming book, Great at Work: How Top Performers Work Less and Achieve More, University of California, Berkeley professor Morten Hansen

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,454 Purpose is defined as the sense that you are contributing to others, that your work has broader meaning. Passion is the feeling of excitement or enthusiasm you have about your work.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,483 The outcome is clear. Purpose trumps passion. Graduation speakers take note: The best advice is not “Pursue your passion!” It’s “Pursue your purpose!”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,485 Passion is individualistic. It can energize us but also isolate us, because my passion isn’t yours. By contrast, purpose is something people can share. It can knit groups together.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,486 Amy Wrzesniewski, who studies how people make meaning of their work,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,488 She believes purpose isn’t discovered, it’s cultivated.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,502 “connecting to meaning”—finding ways to remind people of their purpose. Similar

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,503 When radiologists were shown photos of the patients whose X-rays they were scanning, they increased both the raw number and the accuracy of their scans.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,505 Connecting to meaning matters.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,506 Not all of us save lives or serve patients. Sometimes purpose can be less tangible. What’s the guiding

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,506 “purpose” for the marketing collateral team or the server administrators or the benefits group in HR?

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,514 The janitor is making a contribution to the health and happiness of patients.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,521 A sense of purpose seems to spark “above and beyond” behaviors. At Sharp, as we saw, once employees had been reconnected with the meaning of their work, they began to push beyond their job descriptions to create extraordinary moments for patients.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,567 Looking for solutions, Fisherow met with a representative from the Flamboyan Foundation, a family foundation focused on improving schools.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,611 The true jaw-dropping moment,

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,621 The astonishing moments continued, one after another. Attendance at parent-teacher conferences spiked from 12% of parents the previous year to 73% in 2011-12.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,640 others? What, in short, is the “circuitry” of a successful relationship?

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,642 Our relationships are stronger when we perceive that our partners are responsive to us.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,644 Responsiveness encompasses three things: Understanding: My partner knows how I see myself and what is important to me. Validation: My partner respects who I am and what I want. Caring: My partner takes active and supportive steps in helping me meet my needs.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,672 1. Do I know what is expected of me at work? 2. Do I have the materials and equipment I need to do my work right? 3. Do I have the opportunity to do what I do best every day? 4. In the last seven days, have I received recognition or praise for good work? (Validation.) 5. Does my supervisor, or someone at work, seem to care about me as a person? (Caring.) 6. Is there someone at work who encourages my development? (Understanding. Caring.)

Note:MAnagerial goals

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,721 Their relationship was utterly transformed because of a simple question: “What matters to you?”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,725 As we saw with the Stanton home visits, with the right kind of moment, relationships can change in an instant.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,728 Responsiveness matters in the complex, emotional relationships between caregivers and patients, but it also plays a role in more mundane, day-to-day interactions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,735 Why does the Internet have a photographic memory for ad clicks and amnesia about what we actually care about?

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,736 What links these annoyances, of course, is the lack of understanding, validation, and caring.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,737 You are not special. You’re a number. Analysts at the Corporate Executive Board (CEB) studied customer service calls and the ratings that customers provided afterward. To the researchers’ surprise, only half of the customers’ ratings were attributable to the particular call they had just experienced. The other half reflected the way they had been treated previously.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,741 The CEB team called the customers’ memory of previous treatment their “baggage.” Most call center reps had the instinct to avoid the customer’s baggage.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,754 Baggage handling is responsive: It demonstrates understanding and validation of a customer’s frustrating past experience.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,841 “Connecting to meaning” reconnects people with the purpose of their efforts. That’s motivating and encourages “above and beyond” work.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,842 Hansen’s research: When it comes to performance, strong purpose trumps strong passion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,843 In individual relationships, we believe that relationships grow closer with time. But that’s not the whole story. Sometimes long relationships reach plateaus. And with the right moment, relationships can deepen quickly.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,846 According to the psychologist Harry Reis, what deepens individual relationships is “responsiveness”: mutual understanding, validation, and caring.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,903 You can just as easily conduct a meeting that has drama, meaning, and connection. You cannot bring two teams together by simply talking about unity. They must experience unity. That’s what makes it a defining moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,916 MIT went even further, sending its acceptance packet in a tube stuffed with a poster,1 refrigerator magnet, and best of all, confetti! (Breaking the script)

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,930 A bit of attention and energy can transform an ordinary moment into an extraordinary one.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,945 Our good intentions to create these moments are often frustrated by urgent-seeming problems and pressures.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,948 In the short term, we prioritize fixing problems over making moments, and that choice usually feels like a smart trade-off. But over time, it backfires.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,951 wish I’d had the courage to live a life true to myself, not the life others expected of me. (“

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,978 If that’s what success in this role sounds like, I don’t want it. She’s energized by what she’s talking about. But it bores me to death.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,981 she visited a career counselor, hoping to discover a job that better suited her interests. That’s when her life shifted a second time.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,982 The counselor listened to her aspirations and offered some tools—personality tests and skills assessments—to clarify the kind of work she wanted to do. Armed with this data, the counselor suggested a few careers that might fit her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,984 She remembers looking at the counselor, thinking, I want to do what you do.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,016 epiphanies. “Eureka!” moments. But what dawned on us, as we read more of them, is that these were not stories about sudden realizations. These were stories about action.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,019 Often, what looks like a moment of serendipity is actually a moment of intentionality.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,020 What Kasten, Mistry, and the others experienced as the shock of an insight was actually, we came to believe, the whiplash caused by realizing they could ACT and then willfully jolting their lives in a new direction. They were not receiving a moment, they were seizing it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,031 You ask your children at the dinner table, “What have you failed at this week?” (Stretch for insight)

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,032 meet after work for a cupcake. (Break the script)

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,032 The most precious moments are often the ones that cost the least.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,053 Darcy wrote in a blog post years later about the bucket of snow: “It is those moments of compassion and spontaneity that we are grateful for,

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,057 And that’s the charge for all of us: to defy the forgettable flatness of everyday work and life by creating a few precious moments.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,060 What if every patient was asked, “What matters to you?”

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,061 What if we didn’t just remember the defining moments of our lives but made them? We can be the designers of moments that deliver elevation and insight and pride and connection. These extraordinary minutes and hours and days—they are what make life meaningful. And they are ours to create.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,091 Look for small peaks. People who have experienced trauma often report that they have a greater capacity to enjoy small things in life that previously they might have ignored: a beautiful garden, a strong cup of coffee, a morning with a child.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,102 Celebrate and honor relationships. One parent, describing the death of her son, said, “When he died people just came out of the woodwork” to help. She experienced renewed appreciation for her friends. She came to cherish her husband more.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,107 the idea of “responsiveness,” which says that relationships grow when partners understand, validate, and care for each other.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,114 Acknowledge your strength. A bereaved parent said, “I can handle things better. Things that used to be big deals just aren’t big deals anymore.” People use the trauma as a test of their capacity to stretch, endure hardship, and persevere. Many said, “If I can handle this then I can handle just about anything.” In Chapter 6, we share the story of a young psychiatrist, Michael Dinneen,

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,120 Identify new possibilities. Individuals who are enduring trauma sometimes find themselves identifying new possibilities for their lives: new work, new passions, new paths.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,124 But some people find that when one door closes, another opens.

Yellow highlight | Location: 3,124 Look for spiritual insight.

Yellow highlight | Location: 74 To be principled means to consistently operate with principles that can be clearly explained.

Yellow highlight | Location: 109 I learned my principles over a lifetime of making a lot of mistakes and spending a lot of time reflecting on them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 124 My painful mistakes shifted me from having a perspective of “I know I’m right” to having one of “How do I know I’m right?”

Yellow highlight | Location: 131 Experience taught me how invaluable it is to reflect on and write down my decision-making criteria whenever I made a decision, so I got in the habit of doing that.

Yellow highlight | Location: 135 • Systemize

Note:how to think beyond your timewhat you wished your father have done differently

Yellow highlight | Page: 3 We are all born with different thinking abilities but we aren’t born with decision-making skills. We learn them from our encounters with reality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 “If a man does not keep pace with his companions, perhaps it is because he hears a different drummer. Let him step to the music which he hears, however measured or far away.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 11 And most people tend to be biased by their recent experiences.

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 “You better make sense of what happened to other people in other times and other places because if you don’t you won’t know if these things can happen to you and, if they do, you won’t know how to deal with them.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 36 Seek out the smartest people who disagreed with me so I could try to understand their reasoning. 2. Know when not to have an opinion. 3. Develop, test, and systemize timeless and universal principles. 4. Balance risks in ways that keep the big upside while reducing the downside.

Yellow highlight | Page: 37 think. I came to see that people’s greatest weaknesses are the flip sides of their greatest strengths.

Yellow highlight | Page: 37 Successful people change in ways that allow them to continue to take advantage of their strengths while compensating for their weaknesses and unsuccessful people don’t.

Yellow highlight | Page: 37 beneficial change begins when you can acknowledge and even embrace your weaknesses.

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 than argue about our conclusions, my partners and

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 I have come to realize that bad times coupled with good reflections provide some of the best lessons,

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 didn’t value experience as much as character, creativity, and common sense, which I suppose was related to my having started Bridgewater two years out of school myself, and my belief that having an ability to figure things out is more important than having specific knowledge of how to do something.

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 also learned how people can control how their brains work to produce dramatically better effects. These insights helped me to deal with people more effectively,

Yellow highlight | Page: 82 The 2008 debt crisis was another one of those like the one in 1982, which were both like many more before them and many more that will come. I enjoyed reflecting back on my painful mistakes and

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 a result, I tended to hire people who were the same way—who would dive right into challenges, figure out what to do about them, and then do it. I figured that if they had great character, common sense, and creativity, and were driven to achieve our shared mission, they would discover what it took to be successful if I gave them the freedom to figure out how to make the right decisions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 But starting in the 1990s, I began to recognize the emotional barriers most people had to looking at their problems and weaknesses forthrightly. Rather than embracing ambiguous situations and difficult challenges, they tended to get uncomfortable when facing them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 But while almost all of us quickly agreed on the principles intellectually, many still struggled to convert what they had agreed to intellectually into effective action.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 This was because their habits and emotional barriers remained stronger than their reasoning.

Yellow highlight | Page: 91 It seems to me that life consists of three phases. In the first, we are dependent on others and we learn. In the second, others depend on us and we work. And in the third and last, when others no longer depend on us and we no longer have to work, we are free to savor life. I was beginning my transition from my second to my third phase. Both intellectually and emotionally, I was no longer as excited about being successful as I was excited about having the people I cared about be successful without me.

Yellow highlight | Page: 95 because their need to achieve what they envision is stronger than the pain they experience as they struggle to achieve it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 When I asked him about his background in rocketry, he told me he didn’t have one. “I just started reading books,” he said. That’s how shapers think and act.

Yellow highlight | Page: 108 I gave Wang a copy of Joseph Campbell’s great book The Hero with a Thousand Faces, because he is a classic hero and I thought it might help him. I also gave him The Lessons of History, a 104-page distillation of the major forces through history by Will and Ariel Durant, and River Out of Eden by the insightful Richard Dawkins, which explains how evolution works. He gave me Georgi Plekhanov’s classic On the Role of the Individual in History. All these books showed how the same things happened over and over again throughout history.

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 evolution of the company through their eyes—how some things had changed over the years while others had stayed the same, most importantly, our

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 I came to understand that my encounters were tests of my character and creativity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 What I have seen is that the happiest people discover their own nature and match their life to it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 I realized that passing on knowledge is like passing on DNA—it is more important than the individual, because it lives way beyond the individual’s life. This is my attempt to help you succeed by passing along to you what I learned about how to struggle well—or, at the very least, to help you get the most out of each unit of effort you put in.

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 My point is that people who create great things aren’t idle dreamers: They are totally grounded in reality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 don’t. Some people want to change the world and others want to operate in simple harmony with it and savor life.

Yellow highlight | Page: 135 Over time I learned that getting more out of life wasn’t just a matter of working harder at it. It was much more a matter of working effectively, because working effectively could increase my capacity by hundreds of times. I don’t care what you want or how hard you want to work for it. That’s for you to decide. I’m just trying to pass along to you what has helped me get the most out of each hour of time and each unit of effort.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 This takes practice and changing one’s habits. I have found that it typically takes about eighteen months, which is how long it takes to change most habits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 now realize that nature optimizes for the whole, not for the individual, but most people judge good and bad based only on how it affects them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 But we do know that what we call mankind was simply the result of DNA evolving into a new form about two hundred thousand years ago,

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 years ago, and we know that mankind will certainly

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 you can develop a reflexive reaction to psychic pain that causes you to reflect on it rather than avoid

Yellow highlight | Page: 153 Most people have a tough time reflecting when they are in pain and they pay attention to other things when the

Yellow highlight | Page: 153 pain passes, so they miss out on the reflections that provide the lessons. If you can reflect well while you’re in pain (which is probably too much to ask), great. But if you can remember to reflect after it passes, that’s valuable too. (I created a Pain Button app to help people do this, which I describe in the appendix.)

Yellow highlight | Page: 153 As you climb above the blizzard of things that surrounds you, you will realize that they seem bigger than they really are when you are seeing them up close; that most things in life are just “another one of those.” The higher you ascend, the more effective you become at working with reality to shape outcomes toward your goals. What once seemed impossibly complex becomes simple.

Yellow highlight | Page: 154 that you will become hooked on: • Identifying, accepting, and learning how to deal with your weaknesses, • Preferring that the people around you be honest with you rather than keep their negative thoughts about you to themselves, and • Being yourself rather than having to pretend to be strong where you are weak.

Yellow highlight | Page: 154 Our upbringings and our experiences in the world have conditioned us to be embarrassed by our weaknesses and hide them.

Pink highlight | Page: 155 Weigh second- and third-order consequences. By recognizing the higher-level

Pink highlight | Page: 156 For example, the first-order consequences of exercise (pain and time spent) are commonly considered undesirable, while the second-order consequences (better health and more attractive appearance) are desirable.

Pink highlight | Page: 156 By contrast, people who choose what they really want, and avoid the temptations and get over the pains that drive them away from what they

Pink highlight | Page: 156 really want, are much more likely to have successful lives.

Pink highlight | Page: 158 that it is much more important that you are a good designer/manager of your life than a good worker in it, you will be on the right path.

Blue highlight | Page: 160 Watching people struggle and having others watch you struggle can elicit all kinds of ego-driven emotions such as sympathy, pity, embarrassment, anger, or defensiveness. You need to get over all that and stop seeing struggling as something negative. Most of life’s greatest opportunities come out of moments of struggle; it’s up to you to make the most of these tests of creativity and character.

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 change more slowly than your designs, which will

Yellow highlight | Page: 185 To be effective you must not let your need to be right be more important than your need to find out what’s true.

Yellow highlight | Page: 185 In addition to your ego barrier, you (and everyone else) also have blind spots—areas where your way of thinking prevents you from seeing things accurately.

Yellow highlight | Page: 186 If you’re like most people, you have no clue how other people see things and aren’t good at seeking to understand what they are thinking, because you’re too preoccupied with telling them what you yourself think is correct.

Yellow highlight | Page: 186 In other words, you are closed-minded; you presume too much. This closed-mindedness is terribly costly; it causes you to miss out on all sorts of wonderful possibilities and dangerous threats that other people might be showing you—and it blocks criticism that could be constructive and even lifesaving.

Yellow highlight | Page: 187 Differences in thinking can be symbiotic and complementary instead of disruptive. For example, the lateral approach to thinking common among creative people can lead them to be unreliable, while more linear thinkers are often more dependable; some people are more emotional while others are more logical, and so on. None of these individuals would be able to succeed at any kind of complex project without the help of others who have complementary strengths.

Yellow highlight | Page: 187 In my opinion, these two barriers—ego and blind spots—are the fatal flaws that keep intelligent, hardworking people from living up to their potential.

Yellow highlight | Page: 208 Understand the power that comes from knowing how you and others are wired.

Yellow highlight | Page: 209 Kay Redfield Jamison (who has written frankly about her own experiences with the disease in her book An Unquiet Mind).

Yellow highlight | Page: 209 Once I understood that it’s all physiological, many things became clearer to me. While I used to get angry and frustrated at people because of the choices they made, I came to realize that they weren’t intentionally acting in a way that seemed counterproductive; they were just living out things as they saw them, based on how their brains worked.

Yellow highlight | Page: 210 The only sensible way of behaving with each other was to look down upon ourselves with mutual understanding so we could make objective sense of things. Not only did this make our disagreements less frustrating, it also allowed us to maximize our effectiveness.

Yellow highlight | Page: 210 All these pieces come together to determine what each person is like, and if you know what a person is like, you’ll have a pretty good idea of what you can expect from them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 210 Most attributes are a double-edged sword that bring potential benefits and potential harm. The more extreme the attribute, the more extreme the potential good or bad outcomes it is likely to produce.

Yellow highlight | Page: 210 For example, a highly creative, goal-oriented person good at imagining new ideas might undervalue the minutiae of daily life, which is also important; he might be so driven in his pursuit of long-term goals that he might have disdain for people who focus on the details of daily life. Similarly, a task-oriented person who is great with details might undervalue creativity—and worse still, may squelch it in the interests of efficiency.

Note:Personal strengths

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 Kegan wrote in his book An Everyone Culture, “from the individual experience of probing in every one-on-one meeting, to the technologically integrated processes for discussing . . . issues and

Yellow highlight | Page: 212 David Eagleman describes it in his wonderful book Incognito:

Yellow highlight | Page: 213 eyesight, and instinctual magnetic navigation; most animals for smell; and several for appearing to

Yellow highlight | Page: 214 comes the cerebrum, which includes the basal ganglia (which controls habit) and other parts of the limbic system (which controls emotional responses and

Yellow highlight | Page: 215 human brain comes pre-programmed with the need for and enjoyment of social cooperation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 216 Wilson explains that man is perpetually suspended between the two extreme forces that created us: “Individual selection [which] prompted sin and group selection [which] promoted virtue.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 217 contemporary neuroscience view that all of our thinking and feeling is due to physiology (in other words, the chemicals, electricity, and biology in our brains working like a machine).

Yellow highlight | Page: 217 that prayer and meditation seemed to have similar effects on the brain in producing feelings of spirituality (the rising above oneself to feel a greater connection to the whole) but that each religion adds its own different superstitions on top of that common feeling of spirituality.

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 When thoughts and instructions come to me from my subconscious, rather than acting on them immediately, I have gotten into the habit of examining them with my conscious, logical mind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 220 The biggest difference between people who guide their own personal evolution and achieve their goals and those who don’t is that those who make progress reflect on what causes their amygdala hijackings.

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 If you do just about anything frequently enough over time, you will form a habit that will control you. Good habits are those that get you to do what your “upper-level you” wants, and bad habits are those that are controlled by your “lower-level you” and stand in the way of your getting what your “upper-level you” wants. You can create a better set of habits if you understand how this part of your brain works.

Yellow highlight | Page: 221 Research suggests that if you stick with a behavior for approximately eighteen months, you will build a strong tendency to stick to it nearly forever.

Yellow highlight | Page: 222 if you really want to change, the best thing you can do is choose which habits to acquire and which to get rid of and then go about doing that.

Yellow highlight | Page: 223 I’ve learned that it is more effective to train that subconscious, emotional you the same way you would teach a child to behave the way you would like him or her to behave—with loving kindness and persistence so that the right habits are acquired.

Yellow highlight | Page: 223 The left hemisphere reasons sequentially, analyzes details, and excels at linear analysis. “Left-brained” or “linear” thinkers who are analytically strong are often called “bright.” 2. The right hemisphere thinks across categories, recognizes themes, and synthesizes the big picture. “Right-brained” or “lateral” thinkers with more street smarts are often called “smart.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 223 side. Our experience has been that left-brained folks tend to see right-brained folks as “spacey” or “abstract,” while right-brained thinkers tend to find left-brained thinkers “literal” or “narrow.” I have seen wonderful results occur when people know where their own and others’ inclinations lie, realize that both ways of thinking are invaluable, and assign responsibilities accordingly.

Yellow highlight | Page: 224 We can all learn new facts and skills, but can we also learn to change how we are inclined to think? The answer is a qualified yes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 226 That is because the intuitive thinker’s attention is focused on the context first and the details second.

Yellow highlight | Page: 227 Planning vs. perceiving. Some people like to live in a planned, orderly way and others prefer flexibility and spontaneity.35 Planners (or “Judgers” in Myers-Briggs terms) like to focus on a plan and stick with it, while perceivers are prone to focus on what’s happening around them and adapt to it. Perceivers work from the outside in; they see things happening and work backward to understand the cause and how to respond; they also see many possibilities that they compare and choose from—often so many that they are confused by them. In contrast, planners work from the inside out, first figuring out what they want to achieve and then how things should unfold. Planners and perceivers have trouble appreciating each other. Perceivers see new things and change direction often. This is discomforting to planners, who weigh precedent much more heavily in their decision making, and assume if it was done in a certain way before, it should be done in the same way again. Similarly, planners can discomfort perceivers by being seemingly rigid and slow to adapt.

Yellow highlight | Page: 228 Creators generate new ideas and original concepts. They prefer unstructured and abstract activities and thrive on innovation and unconventional practices.

Yellow highlight | Page: 229 Workplace Personality Inventory. Another assessment we use is the Workplace Personality Inventory, a test based on data from the U.S. Department of Labor. It anticipates behavior and predicts job fit and satisfaction, singling out certain key characteristics/qualities, including persistence, independence, stress tolerance, and analytical thinking.

Yellow highlight | Page: 229 This test helps us understand what people value and how they will make trade-offs between their values.

Yellow highlight | Page: 229 Likewise, someone who is bad at Rule Following may be more likely to think independently.

Yellow highlight | Page: 230 Practical Thinker + Determined. I’ve found that shapers tend to share attributes such as intense curiosity and a compulsive need to make sense of things, independent thinking that verges on rebelliousness, a need to dream big and unconventionally, a practicality and determination to push through all obstacles to achieve their goals, and a knowledge of their own and others’ weaknesses and strengths so they can orchestrate teams to achieve them. Perhaps even more importantly, they can hold conflicting thoughts simultaneously and look at them from different angles. They typically love to knock things around with other really smart people and can easily navigate back and forth between the big picture and the granular details, counting both as equally important.

Yellow highlight | Page: 231 Nature made everything and everyone for a purpose. The courage that’s needed the most isn’t the kind that drives you to prevail over others, but the kind that allows you to be true to your truest self, no matter what other people want you to be.

Yellow highlight | Page: 233 project manager who was less engaged with the concepts and much more focused on the details of specific tasks and deadlines.

Yellow highlight | Page: 233 Cards, we could quickly see them lighting up in some of the areas around being planful, concrete, and driving things to completion, which were areas of weakness for Bob.

Yellow highlight | Page: 244 is the level at which you need to understand

Yellow highlight | Page: 250 Remember that multiple levels exist for all subjects. 2. Be aware on what level you’re examining a given subject. 3. Consciously navigate levels rather than see subjects as undifferentiated piles of facts that can be browsed randomly. 4. Diagram the flow of your thought processes using the outline template shown on the previous page.

Yellow highlight | Page: 251 Make your decisions as expected value calculations. Think of every decision as a bet with a probability and a reward for being right and a probability and a penalty for being wrong.

Yellow highlight | Page: 252 Sometimes it’s smart to take a chance even when the odds are overwhelmingly against you if the cost of being wrong is negligible relative to the reward that comes with the slim chance of being right. As the saying goes, “It never hurts to ask.”

Blue highlight | Page: 254 Separate your “must-dos” from your “like-to-dos” and don’t mistakenly slip any “like-to-dos” onto the first list.

Yellow highlight | Page: 254 People who can accurately sort probabilities

Blue highlight | Page: 254 sort probabilities from possibilities are generally strong at “practical thinking”; they’re the opposite of the “philosopher” types who tend to get lost in clouds of possibilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 254 from possibilities are generally strong at “practical thinking”; they’re the opposite of the “philosopher” types who tend to get lost in clouds of possibilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 255 “Any damn fool can make it complex. It takes a genius to make it simple.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 255 1. Slow down your thinking so you can note the criteria you are using to make your decision. 2. Write the criteria down as a principle. 3. Think about those criteria when you have an outcome to assess, and refine them before the next “one of those” comes along.

Yellow highlight | Page: 258 I believe that it won’t be long before this kind of computerized decision making guides us nearly as much as our brains do now.

Yellow highlight | Page: 273 1.7 Pain + Reflection = Progress. a. Go to the pain rather than avoid it. b. Embrace tough love.

Yellow highlight | Page: 273 The biggest mistake most people make is to not see themselves and others objectively, which leads them to bump into their own and others’ weaknesses again and again.

Yellow highlight | Page: 273 Asking others who are strong in areas where you are weak to help you is a great skill that you should develop no matter what, as it will help you develop guardrails that will prevent you from doing what you shouldn’t be doing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 Prioritize: While you can have virtually anything you want, you can’t have everything you want. b. Don’t confuse goals with desires. c. Decide what you really want in life by reconciling your goals and your desires. d. Don’t mistake the trappings of success for success itself. e. Never rule out a goal because you think it’s unattainable.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 Remember that great expectations create great capabilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 g. Almost nothing can stop you from succeeding if you have a) flexibility and b) self-accountability.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 a. Focus on the “what is” before deciding “what to do about it.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 a. Go back before you go forward.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 c. Remember that there are typically many paths to achieving your goals.

Yellow highlight | Page: 274 2.5 Push through to completion. a. Great planners who don’t execute their plans go nowhere. b. Good work habits are vastly underrated. c. Establish clear metrics to make certain that you are following your plan.

Yellow highlight | Page: 275 b. Everyone has at least one big thing that stands in the way of their success; find yours and deal with it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 275 a. Sincerely believe that you might not know the best possible path and recognize that your ability to deal well with “not knowing” is more important than whatever it is you do know. b. Recognize that decision making is a two-step process: First take in all the relevant information, then decide. c. Don’t worry about looking good; worry about achieving your goal. d. Realize that you can’t put out without taking in. e. Recognize that to gain the perspective that comes from seeing things through another’s eyes, you must suspend judgment for a time—only by

Yellow highlight | Page: 276 4.1 Understand the power that comes from knowing how you and others are wired. a. We are born with attributes that can

Yellow highlight | Page: 276 both help us and hurt us, depending on their application.

Yellow highlight | Page: 276 a. Realize that the conscious mind is in a battle with the subconscious mind. b. Know that the most constant struggle is between feeling and thinking. c. Reconcile your feelings and your thinking. d. Choose your habits well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 276 e. Train your “lower-level you” with kindness and persistence to build the right habits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 d. New is overvalued relative to great.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 e. Don’t oversqueeze dots.

Yellow highlight | Page: 277 5.8 Simplify! 5.9 Use principles. 5.10 Believability weight your decision making. 5.11 Convert your principles into algorithms and have the computer make decisions alongside you. 5.12 Be cautious about trusting AI without having deep understanding.

Yellow highlight | Page: 406 a high level, we look for people who think independently, argue open-mindedly and assertively, and above all else value the intense pursuit of truth and excellence, and through it, the rapid improvement of themselves and the organization. Because we treat work as more than just what we do to make a living, we look at every potential hire not just as an employee but as someone we’d want share our lives with. We insist that the people we work with are considerate and have a high sense of personal accountability to do the difficult, right things. We look for people with generous natures and high standards of fairness. Most important, they must be able to put their egos aside and assess themselves candidly.

Yellow highlight | Page: 407 a. Think through which values, abilities, and skills you are looking for (in that order). Values are the deep-seated beliefs that motivate behaviors and determine people’s compatibilities with each other. People will fight for their values, and they are likely to fight with people who don’t share them. Abilities are ways of thinking and behaving. Some people are great learners and fast processors; others

Yellow highlight | Page: 407 possess the ability to see things at a higher level. Some focus more on the particulars; still others think creatively or logically or with supreme organization. Skills are learned tools, such as being able to speak a foreign

Yellow highlight | Page: 407 While values and abilities are unlikely to change much, most skills can be acquired in a limited amount of time (e.g., software proficiency can be learned) and often change in worth (today’s most in-demand programming language is likely to be

Yellow highlight | Page: 408 Since at Bridgewater the key shared values that maintain our culture are meaningful work and meaningful relationships, radical truth and radical transparency, an open-minded willingness to explore harsh realities including one’s own weaknesses, a sense of ownership, a drive for excellence, and the willingness to do the good but difficult things, we look for highly capable people who deeply want all of those things.

Yellow highlight | Page: 413 But when it comes to assessing a candidate’s common sense, vision, creativity, or decision-making abilities, school records are of limited value.

Yellow highlight | Page: 416 and build in bonuses or other incentives so they will be motivated to knock the cover off the ball. Never pay based on the job title alone.

Yellow highlight | Page: 422 we had literally hundreds of data points on the specific attributes required for the job, including synthesis, knowing what he didn’t know, and managing at the right level.

Yellow highlight | Page: 425 Give people your thoughts on how they might approach their decisions, but don’t dictate to them. The most useful thing you can do is to get in sync with them, exploring how they are doing things and why.

Yellow highlight | Page: 425 Feedback should reflect what is succeeding and what is not in proportion to the actual situation, rather than in an attempt to balance compliments and criticisms.

Yellow highlight | Page: 426 b. Put your compliments and criticisms in perspective. It helps to clarify whether the weakness or mistake under discussion is indicative of a trainee’s total evaluation.

Yellow highlight | Page: 426 Had I explained myself better when we sat down that second time, he could have put my comment into perspective.

Yellow highlight | Page: 426 Think about accuracy, not implications. It’s often the case that someone receiving critical feedback gets preoccupied with the implications of that feedback instead of whether it’s true. This is a mistake. As I’ll explain later, conflating the “what is” with the “what to do about it” typically leads to bad decision making.

Yellow highlight | Page: 427 Your assessment of how Responsible Parties are performing should be based not on whether they’re doing it your way but on whether they’re doing it in a good way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 427 Learn from success as well as from failure. Radical truth doesn’t require you to be negative all the time. Point out examples of jobs done well and the causes of their success. This reinforces the actions that led to the results and creates role models for those who are learning.

Yellow highlight | Page: 427 The greatest gift you can give someone is the power to be successful. Giving people the opportunity to struggle rather than giving them the things they are struggling for will make them stronger.

Yellow highlight | Page: 428 Compliments are easy to give but they don’t help people stretch.

Yellow highlight | Page: 428 While it is important to be clear to people about what they are doing well, it is even more important to point out their weaknesses and have them reflect on them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 428 Build your synthesis from the specifics up. By synthesizing, I mean converting a lot of data into an accurate picture.

Yellow highlight | Page: 434 Put things in perspective by reminding them that their pain is the pain that comes with learning and personal evolution—and that knowing the truth will put them on the path to a much better place.

Yellow highlight | Page: 435 Knowing how people operate and being able to judge whether that way of operating will lead to good results is more important than knowing what they did. Knowing what people are like is the best indicator of how well they are likely to handle their responsibilities in the future. At Bridgewater, we call this “paying more attention to the swing than the shot.” Since good and bad outcomes can arise from circumstances that might not have had anything to do with how the individual handled the situation, it is preferable to assess people based on both their reasoning and their outcomes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 435 Doing this has taught me a lot about how to assess others’ logic, and how to have better logic myself.

Yellow highlight | Page: 436 Abilities, especially right-brained abilities, are more difficult to assess. When thinking about why someone is a poor performer, openly consider whether it is a problem with their abilities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 448 Manage as Someone Operating a Machine to Achieve a Goal

Yellow highlight | Page: 452 Build great metrics. Metrics show how the machine is working by providing numbers and setting off alert lights in a dashboard.

Yellow highlight | Page: 36 This new science of performance argues that you get better at a skill as you develop more myelin around the relevant neurons, allowing the corresponding circuit to fire more effortlessly and effectively.

Yellow highlight | Page: 36 The reason, therefore, why it’s important to focus intensely on the task at hand while avoiding distraction is because this is the only way to isolate the relevant neural circuit enough to trigger useful myelination.

Yellow highlight | Page: 74 “The satisfactions of manifesting oneself concretely in the world through manual competence have been known to make a man quiet and easy,” explains Matthew Crawford. And we believe him.

Yellow highlight | Page: 76 is, what we choose to focus on and what we choose to ignore—plays in defining the quality of our life.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 skillful management of attention is the sine qua non of the good life and the key to improving virtually every aspect of your experience.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 According to Gallagher, decades of research contradict this understanding. Our brains instead construct our worldview based on what we pay attention to.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 As Gallagher summarizes: “Who you are, what you think, feel, and do, what you love—is the sum of what you focus on.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 After a bad or disrupting occurrence in your life, Fredrickson’s research shows, what you choose to focus on exerts significant leverage on your attitude going forward.

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 so consider for a moment the type of mental world constructed when you dedicate significant time to deep endeavors.

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 Gallagher’s theory, therefore, predicts that if you spend enough time in this state, your mind will understand your world as rich in meaning and importance.
