Yellow highlight | Page: 84 The best moments usually occur when a person’s body or mind is stretched to its limits in a voluntary effort to accomplish something difficult and worthwhile.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 86 Kelly published a book, All Things Shining, which explores how notions of sacredness and meaning have evolved throughout the history of human culture. They set out to reconstruct this history because they’re worried about its endpoint in our current era. “The world used to be, in its various forms, a world of sacred, shining things,” Dreyfus and Kelly explain early in the book. “The shining things now seem far away.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 they conclude, “is not to generate meaning, but rather to cultivate in himself the skill of discerning the meanings that are already there.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 89 Any pursuit—be it physical or cognitive—that supports high levels of skill can also generate a sense of sacredness.

Yellow highlight | Page: 92 earlier quoted Winifred Gallagher, the converted disciple of depth, saying, “I’ll live the focused life, because it’s the best kind there is.” This is perhaps the best way to sum up the argument of this chapter and of Part 1 more broadly: A deep life is a good life, any way you look at

Yellow highlight | Page: 95 eudaimonia (a state in which you’re achieving your full human potential),

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 As Baumeister summarized in his subsequent book, Willpower (co-authored with the science writer John Tierney): “Desire turned out to be the norm, not the exception.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 100 You have a finite amount of willpower that becomes depleted as you use it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 Persons who wish to interfere with my concentration are politely requested not to do so,

Yellow highlight | Page: 109 His 2013 bestseller, Give and Take, promotes the practice of giving of your time and attention, without expectation of something in return, as a key strategy in professional advancement.

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 Ritualize An often-overlooked observation about those who use their minds to create valuable things is that they’re rarely haphazard in their work habits.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 perhaps the single best piece of advice I can offer to anyone trying to do creative work is to ignore inspiration.

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 David Brooks summarizes this reality more bluntly: “[Great creative minds] think like artists but work like accountants.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 119 To make the most out of your deep work sessions, build rituals of the same level of strictness and idiosyncrasy as the important thinkers mentioned previously.

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 depth. The dominant force is the psychology of committing so seriously to the task at hand. To

Yellow highlight | Page: 134 Second, even when you retreat to a spoke to think deeply, when it’s reasonable to leverage the whiteboard effect, do so. By working side by side with someone on a problem, you can push each other toward deeper levels of depth,

Yellow highlight | Page: 135 entrenched companies are often unexpectedly dethroned by start-ups that begin with cheap offerings at the low end of the market,

Yellow highlight | Page: 135 “You are such a naïve academic. I asked you how to do it, and you told me what I should do. I know what I need to do. I just don’t know how to do it.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 136 execution should be aimed at a small number of “wildly important goals.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 137 Once you’ve identified a wildly important goal, you need to measure your success.

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 The 4DX framework is based on the fundamental premise that execution is more difficult than strategizing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 141 In retrospect, it was not so much the intensity of my deep work periods that increased, but instead their regularity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 143 insight: It made him better at his job. Here’s Kreider’s explanation: Idleness is not just a vacation, an indulgence or a vice; it is as indispensable to the brain as vitamin D is to the body, and deprived of it we suffer a mental affliction

Yellow highlight | Page: 147 This study, it turns out, is one of many that validate attention restoration theory (ART), which claims that spending time in nature can improve your ability to concentrate.

Yellow highlight | Page: 149 to Anders Ericsson, the inventor of deliberate practice theory.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 succeeding with this strategy is to support your commitment to shutting down with a strict shutdown ritual that you use at the end of the workday to maximize the probability that you succeed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 151 When you’re done, have a set phrase you say that indicates completion (to end my own ritual, I say, “Shutdown complete”).

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 Bluma Zeigarnik, describes the ability of incomplete tasks to dominate our attention.

Yellow highlight | Page: 161 If you eat healthy just one day a week, you’re unlikely to lose weight, as the majority of your time is still spent gorging.

Yellow highlight | Page: 164 Point #3: Scheduling Internet use at home as well as at work can further improve your concentration training.

Yellow highlight | Page: 175 direct measure of memory at all but of attention,” explained Roediger in a New York Times blog post (emphasis mine). The ability in question is called “attentional control,” and it measures the subjects’ ability to maintain

Yellow highlight | Page: 219 day.* In their seminal paper on deliberate practice, Anders Ericsson and his collaborators survey these studies.
