Your Kindle Notes For: Getting to Yes: Negotiating an agreement without giving in Roger Fisher and William Ury Last accessed on Saturday November 3, 2018 266 Highlight(s) | 3 Note(s) Yellow highlight | Location: 441 The third point responds to the difficulty of designing optimal solutions while under pressure. Trying to decide in the presence of an adversary narrows your vision. Having a lot at stake inhibits creativity. So does searching for the one right solution.

Yellow highlight | Location: 444 Before trying to reach agreement, invent options for mutual gain.

Yellow highlight | Location: 446 However, you can counter such a negotiator by insisting that his single say-so is not enough and that the agreement must reflect some fair standard independent of the naked will of either side.

Yellow highlight | Location: 516 Routinely, they fail to interpret what you say in the way you intend and do not mean what you understand them to say.

Yellow highlight | Location: 521 it is worth asking yourself, “Am I paying enough attention to the people problem?”

Yellow highlight | Location: 536 people draw from comments on substance unfounded inferences,

Yellow highlight | Location: 536 which they then treat as facts about that person’s intentions and attitudes toward

Yellow highlight | Location: 582 The ability to see the situation as the other side sees it, as difficult as it may be, is one of the most important skills a negotiator can possess.

Yellow highlight | Location: 594 Don’t deduce their intentions from your fears.

Yellow highlight | Location: 631 Give them a stake in the outcome by making sure they participate in the process.

Yellow highlight | Location: 635 If you want the other side to accept a disagreeable conclusion, it is crucial that you involve them in the process of reaching that conclusion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 686 Pay attention to “core concerns.” Many emotions in negotiation are driven by a core set of five interests: autonomy, the desire to make your own choices and control your own fate; appreciation, the desire to be recognized and valued; affiliation, the desire to belong as an accepted member of some peer group; role, the desire to have a meaningful purpose; and status, the desire to feel fairly seen and acknowledged.

Yellow highlight | Location: 692 we apply our general tendency toward either-or thinking to our self-perception: “I am a kind person.” “I’m a good manager.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 696 If you find a counterpart’s behavior oddly out of character or feel as if you have unexpectedly stepped on a land mine in your conversation, think about whether they might be experiencing a threat to their identity from something you have said or might say.

Yellow highlight | Location: 698 if you find yourself feeling off-balance and emotional, ask yourself if your sense of identity feels threatened.

Yellow highlight | Location: 703 Making your feelings or theirs an explicit focus of discussion will not only underscore the seriousness of the problem, it will also make the negotiations less reactive and more “pro-active.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 707 People obtain psychological release through the simple process of recounting their grievances to an attentive audience.

Yellow highlight | Location: 729 An apology may be one of the least costly and most rewarding investments you can make.

Yellow highlight | Location: 759 “Did I understand correctly that you are saying that …?” the other side will realize that they are not just killing time, not just going through a routine. They will also feel the satisfaction of being heard and understood. It has been said that the cheapest concession you can make to the other side is to let them know they have been heard.

Yellow highlight | Location: 762 to pay close attention to what is said, to ask the other party to spell out carefully and clearly exactly what they mean, and to request that ideas be repeated if there is any ambiguity or uncertainty.

Yellow highlight | Location: 765 Many consider it a good tactic not to give the other side’s case too much attention, and not to admit any legitimacy in their point of view. A good negotiator does just the reverse. Unless you acknowledge what they are saying and demonstrate that you understand them, they may believe you have not heard them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 770 “Let me see whether I follow what you are telling me. From your point of view, the situation looks like this. …”

Yellow highlight | Location: 771 As you repeat what you understood them to have said, phrase it positively from their point of view, making the strength of their case clear.

Yellow highlight | Location: 772 You might say, “You have a strong case.

Yellow highlight | Location: 773 Here’s the way it strikes me.

Yellow highlight | Location: 774 But unless you can convince them that you do grasp how they see it, you may be unable to get them to hear when you explain your viewpoint to them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 776 If you can put their case better than they can, and then refute it, you maximize the chance of initiating a constructive dialogue on the merits and minimize the chance of their believing you have misunderstood them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 789 “Open covenants privately arrived at.” No matter how many people are involved in a negotiation, important decisions are typically made when no more than two people are in the room.

Yellow highlight | Location: 790 Speak about yourself, not about them. In many negotiations, each side explains and condemns at great length the motivations and intentions of the other side. It is more persuasive, however, to describe a problem in terms of its impact on you than in terms of what they did or why: “I feel let down” instead of “You broke your word.” “We feel discriminated against” rather than “You’re a racist.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 795 convey the same information without provoking a defensive reaction that will prevent them from taking it in.

Yellow highlight | Location: 813 Benjamin Franklin’s favorite technique was to ask an adversary if he could borrow a certain book. This would flatter the person and give him the comfortable feeling of knowing that Franklin owed him a favor.

Yellow highlight | Location: 838 1 For more on the core concerns and how to manage them in negotiation, see Roger Fisher and Daniel Shapiro, Beyond Reason: Using Emotions As You Negotiate (Penguin, 2006). 2 For more on identity and other human factors that can get in the way of problem-solving negotiation, see Douglas Stone, Bruce Patton, and Sheila Heen, Difficult Conversations: How to Discuss What Matters Most (Viking/Penguin, 1999; 2nd Edition, 2010).

Yellow highlight | Location: 846 “To get some fresh air.” She asks the other why he wants it closed: “To avoid the draft.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 848 For a wise solution reconcile interests, not positions This story is typical of many negotiations. Since the parties’ problem appears to be a conflict of positions, and since their goal is to agree on a position, they naturally tend to think and talk about positions—and in the process often reach an impasse.

Yellow highlight | Location: 853 Interests define the problem. The basic problem in a negotiation lies not in conflicting positions, but in the conflict between each side’s needs, desires, concerns, and fears. The parties may say:

Yellow highlight | Location: 861 the hubbub of positions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 874 Reconciling interests rather than positions works for two reasons. First, for every interest there usually exist several possible positions that could satisfy

Yellow highlight | Location: 876 When you do look behind opposed positions for the motivating interests, you can often find an alternative position that meets not only your interests but theirs as well. In the Sinai, demilitarization was one such alternative.

Yellow highlight | Location: 878 Reconciling interests rather than compromising between positions also works because behind opposed positions lie many more interests than conflicting ones.

Yellow highlight | Location: 879 Behind opposed positions lie shared and compatible interests, as well as conflicting ones.

Yellow highlight | Location: 880 We tend to assume that because the other side’s positions are opposed to ours, their interests must also be opposed. If we have an interest in defending ourselves, then they must want to attack us. If we have an interest in minimizing the rent, then their interest must be to maximize it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 882 reveal the existence of many more interests that are shared or compatible than ones that are opposed.

Yellow highlight | Location: 961 security economic well-being a sense of belonging recognition control over one’s life

Yellow highlight | Location: 984 The purpose of negotiating is to serve your interests. The chance of that happening increases when you communicate them. The other side may not know what your interests are, and you may not know theirs.

Yellow highlight | Location: 992 Make your interests come alive. If you go with a raging ulcer to see a doctor, you should not hope for much relief if you describe it as a mild stomachache. It is your job to have the other side understand exactly how important and legitimate your interests are.

Yellow highlight | Location: 998 Inviting the other side to “correct me if I’m wrong” shows your openness, and if they do not correct you, it implies that they accept your description of the situation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,005 People listen better if they feel that you have understood them. They tend to think that those who understand them are intelligent and sympathetic people whose own opinions may be worth listening to.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,013 Put the problem before your answer.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,015 you do, you can be quite certain that the representatives will not be listening to the reasons. They have heard your position and are no doubt busy preparing arguments against it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,018 If you want someone to listen and understand your reasoning, give your interests and reasoning first and your conclusions or proposals later.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,030 The question “Why?” has two quite different meanings.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,031 The other looks forward for a purpose and treats our behavior as subject to our free will.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,064 One useful rule of thumb is to give positive support to the human beings on the other side equal in strength to the vigor with which you emphasize the problem. This combination of support and attack may seem inconsistent. Psychologically, it is; the inconsistency helps make it work. A well-known theory of psychology, the theory of cognitive dissonance, holds that people dislike inconsistency and will act to eliminate it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,070 Fighting hard on the substantive issues increases the pressure for an effective solution; giving support to the human beings on the other side tends to improve your relationship and to increase the likelihood of reaching agreement. It is the combination of support and attack that works; either alone is likely to be insufficient.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,079 Often you are negotiating along a single dimension,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,086 He expands the pie before dividing it. Skill at inventing options is one of the most useful assets a negotiator can have.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,088 Yet all too often negotiators end up like the proverbial children who quarreled over an orange. After they finally agreed to divide the orange in half, the first child took one half, ate the fruit, and threw away the peel, while the other threw away the fruit and used the peel from the second half in baking a cake. All too often negotiators “leave money on the table” — they fail to reach agreement when they might have, or the agreement they do reach could have been better for each side. Too many negotiations end up with half an orange for each side instead of the whole fruit for one and the whole peel for the other. Why?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,093 As valuable as it is to have many options, people involved in a negotiation rarely sense a need for them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,095 All available answers appear to lie along a straight line between their position and yours. Often the only creative thinking shown is to suggest splitting the difference.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,097 In most negotiations there are four major obstacles that inhibit the inventing of an abundance of options: (1) premature judgment; (2) searching for the single answer; (3) the assumption of a fixed pie; and (4) thinking that “solving their problem is their problem.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,100 Inventing options does not come naturally. Not inventing is the normal state of affairs,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,105 Nothing is so harmful to inventing as a critical sense waiting to pounce on the drawbacks of any new idea. Judgment hinders imagination.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,107 Practical negotiation appears to call for practical thinking, not wild ideas.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,107 Your creativity may be even more stifled by the presence of those on the other side.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,122 If the first impediment to creative thinking is premature criticism, the second is premature closure.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,136 separate the act of inventing options from the act of judging them; (2) broaden the options on the table rather than look for a single answer; (3) search for mutual gains; and (4) invent ways of making their decisions easy.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,140 Invent first, decide later.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,144 A brainstorming session is designed to produce as many ideas as possible to solve the problem at hand. The key ground rule is to postpone all criticism and evaluation of ideas.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,146 With those inhibitions removed, one idea should stimulate another, like firecrackers setting off one another.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,155 The more different a brainstorming session seems from a normal meeting, the easier it is for participants to suspend judgment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,157 Design an informal atmosphere.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,159 Choose a facilitator. Someone at the meeting needs to facilitate—to keep the meeting on track,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,162 Seat the participants side by side facing the problem. The physical reinforces the psychological.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,162 Physically sitting side by side can reinforce the mental attitude of tackling a common problem together.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,165 2. Clarify the ground rules, including the no-criticism rule.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,168 If ideas are shot down unless they appeal to all participants, the implicit goal becomes to advance an idea that no one will shoot down. If, on the other hand, wild ideas are encouraged, even those that in fact lie well outside the realm of the possible, the group may generate from these ideas other options that are possible and that no one would previously have considered.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,171 to make the entire session off the record and

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,172 3. Brainstorm. Once the purpose of the meeting is clear, let your imaginations go.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,174 Record the ideas in full view. Recording ideas either on a whiteboard or flipcharts gives the group a tangible sense of collective achievement; it reinforces the no-criticism rule; it reduces the tendency to repeat; and it helps stimulate other ideas.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,176 After brainstorming:

Note:make a brainstorming procedure

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,177 Star the most promising ideas.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,179 Invent improvements for promising ideas.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,181 “What I like best about that idea is. … Might it be even better if …?”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,192 To reduce the risk of appearing committed to any given idea, you can make a habit of advancing at least two alternatives at the same time.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,193 You can also put on the table options with which you obviously disagree. “I could give you the house for nothing, or you could pay me a million dollars in cash for it, or. …” Since you are plainly not proposing either of these ideas, the ones that follow are labeled as mere possibilities, not proposals.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,224 But whether you brainstorm together or not, separating the act of developing options from the act of deciding on them is extremely useful in any negotiation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,225 Discussing options differs radically from taking positions. Whereas one side’s position will conflict with another’s, options invite other options. The very language you use differs. It consists of questions, not assertions; it is open, not closed: “One option is. … What other options have you thought of?” “What if we agreed to this?” “How about doing it this way?” “How would this work?” “What would be wrong with that?” Invent before you decide.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,230 Even with the best of intentions, participants in a brainstorming session are likely to operate on the assumption that they are really looking for the one best answer,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,234 A vintner making a fine wine chooses his grapes from a number of varieties.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,236 The key to wise decision-making, whether in wine-making, sports, or negotiation, lies in selecting from a great number and variety of options.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,241 A brainstorming session frees people to think creatively. Once freed, they need ways to think about their problems and to generate constructive solutions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,243 The task of inventing options involves four types of thinking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,273 Look through the eyes of different experts. Another way to generate multiple options is to examine your problem from the perspective of different professions and disciplines.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,307 Look for mutual gain

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,308 The third major block to creative problem-solving lies in the assumption of a fixed pie: the less for you, the more for me.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,311 Even apart from a shared interest in averting joint loss, there almost always exists the possibility of joint gain.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,313 Identify shared interests. In theory it is obvious that shared interests help produce agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,331 a joint publicity campaign with the Chamber of Commerce to attract new companies, a reduction in taxes for existing industries that choose to expand.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,340 Three points about shared interests are worth remembering. First, shared interests lie latent in every negotiation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,341 Ask yourself: Do we have a shared interest in preserving our relationship? What opportunities lie ahead for cooperation and mutual benefit? What costs would we bear if negotiations broke off? Are there common principles, like a fair price, that we both can respect?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,344 Second, shared interests are opportunities, not godsends. To be of use, you need to make something out of them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,344 It helps to make a shared interest explicit and to formulate it as a shared goal. In other words, make it concrete and future-oriented.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,346 The tax holiday for new industries would then represent not a concession by the mayor to you but an action in pursuit of your shared goal.

Note:present what they give off as an action to reach their goal not as concession or lose

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,348 stressing your shared interests can make the negotiation smoother and more amicable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,350 Dovetail differing interests.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,352 In this case as in many others, a satisfactory agreement is made possible because each side wants different things.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,353 People generally assume that differences between two parties create the problem. Yet differences can also lead to a solution.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,354 Agreement is often based on disagreement. It is as absurd to think, for example, that you should always begin by reaching agreement on the facts as it is for a

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,358 Many creative agreements reflect this principle of reaching agreement through differences. Differences in interests and belief make it possible for an item to be of high benefit to you, yet low cost to the other side. Consider the nursery rhyme:

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,391 Look for items that are of low cost to you and high benefit to them, and vice versa.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,396 Impressed with the merits of their own case, people usually pay too little attention to ways of advancing their case by taking care of interests on the other side.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,411 Your task is to give them not a problem but an answer, to give them not a tough decision but an easy one. It is crucial in that process to focus your attention on the content of the decision itself. That decision is often impeded by uncertainty.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,431 Search for it. Look for a decision or statement that the other side may have made in a similar situation,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,432 provides an objective standard for your request and makes it easier for them to go along. Recognizing their probable desire to be consistent, thinking about what they have already done or said will help you generate options acceptable to you that also take their point of view into account.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,437 We often try to influence others by threats and warnings of what will happen if they do not decide as we would like. Offers are usually more effective.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,438 Concentrate both on making them aware of the consequences they can expect if they do decide as you wish and on improving those consequences from their point of view.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,439 How can you make your offers more credible?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,440 What can you invent that might be attractive to them but low in cost to yourself?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,446 Try to draft a proposal to which their responding with the single word “yes” would be sufficient, realistic, and operational.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,450 Therefore, generate many options before selecting among them. Invent first; decide later.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,464 As discussed in Chapter 1, trying to reconcile differences on the basis of will has serious costs. No

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,467 If trying to settle differences of interest on the basis of will has such high costs, the solution is to negotiate on some basis independent of the will of either side—that is, on the basis of objective criteria.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,481 In short, the approach is to commit yourself to reaching a solution based on principle, not pressure. Concentrate on the merits of the problem, not the mettle of the parties. Be open to reason, but closed to threats.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,513 Carrying on a principled negotiation involves two questions: How do you develop objective criteria,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,546 The solution devised was to agree that a private company seeking to mine the seabed would present the Enterprise with two proposed mining sites. The Enterprise would pick one site for itself and grant the

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,559 They can ask a mediator to help them reach a decision. Or they can submit the matter to an arbitrator for an authoritative and binding decision.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,560 Professional baseball, for example, uses “last-best-offer arbitration” to settle player salary disputes.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,562 pressure on the parties to make their proposals more reasonable.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,568 Frame each issue as a joint search for objective criteria.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,569 Reason and be open to reason as to which standards are most appropriate and how they should be applied.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,570 Never yield to pressure, only to principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,571 In short, focus on objective criteria firmly but flexibly.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,574 other side may have conflicting interests, but the two of you now have a shared goal: to determine a fair price.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,577 Ask “What’s your theory?” If the seller starts by giving you a position, such as “The price is $255,000,” ask for the theory behind that price: “How did you arrive at that figure?” Treat the problem as though the seller too is looking for a fair price based on objective criteria.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,580 Agree first on principles.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,581 Each standard the other side proposes becomes a lever you can then use to persuade them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,581 Your case will have more impact if it is presented in terms of their

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,582 criteria, and they will find it difficult to resist applying their criteria to the problem.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,583 Your theory is that this house should be sold for what comparable houses in the neighborhood are going for, am I right?

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,586 the standard, their deferring to it is not an act of weakness but an act of strength, of carrying out their word.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,588 mind. In most negotiations, people use precedent and other objective standards simply as arguments in support of a position.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,594 This is emphatically not what is meant by principled negotiation. Insisting that an agreement be based on objective criteria does not mean insisting that it be based solely on the criterion you advance.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,597 you should be willing to respond to reasons for applying another standard or for applying a standard differently. When each party is advancing a different standard, look for an objective basis for deciding between them, such as which standard has been used by the parties in the past or which standard is more widely applied.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,604 you might suggest putting them to a test. Agree on someone you both regard as fair and give him or her a list of the proposed criteria.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,608 The difference between seeking agreement on the appropriate principles for deciding a matter and using principles simply as arguments to support positions is sometimes subtle, but always significant.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,610 A principled negotiator is open to reasoned persuasion on the merits; a positional bargainer is not.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,610 It is the combination of openness to reason with insistence on a solution based on objective criteria that makes principled negotiation so persuasive

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,612 Never yield to pressure.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,613 hire your brother-in-law on the condition that you give in on the depth of the foundations? You would probably answer, “A job for my brother-in-law has nothing to do with whether the house will be safely supported on a foundation of that depth.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,615 “We’ll settle that question on the merits too.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,616 Let’s see what other contractors charge for this kind of work,”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,616 “Bring me your cost figures and we’ll work out a fair profit margin.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,617 “Trust is an entirely separate matter. The issue is how deep the foundations have to be to make the house safe.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,619 Pressure can take many forms: a bribe, a threat, a manipulative appeal to trust, or a simple refusal to budge. In all these cases, the principled response is the same: invite them to state their reasoning, suggest objective criteria you think apply, and refuse to budge except on this basis. Never yield to pressure, only to principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,627 principled negotiation is a dominant strategy over positional bargaining.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,630 Principle serves as your hardhearted partner who will not let you yield to pressure. It is a form of “right makes might.”

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,639 Shifting discussion in a negotiation from the question of what the other side is willing to do to the question of how the matter ought to be decided does not end argument, nor does it guarantee a favorable result. It does, however, provide a strategy you can vigorously pursue without the high costs of positional bargaining.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,648 1 For more interesting examples from the Law of the Sea negotiations, see James K. Sebenius, Negotiating the Law of the Sea: Lessons in the Art and Science of Reaching Agreement (Harvard University Press, 1984).

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,667 When you are trying to catch an airplane your goal may seem tremendously important; looking back on it, you see you could have caught the next plane. Negotiation will often present you with a similar situation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,671 The siren song of “Let’s all agree and put an end to this” becomes persuasive. You may end up with a deal you should have rejected.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,676 Having a bottom line makes it easier to resist pressure and temptations of the moment.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,684 But the protection afforded by adopting a bottom line involves high costs. It limits your ability to benefit from what you learn during negotiation. By definition, a bottom line is a position that is not to be changed.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,686 A bottom line also inhibits imagination. It reduces the incentive to invent a tailor-made solution that would reconcile differing interests in a way more advantageous for both you and them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,691 this. A bottom line—by its very nature rigid—is almost certain to be too rigid.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,699 Is there an alternative to the bottom line? Is there a measure for agreements that will protect you against both accepting an agreement you should reject and rejecting an agreement you should accept? There is.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,708 The reason you negotiate is to produce something better than the results you can obtain without negotiating.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,709 What is your BATNA—your Best Alternative To a Negotiated Agreement? That is the standard against which any proposed agreement should be measured.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,714 If you have not thought carefully about what you will do if you fail to reach an agreement, you are negotiating with your eyes closed.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,718 One frequent mistake is psychologically to see your alternatives in the aggregate. You may be telling yourself that if you do not reach agreement on a salary for this job, you could always go to California, or go south, or go back to school, or write, or work on a farm, or live in Paris, or do something else. In your mind you are likely to find the sum of these alternatives more attractive than working for a specific salary in a particular job.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,722 you fail to reach agreement, you will have to choose just one.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,723 In most circumstances, however, the greater danger is that you are too committed to reaching agreement. Not having developed any alternative to a negotiated solution, you are unduly pessimistic about what would happen if negotiations broke off.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,727 You may think to yourself, “Let’s negotiate first and see what happens. If things don’t work out, then I’ll figure out what to do.” But having at least a tentative answer to the question is absolutely essential if you are to conduct your negotiations wisely.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,732 it is useful to identify one far from perfect agreement that is better than your BATNA.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,741 In fact, the relative negotiating power of two parties depends primarily upon how attractive to each is the option of not reaching agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,745 The tourist may be wealthy and “powerful,” but in this negotiation he will be weak indeed unless he knows approximately how much it would cost and how difficult it would be to find a comparable pot elsewhere.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,749 Think for a moment about how you would feel walking into a job interview with no other job offers—only some uncertain leads. Think how the talk about salary would go. Now contrast that with how you would feel walking in with two other job offers. How would that salary negotiation proceed? The difference is power.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,760 because they were not converted into a good BATNA, proved of little use. Having an attractive BATNA, the small town had more ability to affect the outcome of the negotiation than did one of the world’s largest corporations.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,763 Vigorous exploration of what you will do if you do not reach agreement can greatly strengthen your hand. Attractive alternatives are not just sitting there waiting for you; you usually have to develop them.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,764 (1) inventing a list of actions you might conceivably take if no agreement is reached; (2) improving some of the more promising ideas and converting them into practical alternatives; and (3) selecting, tentatively, the one alternative that seems best.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,770 The second stage is to improve the best of your ideas and turn the most promising into real alternatives.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,777 Having gone through this effort, you now have a BATNA.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,777 Judge every offer against it. The better your BATNA, the greater your ability to improve the terms of any negotiated agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,779 It is easier to break off negotiations if you know where you’re going. The

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,780 greater your willingness to break off negotiations, the more forcefully you can present your interests and the basis on which you believe an agreement should be reached.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,783 If they think you lack a good alternative when in fact you have one, then you should almost certainly let them know.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,789 reached. Perhaps they have a vague notion that they have a great many alternatives and are under the influence of their cumulative total.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,789 they appear to overestimate their BATNA, you will want to help them think through whether their expectations are realistic.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,803 Apply knowledge, time, money, people, connections, and wits into devising the best solution for you independent of the other side’s assent.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,804 The more easily and happily you can walk away from a negotiation, the greater your capacity to affect its outcome.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,806 Developing your BATNA is perhaps the most effective course of action you can take in dealing with a seemingly more powerful negotiator.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,826 If the other side announces a firm position, you may be tempted to criticize and reject it. If they criticize your proposal, you may be tempted to defend it and dig yourself in.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,827 If they attack you, you may be tempted to defend yourself and counterattack. In short, if they push you hard, you will tend to push back.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,834 Break the vicious cycle by refusing to react. Instead of pushing back, sidestep their attack and deflect it against the problem.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,836 Rather than resisting their force, channel it into exploring interests, inventing options for mutual gain, and searching for independent standards.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,847 ask them how they think it addresses the problem at hand. Treat their position as one option and objectively examine the extent to which

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,871 Examine their negative judgments to find out their underlying interests and to improve your ideas from their point of view.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,876 turn the situation around and ask for their advice. Ask them what they would do if they were in your position.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,882 Recast an attack on you as an attack on the problem. When the other side attacks you personally — as frequently happens — resist the temptation to defend yourself or to attack them. Instead, sit back and allow them to let off steam.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,883 Listen to them, show you understand what they are saying,

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,887 Ask questions and pause. Those engaged in negotiation jujitsu use two key tools. The first is to use questions instead of statements.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,888 Statements generate resistance, whereas questions generate answers.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,893 Silence is one of your best weapons. Use it. If they have made an unreasonable proposal or an attack you regard as unjustified, the best thing to do may be to sit there and not say a word.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,894 If you have asked an honest question to which they have provided an insufficient answer, just wait. People tend to feel uncomfortable with silence, particularly if they have doubts about the merits of something they have said.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,899 Silence often creates the impression of a stalemate that the other side will feel impelled to break by answering your question or coming up with a new suggestion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,900 When you ask questions, pause. Don’t take them off the hook by going right on with another question or some comment of your own. Some of the most effective negotiating you will ever do is when you are not talking.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,967 that a camel is a horse designed by a committee.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,973 Note that in most situations you do not have to get anyone’s consent to start using the one-text procedure.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,974 Simply prepare a draft and ask for criticism.

Yellow highlight | Location: 1,992 The essence of principled negotiation lies in remaining open to persuasion by objective facts and principles.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,000 Making yourself open to correction and persuasion is a pillar in the strategy of principled negotiation. You can convince the other side to be open to the principles and objective standards you suggest only if you show yourself open to the ones they suggest.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,002 “We appreciate what you’ve done for us”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,007 “We have nothing against you personally. We think you’re a generous person.” He puts himself on her side. He defuses any threat she may feel to her self-image.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,008 Praise and support, moreover, imply that the person will continue to deserve them. After being praised, Mrs. Jones now has a slight emotional investment in Turnbull’s approval of her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,011 “Our concern is fairness”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,014 Turnbull takes a basic stand on principle and announces his intention to stick to it;

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,015 he must be persuaded on the basis of principle. At the same time, he lets Mrs. Jones know he is open to persuasion along the lines of this principle. She is thus left with little choice but to reason with him in pursuit of her interests.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,018 His ends, he claims, are a fair balance between rent paid and time spent.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,020 “We would like to settle this on the basis of independent standards, not of who can do what to whom”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,035 But instead of reacting, Turnbull keeps his temper and brings the negotiation back to the merits. This is a good example of negotiation jujitsu. He deflects Mrs. Jones’s attack by taking responsibility for her mistaken perceptions, and he tries to persuade her of his sincere interest in principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,037 He does not hide either his selfish interests or his leverage over her; on the contrary, he makes both explicit. Once they are acknowledged, he can distinguish them from the merits and they can cease being an issue.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,047 however, by expressing his gratitude once more and then defining the question of trust as irrelevant. Turnbull at once reaffirms his appreciation of Mrs. Jones while he remains firm on the principle. In doing so, he avoids connecting the two thoughts with “but,” implicitly using “and” instead. “But,” sometimes called the “great eraser,” has a tendency to negate the first thing you say by implying that only one of two statements can be true, making it either/or. “And” underscores the more complex reality that both thoughts can be true at the same time.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,065 Analysis. Statements of fact can feel lecturing or threatening. Whenever you can, ask a question instead.

Note:important

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,069 Phrasing each piece of information as a question allows Mrs. Jones to participate, listen to the information, evaluate it, and either accept or correct it.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,070 Turnbull communicates the same information to her but in a less provocative manner. He reduces the heat still further by attributing a particularly pointed question to his absent roommate.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,076 A principled negotiator neither accepts nor rejects the other side’s positions.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,076 To keep the dialogue focused on the merits, Turnbull questions Mrs. Jones about the reasons for her position. He does not ask whether there were any reasons. He assumes there are good reasons. This flattering assumption leads the other side to search for reasons even if there are none, thus keeping the negotiation on the basis of principle.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,086 Analysis. Principled negotiation requires good communication. Before responding to Mrs. Jones’s arguments, Turnbull restates to her in positive terms what he has heard to make sure he has indeed understood her.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,087 Once she feels understood, she can relax and discuss the problem constructively.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,088 She can’t dismiss his arguments on the grounds that they do not take into account what she knows. She is more likely to listen now and be more receptive. In trying to sum up her point of view, Turnbull establishes a cooperative game in which both are making sure he understands the facts.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,093 Analysis. A good negotiator rarely makes an important decision on the spot. The psychological pressure to be nice and to give in is too great. A little time and distance help disentangle the people from the problem.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,097 He shows not only decisiveness but also control over the course of the negotiation.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,103 Turnbull: Let me show you where I have trouble following some of your reasons for the extra $268 a month.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,108 Analysis. In principled negotiation you present your reasons first before offering a proposal. If principles come afterward, they appear not as the objective criteria that any proposal should satisfy but as mere justifications for an arbitrary position.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,110 For Turnbull to explain his reasons first shows his openness to persuasion and his awareness of the need to convince Mrs. Jones. If he announced his proposal first, Mrs. Jones probably would not bother to listen to the reasons that followed. Her mind would be elsewhere, considering what objections and counterproposals she could make.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,114 In preparing for your negotiation, it helps to think about what standards would be useful, who might be able to provide them, and how to frame your questions to elicit the most relevant information.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,116 “One fair solution might be …”

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,120 Analysis. Turnbull presents a proposal not as his, but as a fair option that deserves their joint consideration.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,120 He does not claim it is the only fair solution, but one fair solution. He is specific without digging himself into a position and inviting rejection.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,127 Turnbull is trying to make it easy for Mrs. Jones to say yes to his proposal. So he starts by making it clear that all it takes for the problem to go away is Mrs. Jones’s agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,130 without upsetting the negotiations? He bases the alternative on objective principle by attributing it to a legal authority—the hearing examiner.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,131 He distances himself personally from the suggestion.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,144 Incorporating her interests into the agreement not only gives her more of a stake in it but also allows Mrs. Jones to save face.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,148 Paul and I do appreciate, Mrs. Jones, all that you’ve done for us, and I’m pleased that we’ve settled this last problem fairly and amicably.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,194 Don’t attack people personally for using a tactic you consider illegitimate. If they get defensive it may be more difficult for them to give up the tactic, and they may be left with a residue of anger that will fester and interfere with other issues.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,198 Don’t be diverted from the negotiation by the urge to teach them a lesson.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,202 Invent options for mutual gain. Suggest alternative games to play. “How about our undertaking

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,204 Insist on using objective criteria. Above

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,212 Some common tricky tactics Tricky tactics can be divided into three categories: deliberate deception, psychological warfare, and positional pressure

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,223 A practice of verifying factual assertions reduces the incentive for deception, and your risk of being cheated.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,450 expected. In contrast, looking behind positions for interests, inventing options for mutual gain, and finding and using objective criteria take hard work and, when the other side seems recalcitrant, emotional restraint and maturity.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,461 How complex are the issues? The more complex the subject matter, the more unwise it is to engage in positional bargaining. Complexity calls for careful analysis of interests that are shared or that can be creatively dovetailed, and then for brainstorming.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,463 How important is it to maintain a good working relationship? If the other side is a valued customer or client, maintaining your ongoing relationship may be more important to you than the outcome of any one deal. This does not mean you should be less persistent in pursuing your interests, but it does suggest avoiding tactics such as threats or ultimatums that involve a high

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,482 Bargaining over positions does the least harm if it comes after you have identified each other’s interests, invented options for mutual gain, and discussed relevant standards of fairness.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,486 Yet using external standards improves on haggling in three ways: An outcome informed even by conflicting standards of fairness and community practice is likely to be wiser than an arbitrary result.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,506 Using external standards often helps narrow the range of disagreement and may help expand the area of potential agreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,527 Many negotiators are overly optimistic in assuming that they are more clever than their counterparts.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,548 The human propensity for defensive and reactive behavior is one reason so many negotiations fail when agreement would otherwise make sense.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,551 The more seriously you disagree with someone, the more important it is that you be able to deal well with that disagreement.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,561 Rather, substantive issues need to be disentangled from relationship and process issues. The content of a possible agreement needs to be separated from questions of how you talk about it and how you deal with the other side. Each set of issues needs to be negotiated on its own merits. The following list illustrates the distinction: Substantive Issues Terms Conditions Prices Dates Numbers Liabilities Relationship Issues Balance of emotion and reason Ease of communication Degree of trust and reliability Attitude of acceptance (or rejection) Relative emphasis on persuasion (or coercion) Degree of mutual understanding People often assume that there is a trade-off between pursuing a good substantive outcome and pursuing a good relationship. We disagree. A good working relationship tends to make it easier to get good substantive outcomes (for both sides). Good substantive outcomes tend to make a good relationship even better.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,575 Our point is that you should not give in for the purpose of trying to improve a relationship.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,587 Our behavior should be designed to model and encourage the behavior we would prefer and to avoid any reward for the behavior we dislike, both without compromising our substantive interests.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,600 It is the perception that is skewed, not the response to that perception.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,601 On the other hand, if you inquire empathetically, taking their feelings seriously and trying to trace their reasoning to its roots, it is sometimes possible to effect change.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,603 Working with them, you may discover a logical leap, a factual misperception, or a traumatic association from an earlier time that, once brought to light, can be examined and modified by the people themselves.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,604 In essence, you are looking for the psychological interests behind their position, to help them find a way to meet more of their interests more effectively.

Yellow highlight | Location: 2,656 A key point, worth repeating, is that negotiating does not require compromising your principles. More often success is achieved by finding a solution that is arguably consistent with each side’s principles.

Your Kindle Notes For: Who: The A Method for Hiring Geoff Smart and Randy Street Last accessed on Saturday November 3, 2018 225 Highlight(s) | 0 Note(s) Yellow highlight | Page: 5 “One of the hardest challenges is to hire people from outside the company.

Yellow highlight | Page: 5 What is a resume? It is a record of a person’s career with all of the accomplishments embellished and all the failures removed.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 6 “Look, I hired your resume. But unfortunately, what I got was you!”

Yellow highlight | Page: 6 “Otherwise smart people struggle to hire strangers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 7 managers cling to their favorite methods even when evidence suggests they don’t work.

Yellow highlight | Page: 7 Forgers can pass off fake paintings as real ones to the time-pressed buyer, and people who want a job badly enough can fake an interview if it lasts only a few minutes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 Unfortunately, managers rarely coordinate their efforts, leaving everybody to ask the same, superficial questions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 8 but knowledge and ability to do the job are not the same thing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 9 “What type of animal would you be?” The question has a truly voodoo answer key. “I look for people who have a witty answer.” Not only do questions like this lack any relevance or scientific basis, but they are utterly useless as predictors of on-the-job performance.

Yellow highlight | Page: 10 The Psychological and Personality Tester. The Handbook of Industrial/Organizational Psychology

Yellow highlight | Page: 10 Savvy candidates can easily fake the answers based on the job for which they are vying.

Yellow highlight | Page: 10 The Fortune-Teller. Just like a fortune-teller looking in a crystal ball to predict the future, some interviewers like to ask their candidates to look into the future regarding the job at hand by asking hypothetical questions: “What would you do? How would you do it? Could you do it?” Fifty years of academic literature on interview methods makes a strong case against using these types of questions during interviews.

Yellow highlight | Page: 11 Remember, it’s the walk that counts, not the talk.

Yellow highlight | Page: 11 but one of the painful truths of hiring is this: it is hard to see people for who they really are.

Yellow highlight | Page: 12 We define an A Player this way: a candidate who has at least a 90 percent chance of achieving a set of outcomes that only the top 10 percent of possible candidates could achieve.

Yellow highlight | Page: 14 “Hiring A Players is not everything. But it is one of the most important skills to growing a large private equity firm, or

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 person to accomplish in a role. It is not a job description, but rather a set of outcomes and competencies that define a job done well.

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 Systematic sourcing before you have slots to fill ensures you have high-quality candidates waiting when you need them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 a series of structured interviews that allow you to gather the relevant facts about a person so you can rate your scorecard and make an informed hiring decision.

Yellow highlight | Page: 16 Selling the right way ensures you avoid the biggest pitfalls that cause the very people you want the most to take their talents elsewhere.

Yellow highlight | Page: 20 “That’s not what we need at all! We don’t need a tactical planner. We need a visionary leader. We need someone who can survey the market and help us devise new strategies and create new products. We need someone to keep us ahead of the competition.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 20 The first failure point of hiring is not being crystal clear about what you really want the person you hire to accomplish.

Yellow highlight | Page: 21 “In hiring, everything is situational,” he

Yellow highlight | Page: 21 You are going to need different types of leaders at different phases of organizations.

Yellow highlight | Page: 21 That meant I needed somebody with high emotional intelligence, really strong knowledge of the business, really good interpersonal skills, and the ability to build bridges.

Yellow highlight | Page: 21 The scorecard is composed of three parts: the job’s mission, outcomes, and competencies.

Yellow highlight | Page: 23 If you’ve defined the position correctly from the outset, you should be looking for narrow but deep competence.

Yellow highlight | Page: 25 You wouldn’t let your family-practice doctor perform open-heart surgery on you, and in the same way you shouldn’t look for a full team of generalists to solve your business problems.

Yellow highlight | Page: 25 “I think success comes from having the right person in the right job at the right time with the right skill set for the business problem that exists.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 26 Gores has learned to rely on people with job-specific talents, rather than gunning for all-around athletes.

Yellow highlight | Page: 26 “Each target and company has different needs for the CEO and any management role,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 28 “Create and implement a new marketing campaign within 180 days of start date.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 29 Critical Competencies for A Players • Efficiency. Able to produce significant output with minimal wasted effort. • Honesty/integrity. Does not cut corners ethically. Earns trust and maintains confidences. Does what is right, not just what is politically expedient. Speaks plainly and truthfully. • Organization and planning.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 Plans, organizes, schedules, and budgets in an efficient, productive manner. Focuses on key priorities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 • Aggressiveness. Moves quickly and takes a forceful stand without being overly abrasive.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 Follow-through on commitments.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 Lives up to verbal and written agreements, regardless of personal cost.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 Intelligence. Learns quickly. Demonstrates ability to quickly and proficiently understand and absorb new information.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 Analytical skills. Able to structure

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 and process qualitative or quantitative data and draw insightful conclusions from it. Exhibits a probing mind and achieves penetrating insights. • Attention to detail. Does not let important details slip through the cracks or derail a project.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 • Persistence. Demonstrates tenacity and willingness to go the distance to get something done.

Yellow highlight | Page: 30 • Proactivity. Acts without being told what to do. Brings new ideas to the company.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 • Ability to hire A Players (for managers). Sources, selects, and sells A Players to join a company.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 Enthusiasm. Exhibits passion and excitement over work. Has a can-do attitude.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 Listening skills. Lets others speak and seeks to understand their viewpoints.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 Openness to criticism and ideas. Often solicits feedback and reacts calmly to criticism or negative feedback.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 • Communication. Speaks and writes clearly and articulately without being overly verbose or talkative. Maintains this standard in all forms of written communication, including e-mail.

Yellow highlight | Page: 33 “Number two is commitment. Theirs to you and yours to them. That is a difficult thing to assess, but it really matters. I want people who are committed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 33 “Third, are they coachable? I underestimated this earlier in my career. You can pass on learning and shortcut their development if they are.

Yellow highlight | Page: 34 “What adjectives would you use to describe our culture?” Jot down their responses on a flip chart or whiteboard. It won’t take long before a picture emerges. We recently put a new client through this exercise. Soon the room buzzed with words such as analytical, fast-paced, and informal.

Yellow highlight | Page: 38 By translating your culture and values into a series of competencies that matter for every job, you can avoid making the mistake of not evaluating candidates for the cultural fits that are absolutely

Yellow highlight | Page: 38 crucial to your enterprise.

Yellow highlight | Page: 40 Scorecards solve that problem and ensure not just that you have A Players but that the A Players are delivering A performances.

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 “The thing we valued at EMC was the willingness to go one more step than the next guy, to go one more step to service the customer,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 To accomplish that, we specifically hired people who had an unusually high customer service attitude.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 Marino wasn’t hiring merely to fill a position. He was hiring to reinforce corporate strategy and culture, and he held the people he brought in accountable for accomplishing and demonstrating that every day. The results speak for themselves.

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 Set expectations with new hires • Monitor employee progress over time

Yellow highlight | Page: 41 Objectify your annual review system • Allow you to rate your team annually as part of a talent review process

Yellow highlight | Page: 42 The whole key, whether you are hiring, promoting, or managing for performance in the current job, is that you have clear expectations. Having a clear, focused approach helps us be better managers

Yellow highlight | Page: 42 and therefore helps the people we hire have a higher likelihood of success.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 43 The board decided on a few competencies that really mattered to fit the culture they wanted to build and support the outcomes for the role. They wanted someone who was professional, disciplined, caring, fair, and diplomatic.

Yellow highlight | Page: 44 2. OUTCOMES. Develop three to eight specific, objective outcomes that a person must accomplish to achieve an A performance. For example, “Improve customer satisfaction on a ten-point scale from 7.1 to 9.0

Yellow highlight | Page: 44 by December 31.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 46 “We found the process of gathering data from each candidate and comparing it to our scorecard very helpful and worthwhile.

Yellow highlight | Page: 47 They consider themselves chief recruiting officers and expect all of their managers to view their jobs the same way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 47 then. They are always sourcing, always on the lookout for new talent, always identifying the who before a new hire is really needed.

Yellow highlight | Page: 48 Take a moment and think about how passive such an approach is.

Yellow highlight | Page: 48 The overwhelming evidence from our field interviews is that ads are a good way to generate a tidal wave of resumes, but a lousy way to generate the right flow of candidates.

Yellow highlight | Page: 49 Of all the ways to source candidates, the number one method is to ask for referrals from your personal and professional networks. This approach may feel scary and timeconsuming, but it is the single most effective way to find potential A Players.

Yellow highlight | Page: 50 us, a full 77 percent of them cited referrals as their top technique for generating a flow of the right candidates for their businesses. Yet among average managers it is the least often practiced approach to sourcing.

Yellow highlight | Page: 50 I am constantly on the hunt for talented people to bring into my company.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 names. Ryan captures those names on a list, and he makes a point of calling a few new people from his list every week. Then he stays in touch with those who seem to have the most promise.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 “Who are the most talented people you know that I should hire?”—can easily generate another fifty to one hundred names.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 no time you will have moved into many other networks and enriched your personal talent pool with real ability. But don’t stop there. Bring your broader business contacts in on the hunt, too. Ask your customers for the names of the most talented salespeople who call on them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 Ask your business partners who they think are the most effective business developers. Do the same with your suppliers to identify their strongest purchasing agents. Join professional organizations and ask the people you meet through events. People you interact with every day are

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 the most powerful sources of talent you will ever find.

Yellow highlight | Page: 51 “Say, now that I have told you what I do, who are the most talented people you know who could be a good fit for my company?” Do that, and you will turn a common social question into a sourcing opportunity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 52 Ryan nurtured his relationship with Case over a period of many years before finally convincing Case to succeed him as CEO.

Yellow highlight | Page: 53 What sets Patrick Ryan apart from so many other executives is how he actively built his network through referrals, then followed up with high-potential candidates to maintain the relationship.

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 “It takes A Players to know A Players,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 “Our success rate is 60 percent higher for people who are referred by somebody else in our

Yellow highlight | Page: 54 At ghSMART, we’ve made in-house referrals a key part not only of our staffing policies but also of promotions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 The conversation does not have to be long. We frequently begin with something simple like, “Sue recommended that you and I connect. I understand you are great at what you do. I am always on the lookout for talented people and would love the chance to get to know you. Even if you are perfectly content in your current job, I’d love to introduce myself and hear about your career interests.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 Most people will be thrilled to chat. Done well, you will find you can connect with forty or more new people per year.

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 One more thing. When you are done with the call, assuming you were even moderately impressed with what you heard, be sure to ask the key follow-up question: “Now that you know a little about me, who are the most talented people you know who might be a good fit for my company?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 71 Ideally, a candidate will share career goals that match your company’s needs. If he or she lacks goals or sounds like an echo of your own Web site, screen the person out. You are done with the call. Talented people know what they want to do and are not afraid to tell you about it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 72 you still find yourself struggling, we recommend that you put the fear of the reference check into the person. You say, “If you advance to the next step in our process, we will ask for your help in setting up some references with bosses, peers, and subordinates. Okay?” The candidate will say, “Okay.” Then you say, “So I’m curious. What do you think they will say are some things you are not good at, or not interested

Yellow highlight | Page: 72 in?” Now you’ll get an honest and full answer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 72 The thought that you will be talking to references and verifying the candidate’s answers compels the candidate to be much more truthful and complete than usual. You will be amazed how much of a truth serum this technique can be at this stage of the screening interview.

Yellow highlight | Page: 73 Who were your last five bosses, and how will they each rate your performance on a 1–10 scale when we talk to them?

Yellow highlight | Page: 75 about the answer by asking a follow-up question that begins with “What,” “How,” or “Tell me more.” Keep using this framework until you are clear about what the person is really saying.

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 What Brad Smart discovered was the power of using data and patterns of behavior for making predictions about how somebody is likely

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 perform in the future.

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 “The patterns become clearer and clearer,” he told us, “so it becomes easy to get a fix on exactly what the individual’s strengths and weaknesses are today. It discloses the likelihood that a person will

Yellow highlight | Page: 81 minimize weaker points. If the pattern is there of extracting success out of the jaws of defeat, that makes you want to hire somebody.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 83 This is where you will hear the stories behind the polished statements on a resume. In our experience, most

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 candidates naturally focus on what really mattered to them at that time in their career rather than regurgitate what they put on their resume.

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 A Players tend to talk about outcomes linked to expectations. B and C Players talk generally about events, people they met, or aspects of the job they liked without ever getting into results.

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 Our recommendation is to reframe the question over and over until the candidate gets the message. “What went really wrong? What was your biggest mistake? What would you have done differently? What part of the job did you not like? In what ways were

Yellow highlight | Page: 84 your peers stronger than you?” Don’t let the candidate off the hook. Keep pushing until the candidate shares the lows.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 Begin by asking candidates for their boss’s name. Ask them to spell it for you, and make a point to show them you are writing it down.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 “John Smith, you say? That is S, M, I, T, H, right?” Forcing candidates to spell the name out no matter how common it might be sends a powerful message: you are going to call, so they should tell the truth.

Yellow highlight | Page: 85 Now ask, “What will Mr. Smith say were your biggest strengths and areas for improvement?” Be sure to say will, not would.

Yellow highlight | Page: 88 A Players are highly valued by their bosses. B and C Players often are not.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 Thank you for taking the time to visit us today. As we have already discussed, we are going to do a chronological interview to walk through each job you have held. For each job I am going to ask you five core questions: What were you hired to do? What accomplishments are you most proud of? What were some low points during that job? Who were the people you

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 worked with? Why did you leave that job?

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 At the end of the interview we will discuss your career goals and aspirations, and you will have a chance to ask me questions.

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 Eighty percent of the process is in this room, but if we mutually decide to continue, we will conduct reference calls to complete the process.

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 this sounds like a lengthy interview, it will go remarkably fast. I want to make sure you have the opportunity to share

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 your full story, so it is my job to guide the pace of the discussion. Sometimes, we’ll go into more depth in a period of your career. Other times, I will ask that we move on to the next topic. I’ll try to make sure we leave plenty of time to cover your

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 most recent, and frankly, most relevant jobs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 94 Setting expectations will put the candidate at ease and enable you to launch into the first chapter of his or her career with minimal confusion

Yellow highlight | Page: 95 You will have to interrupt the candidate at least once every three or four minutes, so get ready.

Yellow highlight | Page: 95 The good way to interrupt somebody is to smile broadly, match their enthusiasm level, and use reflective listening to get them to stop talking without demoralizing them. You say, “Wow! It sounds like that pig farm next to the corporate office smelled horrible!” The candidate nods and says “Yes!” and appreciates your empathy and respect. Then you immediately say, “You were just telling me about

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 is through maintaining very high rapport that you get the most valuable data, and polite

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 interrupting can build that rapport.

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 you can use to clarify how valuable an accomplishment was in any context. The questions are:

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 How did your performance compare to the previous year’s performance? (For example, this person achieved sales of $2 million and the previous year’s sales were only $150,000.)

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 How did your performance compare to the plan?

Yellow highlight | Page: 96 How did your performance compare to that of peers? (For example, this person sold $2 million and was ranked first among thirty peers; the next-best performer sold only

Yellow highlight | Page: 97 People who perform well are generally pulled to greater opportunities. People who perform poorly are often pushed out of their jobs. Do not hire anybody who has been pushed out of 20 percent or more of their jobs. From our experience, those folks have a three times higher chance of being a chronic B or C Player.

Yellow highlight | Page: 97 Pull. “My biggest client hired me.” “My old boss recruited me to a bigger job.” “The CEO asked me to take a double promotion.” “A former peer went to a competitor and referred me to his boss.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 As with all of the interviews we present in this book, get curious after every answer by using the “What? How? Tell me more” framework, and keep asking until you understand what the person did and how he or she did it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 In addition, let’s say you have identified six competencies that define success in the job: 1. Aggressive 2. Persistent 3. Hires A Players 4. Holds people accountable 5. Follows through on commitments 6. Open to criticism and feedback

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 Mike Ahearn, First Solar’s CEO, painted the big picture for us. “We are a fast-moving, aggressive company.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 They need to be results-oriented people who work toward continuous improvement.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 And they have to put safety first, build deep customer relationships, and recognize that people matter.

Yellow highlight | Page: 107 “What were the person’s biggest areas for improvement back then?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 109 answers. If you want to find out about a football team, the last person you talk to is the head coach. Don’t believe the coach. You talk to the players and the trainer and the managers.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 But he spent two hours of his time to save $10. So his need to win in that way makes him do stupid things. You should beware of candidates who need to win to an unhealthy extent because they will be battling you and your colleagues over petty things.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 “Starting a sentence with ‘no,’ ‘but,’ or ‘however’ during the interview process. ‘Yes, that is a great idea’ is the right answer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 ‘No, I agree with you but’ is the symptom of somebody with an overactive ego who might be challenging to work with.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 “Making destructive comments about previous colleagues is a huge red flag. Because once this person works for you, he or she will make the same needless sarcastic comments about you!

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 “Passing the buck. Blaming is always bad. Winners don’t blame.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 “Making excuses. Ask people what their challenges were. If they say that their biggest challenges were

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 not their fault but other people’s fault, that shows they do not take responsibility for their performance.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 “The excessive need to ‘be me.’ Listen for comments like ‘That’s just me, I’m not organized.’ ‘That’s just me, I’m impatient.’ ‘That’s just me, I don’t include other people in decisions. That’s just the way I am.’ Beware. Somebody who has an excessive need to ‘be me’ is telling you that they are not open to adapt their style to fit your culture or your company and

Yellow highlight | Page: 120 But wait, you are not finished. Have you heard the riddle about the five frogs on a log? It goes like this: Five frogs are on a log and one decides to jump off. How many are left? If you answered “five,” you are correct. Deciding to do something and actually doing it are two different things. You have decided who you should hire. Now it is time to take the final step: selling the person on actually joining your team.

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 questions. Probe for more information by using the “What? How? Tell me more” framework.

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 Conduct a Who Interview of one and a half to three hours by walking chronologically through a candidate’s career, using the same five questions for each job or chapter in the person’s work history. The hiring manager and one other colleague should conduct the interview in tandem. 3. FOCUSED INVERVIEW(S): Involve others in the hiring process by assigning team members to conduct interviews that focus on the outcomes and/or competencies on the scorecard. 4. CANDIDATE DISCUSSION: Following each day of interviews, grade the scorecard using the skill-will framework. Advance those whose skill (what they are fundamentally good at doing) and will (what they want to do, and in what type of culture) match the mission, outcomes, and competencies on your scorecard. Look for people whom you would rate an A on the critical outcomes and key competencies. Nobody is perfect, but seek those who are strong in the most important places of your scorecard. 5. REFERENCE INTERVIEW: Conduct seven reference calls with people you choose from the Who Interview. Ask the candidate to set up the calls to break through the gatekeepers while minimizing your own effort. 6. FINAL DECISION: Repeat your analysis of the skill-will profile to

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 Most managers fail to sell a candidate.

Yellow highlight | Page: 124 line. The five areas, which we call the five F’s of selling, are: fit, family, freedom, fortune, and fun.

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 Alec Gores uses this approach with every hire. “I tell them the vision and

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 where we are heading, and they get excited,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 “They have to understand my vision. They have to become part of the formula. We are all in the same boat. We make money the same way, and we go forward the same way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 125 “Show that you are as concerned with the fit for them as you are in the fit for you. Ninety-nine percent of your competitors are not doing that. It is a key differentiator. You will be the one who cares enough to see if there is something for them here.

Yellow highlight | Page: 126 The challenge, Echavarría told us, is to walk them through the larger fit with company and culture.

Yellow highlight | Page: 126 “Our corporate culture is low-key. It is a family company, not a public company. We have a high appreciation for values. We don’t like people who are too ostentatious or too self-sufficient. We are multinational, so we need people who can adapt to foreign cultures and our company culture.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 29 how they work, I, too, thought of myself as more talented than others, maybe even more worthy than others because of my endowments. The scariest thought, which I rarely entertained, was the possibility of being ordinary. This kind of thinking led me to need constant validation. Every comment, every look was meaningful—it registered on my intelligence scorecard, my attractiveness scorecard, my likability scorecard. If a day went well, I could bask in my high numbers.
