Yellow highlight | Page: 60 “I’m looking,” Rickey told him, “for a ball player with the guts not to fight back.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 61 hotheaded

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 Our own path, whatever we aspire to, will in some ways be defined by the amount of nonsense we are willing to deal with.

Yellow highlight | Page: 62 “[lose] temper as a refuge from despair.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 63 will be subjected to treatment ranging from indifference to outright sabotage. Count on it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 63 absolute opposite of what is needed. Who can afford to be jerked around by impulses, or believe that you’re god’s gift to humanity, or too important to put up with anything you don’t like? Those who have subdued their ego understand that it doesn’t degrade you when others treat you poorly; it degrades them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 63 You want to remind them of what they’ve forgotten; your ego screams for you to indulge it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 Play the game. Ignore the noise; for the love of God, do not let it distract you.

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 Restraint is a difficult skill but a critical one. You will often be tempted, you will probably even be overcome. No one is perfect with it, but try we must.

Yellow highlight | Page: 65 But he learned early that the tight-rope he walked would tolerate only restraint and had no forgiveness for ego. Honestly, not many paths do.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 “The first product of self-knowledge is humility,” Flannery O’Connor once said. This is how we fight the ego, by really knowing ourselves.

Yellow highlight | Page: 77 What am I missing right now that a more humble person might see?

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 We are still striving, and it is the strivers who should be our peers—not the proud and the accomplished.

Yellow highlight | Page: 79 The distinction between a professional and a dilettante occurs right there—when you accept that having an idea is not enough; that you must work until you are able to recreate your experience effectively in words on the page.

Yellow highlight | Page: 80 “A poet’s function… is not to experience the poetic state: that is a private affair. His function is to create it in others.” That is, his job is to produce work.

Yellow highlight | Page: 80 “You can’t build a reputation on what you’re going to do,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 80 psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi’s

Yellow highlight | Page: 86 And we can set upon positive habits that will last a lifetime.

Yellow highlight | Page: 90 crutches. It will be a lonely fight to be real, to say “I’m not going to take the edge off.” To say, “I am going to be myself, the best version of that self. I am in this for the long game, no matter how brutal it might be.” To do, not be.

Yellow highlight | Page: 91 Why is success so ephemeral? Ego shortens it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 91 Sobriety, open-mindedness, organization, and purpose—these are the great stabilizers.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 one, of proud ambition and ostentatious avidity. The other, of humble modesty and equitable justice.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 Two different models, two different pictures, are held out to us, according to which we may fashion our own character and behaviour;

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 the one more gaudy and glittering in its colouring; the other more correct and more exquisitely beautiful in its outline.

Yellow highlight | Page: 97 Eventually, ego killed Howard Hughes as much as the mania and trauma did—if they were ever separate to begin with.

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 but ego has the same roots—insecurity, fear, a dislike for brutal objectivity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 “Man is pushed by drives,” Viktor Frankl observed. “But he is pulled by values.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 99 On top of all this, we have to build an organization and a system around what we do—one that is about the work and not about us.

Yellow highlight | Page: 102 “a persistent cycle of pragmatic learning, experimental adaptation, and constant revision driven by his uniquely disciplined and focused will.”

Note:nice

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 It is not enough only to be a student at the beginning. It is a position that one has to assume for life. Learn from everyone and everything. From the people you beat, and the people who beat you, from the people you dislike, even from your supposed enemies. At every step and every juncture in life, there is the opportunity to learn—and even if the lesson is purely remedial, we must not let ego block us from hearing it again.

Yellow highlight | Page: 105 Put yourself in rooms where you’re the least knowledgeable person. That uncomfortable feeling, that defensiveness that you feel when your most deeply held assumptions are challenged—what about subjecting yourself to it deliberately? Change your mind. Change your surroundings.

Yellow highlight | Page: 105 An amateur is defensive. The professional finds learning (and even, occasionally, being shown up) to be enjoyable; they like being challenged and humbled, and engage in education as an ongoing and endless process.

Yellow highlight | Page: 109 Old School, these explanations and stories get “cobbled together later, more or less sincerely, and after the stories have been repeated they put on the badge of memory and block all other routes of exploration.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 110 deceptively small things—that was responsible for the team’s transformation and victory.

Yellow highlight | Page: 110 To accept the title and the story wouldn’t be a harmless personal gratification. These narratives don’t change the past, but they do have the power to negatively impact our future. His players shortly proved the risks inherent in letting a story go to their heads.

Yellow highlight | Page: 110 This is what happens when you prematurely credit yourself with powers you don’t yet have control of.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 Facts are better than stories and image.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 “Don’t try to buy at the bottom and sell at the top. This can’t be done—except by liars.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 The founding of a company, making money in the market, or the formation of an idea is messy.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 Reducing it to a narrative retroactively creates a clarity that never was and never will be there.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 When we are aspiring we must resist the impulse to reverse engineer success from other people’s stories. When we achieve our own, we must resist the desire to pretend that everything unfolded exactly as we’d planned. There was no grand narrative.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 You should remember—you were there when it happened.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 explicitly warns startups against having bold, sweeping visions early on.

Yellow highlight | Page: 111 he wants to fund companies that massively disrupt industries and change the world—that’s where the money is.

Yellow highlight | Page: 112 “The way to do really big things seems to be to start with deceptively small things.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 112 you start with a small bet and iteratively scale your ambitions as you go.

Yellow highlight | Page: 112 “Keep your identity small,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 113 The same goes for us, whatever we do. Instead of pretending that we are living some great story, we must remain focused on the execution—and on executing with excellence. We must shun the false crown and continue working on what got us here. Because that’s the only thing that will keep us here.

Yellow highlight | Page: 115 That’s how it seems to go: we’re never happy with what we have, we want what others have too. We want to have more than everyone else. We start out knowing what is important to us, but once we’ve achieved it, we lose sight of our priorities. Ego sways us, and can ruin us.

Yellow highlight | Page: 116 All of us waste precious life doing things we don’t like, to prove ourselves to people we don’t respect, and to get things we don’t want.

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 On an individual level, however, it’s absolutely critical that you know who you’re competing with and why, that you have a clear sense of the space you’re in.

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 it is the sense of our own path and how to stay on it without getting distracted by all the others that intersect it. In other words, it’s not about beating the other guy. It’s not about having more than the others. It’s about being what you are, and being as good as possible at it, without succumbing to all the things that draw you away from it. It’s about going where you set out to go. About accomplishing the most that you’re capable of in what you choose. That’s it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 It’s time to sit down and think about what’s truly important to you and then take steps to forsake the rest. Without this, success will not be pleasurable, or nearly as complete as it could be. Or worse, it won’t last.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 Ego rejects trade-offs. Why compromise? Ego wants it all.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 So why do you do what you do? That’s the question you need to answer.

Yellow highlight | Page: 121 Achieving success involved ignoring the doubts and reservations of the people around us. It meant rejecting rejection. It required taking certain risks. We could have given up at any time, but we’re here precisely because we didn’t.

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 Driven to prove the doubters wrong? Welcome to the seeds of paranoia.

Yellow highlight | Page: 122 But you can’t let the walls close in on you. You’ve got to get yourself—and your perceptions—under control.

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 Probably because he was in such command of his own temper, Franklin decided that writing the letter was cathartic enough. He never sent it.

Yellow highlight | Page: 127 He knew that urgent and important were not synonyms. His job was to set the priorities, to think big picture, and then trust the people beneath him to do the jobs they were hired for.

Yellow highlight | Page: 127 we can be idiosyncratic, we can compensate for disorganization with hard work and a little luck. That’s not going to cut it in the majors. In fact, it’ll sink you if you can’t grow up and organize.

Yellow highlight | Page: 128 “had the ability to recognize a good opportunity but he didn’t know how to make it happen.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 129 DeLorean couldn’t manage himself, and so he had trouble managing others. And so he managed to fail, both himself and the dream.

Yellow highlight | Page: 129 Management? That’s the reward for all your creativity and new ideas? Becoming the Man? Yes—in the end, we all face becoming the adult supervision we originally rebelled against.

Yellow highlight | Page: 130 your responsibilities may begin to change. Days become less and less about doing and more and more about making decisions. Such is the nature of leadership. This transition requires reevaluating and updating your identity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 131 Responsibility requires a readjustment and then increased clarity and purpose.

Yellow highlight | Page: 145 “Fear is a bad advisor.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 146 That is sobriety. That is command of oneself.

Your Kindle Notes For: The Start-up of You: Adapt to the Future, Invest in Yourself, and Transform Your Career Reid Hoffman and Ben Casnocha Last accessed on Sunday September 4, 2016 77 Highlight(s) | 0 Note(s)

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 “Only the paranoid survive.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 15 Success, he meant, is fragile—and perfection, fleeting.

Yellow highlight | Page: 17 the hubris that comes from success, the failure to recognize and match competition, an unwillingness to exploit opportunities that contain risk, and an inability to adapt to relentless change.

Yellow highlight | Page: 21 “Most of the time, change in the world overtakes you,”

Yellow highlight | Page: 22 “Though we are optimistic, we must remain vigilant and maintain a sense of urgency.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 27 unless it’s first, only, faster, better, or cheaper—it’s not going to command anyone’s attention.

Yellow highlight | Page: 29 If you want to chart a course that differentiates you from other professionals in the marketplace, the first step is being able to complete the sentence, “A company hires me over other professionals because …” How are you first, only, faster, better, or cheaper than other people who want to do what you’re doing in the world? What are you offering that’s hard to come by? What are you offering that’s both rare and valuable?

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 The most brilliant business idea is often the one that builds on the founders’ existing assets in the most brilliant way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 31 Their business goals emerged from their strengths, interests, and network of contacts.

Yellow highlight | Page: 32 During a career transition, someone who can go six to twelve months without earning money has different options—indeed, a significant advantage—over someone who can’t go more than a month or two without a paycheck.

Yellow highlight | Page: 32 is to go to a networking event and ask people about their professional problems or needs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 32 A competitive edge emerges when you combine different skills, experiences, and connections.

Yellow highlight | Page: 33 So if you think you lack certain assets that would make you more competitive, don’t use it as an excuse. Start developing them.

Yellow highlight | Page: 34 For a start-up, a compelling vision that acts as a pole star is a meaningful piece of a company’s competitive advantage.

Yellow highlight | Page: 44 “Because of my [skill/experience/strength], I can do [type of professional work] better than [specific types of other professionals in my industry].”

Yellow highlight | Page: 55 he told her. It was outstanding advice: Work in a market with natural momentum. Ride the big waves.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 “The reason I don’t have a plan is because if I have a plan I’m limited to today’s options,” she says.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 Winning careers, like winning start-ups, are in permanent beta: always a work in progress.

Yellow highlight | Page: 57 It’s important to understand, though, that while entrepreneurial companies and people are always evolving, the choices they’re making are disciplined, not random.

Yellow highlight | Page: 60 They read about stocks and bonds instead of reading books that improve their mind.

Yellow highlight | Page: 60 They focus, in short, on hard assets instead of soft assets. This is a mistake. We’re not suggesting you be a starving, unshaven graduate student forever; you do need to earn money and build economic assets. But as much as you can, prioritize plans that offer the best chance at learning

Yellow highlight | Page: 60 about yourself and the world.

Yellow highlight | Page: 60 “Which plan will grow my soft assets the fastest?” Even simpler: “Which plan offers the most learning potential?”

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 make the headline of your LinkedIn profile not a specific job title (e.g., “VP of Marketing at Company X”) but personal-brand or asset-focused (e.g., “Entrepreneur. Product Strategist. Investor.”).

Yellow highlight | Page: 64 This way, you’ll have a professional identity that you can carry with you as you shift jobs. You own yourself. It’s the start-up of you.

Yellow highlight | Page: 66 I learned that product/market fit—the focus of product management—mattered more than user experience or design.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 And because product management is vital in any product organization, work experience in the area tends to lead to more diverse career opportunities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 It’s a common catch-22: for jobs that require prior experience, how do you get the experience the first time?

Yellow highlight | Page: 67 My solution: do the job for free on the side. I sought out the head of product management within the eWorld group at Apple, James Isaacs, and told him I had a few product ideas. I offered to write them up in addition to everything else I was doing, and I did. Product managers reviewed my ideas and gave me feedback and encouragement.

Yellow highlight | Page: 68 All important lessons I wouldn’t have gained any way other than by setting foot in the industry.

Yellow highlight | Page: 76 The reason many people do not embrace trial and error, learning by doing, adaptation, and the other themes of this chapter is because these strategies introduce real uncertainty. It’s easy to say “learn by doing”—but what if you’re not sure what you’ll learn or what you should do?

Yellow highlight | Page: 78 Make a plan to develop more transferable skills, those skills and experiences that are broadly useful to potential other jobs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 87 Research shows that a team in the business world will tend to perform at the level of the worst individual team member.

Yellow highlight | Page: 92 The first is seeing the world from the other person’s perspective. No one knows this better than the skilled entrepreneur.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 The second requirement is thinking about how you can help and collaborate with the other person rather than thinking about what you can get from him or her.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 think about how you can help first.

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 A study on negotiation found that a key difference between skilled negotiators and average negotiators was the time spent searching for shared

Yellow highlight | Page: 93 interests, asking questions of the other person, and forging common ground.

Yellow highlight | Page: 98 every morning they showed up to work two and a half hours before their already long and grueling shift began.

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 “In a business that is so crazy, to actually know that there is somebody who is really smart, who you care about, who has your interests, and who is rowing in the same direction, is something of immense value.” That’s an ally.

Yellow highlight | Page: 101 felt inspired by Mark’s wild creativity and how at times he seems to bounce off the walls with energy.

Yellow highlight | Page: 102 Zynga and Facebook would be very strong companies, but no one could have predicted the astronomical heights of success.

Yellow highlight | Page: 103 David Brooks, is “habitual reciprocity that becomes coated

Yellow highlight | Page: 104 In other words, as the score keeping becomes less and less formal and as the expectation for reciprocal exchange stretches over a longer and longer period of time, a relationship goes from being an exchange partnership to being a true alliance.

Yellow highlight | Page: 105 The friends you don’t know very well are the ones who refer winning jobs.

Yellow highlight | Page: 105 In contrast, weak ties usually sit outside of the inner circle. You’re not necessarily going to introduce a looser connection to all of your other friends. Thus, there’s a greater likelihood a weak tie will be exposed to new information or a job opportunity.

Yellow highlight | Page: 106 what is valuable is the breadth and reach of your network.

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 garnered the highest response rates included phrases like “You mention …” or “I noticed that …” or “I’m curious what.…”17 In other words, phrases that showed that the person had carefully read the other’s profile. People do this in online dating, but when it comes to professional correspondence, for whatever reason, it doesn’t get done.

Yellow highlight | Page: 117 and generic requests. If you spend thirty minutes researching a person in your extended network (LinkedIn is a great place to start), and tailor your request for an introduction to something you’ve learned, your request will stand out.

Yellow highlight | Page: 118 In contrast, the social networks of the people behind successful productions had a healthy balance: some of the people involved had preexisting relationships and some didn’t. There were some strong ties, some weak ties. There was some established trust among the producers, but also enough new blood in the system to generate new ideas.

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 “Tell me more about your skills, interests, and background.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 123 To give helpful help you need to have a sense of your friend’s values and priorities so that your offer of help can be relevant and specific.

Yellow highlight | Page: 129 Because he had allocated money to follow through on a predecided policy, he didn’t have to worry about the cost of flights or the stress of decision making.

Yellow highlight | Page: 130 who’s figured out that precommitting yourself to do something makes sure it actually happens.

Yellow highlight | Page: 133 status dynamics around him; failed to account for the insecurities, status anxieties, and egos of everyone else. He failed to build relationships with the people above him and below him on the totem pole. And ultimately, he paid the price with his job.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Look at your calendar for the past six months and identify the five people you spend the most time with—are you happy with the influence those five people are having on you?

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Introduce two people you know who do not know each other. Make sure the intro will be useful to both sides. (Visit startupofyou.com if you need help on how to craft the actual introduction email.) Then think about a challenge you are dealing with and ask an existing connection for an introduction to someone who could help. Jump-start the process by offering a small gift (such as a relevant article) to the person you want to meet.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Imagine you got laid off from your job today. Who are the ten people you’d email to solicit their advice on what to do next? Reach out to them now, when you don’t need anything specifically.

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 Pick one person in your network who is a weaker tie but with whom you might like to have a stronger alliance. Commit to trying to help him or her proactively by giving small gifts. These can be anything from sending the person an

Yellow highlight | Page: 138 interesting article to helping them prepare for a presentation to forwarding a job posting. Invest serious time and energy in the relationship over several months.

Yellow highlight | Page: 142 Create an “interesting people fund” to which you automatically funnel a certain percentage of your paycheck. Use it to pay for coffees, lunches, and the occasional plane ticket to meet new people and shore up existing relationships.

Yellow highlight | Page: 142 More advanced tips on how to invest in your network are available at www.startupofyou.com.

Yellow highlight | Page: 149 “Everyone’s looking for an opportunity, even if they don’t know it.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 152 By being in motion, you are spinning a web as wide and as tall as possible in order to catch any interesting opportunities that come your way.

Yellow highlight | Page: 160 Shared experiences lead to trust, which leads to people’s sharing information and opportunities.

Yellow highlight | Page: 162 When you feel like you’re going nowhere. When you may be short on funds or allies or both. When no one is knocking at your door inviting you to stuff. These situations call for the most entrepreneurial opportunity-generating strategy of this chapter: hustle.

Yellow highlight | Page: 167 Potentially. When you have no resources, you create them. When you have no choice but to fight, you fight hard. When you have no choice but to create, you create.

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 Rick Hanson

Yellow highlight | Page: 178 “To keep our ancestors alive, Mother Nature evolved a brain that routinely tricked them into making three mistakes: overestimating threats, underestimating opportunities, and underestimating resources (for dealing with threats and fulfilling opportunities).” The result is that we’re programmed to overestimate the risk in any given situation.2

Yellow highlight | Page: 179 Anxiety about how your boss will react to an unconventional proposal will overpower feelings of optimism that he’ll be impressed by your work.

Yellow highlight | Page: 181 You’ll never be fully certain. Don’t conflate uncertainty with risk.

Yellow highlight | Page: 182 But the biggest and best opportunities frequently are the ones with the most question marks. Don’t let uncertainty lull you into overestimating the risk.

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 “Be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful.

Yellow highlight | Page: 183 contrarian

Yellow highlight | Page: 189 You gain the “ability to absorb shocks gracefully.”

Yellow highlight | Page: 189 join and create groups, be in motion, take on side projects, hustle. In

Yellow highlight | Page: 195 How you gather, manage, and use information will determine whether you win or lose.”

Serdar Korur
Data Scientist and PhD in Molecular Biology

Serdar is a Data Scientist and PhD in Cell Biology
